figure.p: PANDION and AMPHIGENIA Or The Hitorie of the Coy Lady Adorned with Sculpture,

div.p: PANDION AND AMPHIGENIA: OR, THE HISTORY OF THE Coy Lady OF THESSALIA Adorned with Sculptures. By J. CROWNE.
LONDON, Printed by I. G. for R. Mills, at the ign of the Petel and Mortar without Temple-Barr, Anno, 1665.

div.head: To the Right Honorable ARTHUR Lord Vicount CHICHESTER, Earl of DONEGAL, And one of His Majeties mot Honorable Privy Council for the Kingdom of Ireland.
div.p:
THis poor Off-pring of my vacant hours, having lept awhile in the hades of obcurity and ilence, I knew not when it might better walk abroad, and take the Air of popular cenure, than in the Sun-hine of your Lordhip Patronage. I am very enible of the meannes of the Subject (being wholly fictitious) and the poverty of its dres; and none can think more contemptibly of it than my elf: I was carce twenty years of Age when I fancyed it, and therefore it mut needs want thoe maculine conceits as do violence to mens undertandings. I am not ignorant that things of this nature are onely
to eae and upple a Brain that hath long bin in the Rack of everer Studies: and I am afraid this will hardly be preferred to o noble a ue, ince a lofty Intellect that hath been Airing its Wings in clear and ublime Meditations, will hardly toop to Bath in the puddle of thee low and ordid Fancies. If throughout the whole Utopia, there be an expresion, or a peron whoe Character or Pasion may deerve a tranient glance from your eye, it hath commenced a degree of Honor above my expectations. And I hall eteem my elf highly and generouly rewarded, if I may hereby in any degree merit the title of,
div.closer: My Lord, Your Lordhips mot humble, and mot obedient ervant, John Crowne.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
IT was on a day, that as Time rode by in the Chariot of the Sun, I reolved to go in Pilgrimage to Parnaus; and borrowing ome few idle hours of that old bald-pated Uurer to bear my expences, I weaved me a Hermits Gown of Opportunities for clock, and took for a Staff a Sun-beam, and o accoutred I went to do my devoire to the nine Patronees of Poeie. Where after a long and tedious peregrination I arrived; but no ooner arrived than I beheld to my atonihment, the Widowed chanel that once had embraced the Catalian Springs weet off pring, detitute of its murmuring ociety, and of the delight it once took in its moit kies, and protitute to a new black complexion'd Lover; the bubling womb whence that progeny was extracted, being turned to a Grave, where Oblivion lay entombed; that treaury of liquid Pearls that ued of yore to enrich old Poets Brains, wherewith they o oft bepangled their Poems, being quite exhauted. Some aid it was thence conveyed into little Citerns, and o conducted thorough lender pipes into a vat Conduit. Others aid the thirty throats of Lovers, parch't with Beauties Raies had will'd it up. I as an impartial Judge imputed it to both. Next I looked round to ee if I could epy the Mues; but Time it eemed had long ago ravihed thoe weet
Virgins from that olitary place. Some aid they were dead and Coffin'd up in Poets Souls. Others aid, they erved as Handmaids to fond Lovers Paramors. I as an unintereed Umpire imputed it to neither, but judged they were fled to heaven to renew their Bankrupted tores. Thus grieved to ee my journey frutrate, I reolved however to Banquet my eyes with the ight of that forked mountain, that once had been the pleaant Throne where the nine Virgin Queens were wont to it, Crowned with Lawrel, on a green Carpet wrought with Fore's embroidery, tuning their enchanting Laies to Ecch • es reounding Acc • nts; but turning to behold it, I aw nothing but the Plain whoe houlders had once born that huge pile of earth; when truck into a tranport with admiration at this montrous product of Time, I was told by the tanders by, that ome Modern Gyants of w • t had born it thence, intending to cal Heaven, and plunder it of its choicet rarities, wherewith to fill the heavenly Coffers of their minds. Thee words were as an alarum to my murmuring thoughts, which now began to mutiny againt my repoe; whom whilt I trove to appeae, I heard from a confued Mas of Rocks and Stones, the mot oul-entrancing-melody that ever was begotten of the Airs fluid womb; uch as would have compelled a Stoick to leep his mind in thoe oft pleaures, whoe every tone ounded like a Diapason, and all its accents like the very relihes and cloes of that heavenly Muick, Angels and beatified
ouls compoe, when in their Silver Bowers, they joyn in Conort, and make the Arches of that Empyreal Orb reound the Eulogies they ing in praie of their immortal olace. No ooner were thee Airs convey'd into the Labyrinth of my ear, but I felt my elf confounded with udden ravihment; when demanding of the Auditory, whether Melody it elf lay interred under that Chaos? Reply was made, that they were onely ome few Reliques of thoe ravihing trains Apollo ued to charm ouls withall, when playing on his Viol he made the Air dance her rarest meaures, in thouands of weet forms, after his nimbly quavering fingers, whoe melody made the very eneles tones become Epicures, who loath to part with their delight, hoorded up its Silver ound in their obdurate, treauries. Scarce had my mind lent attendance to the cadence of their peech, ere I was natcht I knew not how, I knew not whither. Whilt I lay extaied with this harmony, I aw in a Viion, a young Mue in tattered habit, holding in her hand the pourtraiture of a man, drawn by the Pencil of Nature o exquiitely, that it eemed the perfect Character of a Divine Idea, for no humane fancy could devie uch an excellent draught. His looks were the Enigns of ome eminence in him, more than humane; o that he eemed the Epitome of the whole worlds excellencies: The Princely Air of his countenance eeming as a refracting medium of the beams of an illustrious Soul; that he almost confirmed in me, that before doubted Platonim,
That Angels are united to bodies. As I was feeding my admiration with this admirable ight, I heard a voice proclame in my ears, Copy out this repreentation. Fain would I have made my own inability the excue of my neglect, and made anwer, that uch uperlative excellencies did trancend my comprehenion, much more my expreions; and that it ufficed that they were their own blazons, ince none could ufficiently emblazon them; and as for me, I would imitate the adorers of the Sun, not being able to encircle his head in a Lawrel Crown, I'de acrifize ome few Poetick Flowers to his praie. Thee thoughts retored my revolted enes to their Offices, when no ooner awaked, and that I had taken acquaintance with my elf, but I aw the Mue that appeared to me in my Viion, who came running to me, and preently Midwived ome conceipts, that my Brain was then in travail withall; which when born he wrapped up in ome cattered plumes that the Mues had left behind them, and o preented it to the Nurery of wits the Pres; which (Reader) here I devote unto thee. Who if thou beet one of thoe whoe queamih tomacks naueat every thing, but what's of their own dresing, I hall not wonder if thou canst not empanch this illdret-garbage, ince the rarities of a more curious fancy, Cook't by a cleanlier Mue, offend thy palate. Doubtles Brains is the bet auce for this ort of dihes, but Neceity is the bet Apology. Want and ordidnes are like Aeneas and Achates ineparable
coitinerants. As her youth may eaily excue her want of skill to weave a fine-pun-webb wherein to array her Progeny. She is not yet emancipata, and therefore no wonder if not o inewy, vigorous and prightly, as thoe that have arrived to the third or fourth climacterical. The way then for thee to banquet thy own Genius, is not to feed on thee jejune weak conceipts, but rather on ome more polite, accurate piece of thy own compoing, whoe excellency may be et off by the foil of my deficiency; for o men augment the Suns refulgency, by comparing them with the gloomy hades. Again, if thou beet one, who ettet up thee few Pictures of my fancies confued Ideaes, in the Gallery of thy thoughts, thinking to adorn it, with the quaint alluions, acute Criticims, high-flown raptures, and big-wollen words, that may be expected to fall from a Pen that endeavors to limn out the pourtraiture of Vertue; let me anticipate that wonder, a rational conjecture tells me an unexpected deluion will create in thee, by telling thee before hand, this Cabinet encloes no uch treaure. I cannot tell which I was mot unhappy in, in my perambulation, whether to forget to pas thorough France, and there to have adapted my tongue and pen to the moding complements wherewith that Ceremonious Nation o neatly give the lye to themelves; or ele that during my abode in Thealy, I could not procure ome of the golden Fleece, which Jaon with the Argonautes brought from Colchis, of which to have pun my Mue a
glitering Veture. I mut confes, ambitious I was to trut it with the mot boytrous and Alla-mode Royters of our times, and therefore ent my Wits a Wool-gathering, to ee if they could pick up ome locks of it, and thats the reaon they come home o ragged. Some though they live in the frozen Zone of a Plebeian tupidity, will yet apparel their minds in futian, which ure is the reaon they Cough and pit out uch Phlegmatick conceipts; which oyterlike dotes, they will (in depite of any) fancy to enhrine the richet Pearls. To bolter up a crooked invention with fungous words, and putid phraes (methinks) makes the deformity more apparent. Volumes filled with uch empty inflations, inherit the Office of a foot-ball. As I ever hated uch barbarims, o I never delighted in complemental falities: and as I am a tranger to Silken language, o neither am I familiar with the expreions mot in Vogue. My endeavors have been rather to delineate humors and affections, than to affect humorous delineations. Or again, if thou beest a Lover, I marvail not if thou eteemet this Poem relihles, if thy eye dazled with the Rays of Beauty, can ee no lutre in this hady repreentation of that Paion: for there wants that pure Vestal fire, that hould devout my thoughts, and ditill my notions into a quinteence.

Or latly, to be brief, if thou beet ome Antick Mimick, that turning over th • e Pages, dot coff and deride, probably not with o good reaon, as if
every leaf were a Looking-glas, I depie thy everet cenures, and value not though thou make this little off-pring of my Invention a Martyr to thy Moroenes; as I ued my liberty in fancying, o do thou in approving or condemning.

To the benign Reader then do I principally dedicate thee droppings of my Pen; who as his clearey'd judgement will dicern this Fiction to be an Hopital of lame conceipts, o his judicious candor will erve as a crutch to obcure their haltings. If he meeteth not here with the mot exquiite illutrations, let him conider this is but the first eay. Natura non facit altum. None but Angels and pure pirits tript from all union with matter work intantaneouly, or derive their notions from infued Species. Beides, had I uch a vat big-bellied Fancy, that the very boundaries of Nature would eem too treight-lac't for it, yet whilt caged within the Univere, it mut not think to flutter out of the tate of imperfection. Perfection is the array reerved for Souls that have haked of their clayie mantle. However, as all that is here is mean, o all is Genuine; nothing tole, nothing trained. As my Mue is none of the rare Phaenixes of our Age, who eem to arie out of the picy net of Invention, from whence they perfume the world with odors more fragrant than thoe wherein the Arabian Nunn expires; o neither is he any of thoe dung-bread Scarabies, generated of the putrefaction of ome dead Mue, whoe works are onely glimmering lights, lightned at the
Torches of ome deceaed Poets, as Paper Urnes that contained nothing but his Ahes. In fine, he is no Jay trickt up in others feathers, nor Popinjay to parrat others Wit: So I hall conclude with a vere of weet-tongued Draytons,
Like me that lit, my honet Proe and Rimes
Nor care for Critick, nor Cenorious times.

body.div:
PANDION AND AMPHIGENIA.
NO ooner were Nights Sable Curtains drawn, and Aurora had opened her Roie Courts, but fair Cleodora aroe, and dipoeed her downy Bed of thoe perfections, which that Night had been a treaure of: And looking forth out of the window, to ee whether the eaon would permit her her uual Cutom, which was early (while others were fettered with Morpheus his Chains, and wrapped in Sleeps care-charming Mantle) to walk forth, ometimes into the Gardens, ometimes into the open Fields, and then into the hady Groves, feeding her mournful meditations with thoe objects, which in others would breed delight; and eeing each thing by diplaying its beauty to invite her among them; the Heavens painted with a Vermilion dye; the Roie morn having flung her elf among the Clouds, as if on purpoe to gaze on o weet an object; the sky intermixed with azure treaks, as indeavouring to imitate her Veins; the winged Choriters chirping in each Tree
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
their melodious Anthems, as in praie of o many excellencies united in perfection, and the odoriferous Flowers perfuming the Air, with fragrant odours, as if they trove to exceed the weetnes of her breath; he lipt on her morning habit, and walked out to betake her elf to her accutomed Soliloquies, and entertain her mind with thoe thoughts, that made her frequent unfrequented places, accounting them her mot delicious recreations; at firt the abundance of delight, for a while overwhelmed her Melancholike paions, but recovering her elf, he thus began to complain, What fatall Star is this whoe Petilential influence doth afflict me with uccedaneous orrows, and makes me daily fill the air with Complaints, as if my oul were griefs Exchequer? Miery and depair hath arreted all my powers, that all my words and thoughts are teeped in brine orrows, and not a part of me, but is forced to bear a part in this Conort, to make a horrid harmony in woe. My tongue, the Organ of my oul, blown by the ighing Bellows of my heart, never ceaeth its mournful tones, whilt the tears flow in uch unmeaurable meaure, from the floud-gates of my Eyes, as if my very Soul would be difued out of thoe perpetual treaming luces. Not a thought but is acrificed to him, on the Altar of a contant mind. And that that confounds me with endles woe, and makes my woes endlely profound, is not only an utter depair of ever being blet with the fruition of him (which alone were able to kill a lip-ick Lover, who with quaint Rhetorications can paint his Mitres face, and curl her hair with better art than he her elf, and think her tears love philters, each entence a heart-charming Exorcim, and every frown to dart a death) but that my affections hould be innated by one, for fading skin-thick beauty, whoe worth and valour, and all that might render him excellent,
I am wholly ignorant of. But Ah! my Soul, how daret thou entertain a dihonorable thought of one, by externals, Natures Minion, and thy darling? would Nature have Compiled o beautiful a fabrick, to be a receptacle for a deformed oul? Certainly he would not have made uch a Cabinet, but to place a Jewel in it, and that of no mean value neither; do we not ee how he hath framed the heavenly Orbes, of a more pure quinteential nature, than thee coure-grained Elementary bodies, et with glitring pangles, garnihed with millions of golden Scutchions, and all to be a fit Pavilion for the Sun, the worlds great General? And what is this dull blockih earth, but for blind Moles, Dens of wild Beats, graves of dead putriying Corps, and at bet for man to tread on? and as for Trees, Plants, and Flowers, do we not ee how they not induring to be imprioned within its bowels, break forth, triving to acend, and leave it; but that the Earth as loth to part with them, fetters them by the roots; And wherefore hath he made this Microm, Man, the Epitome and total umm of all the worlds Excellencies, but that it may befit to contain uch an Angelical Soul? And will he now be o prepoterous, as to make Pauanias excell all in beauty, but that he excels all in vertue? But what's all this to me? I do but Tantalize my elf with thee fond thoughts, ince cruel Fortune eparates me from him.
Thus he walked, regardles whither he went, until he was urprized with a glimmering light, appearing through the leaves and boughes; the uddennes whereof ilenced her incompoed thoughts, o that now he be took her elf to ee, what hould caue thee twinkling parks of light; and having gone ome few paces forward, he came to a little Plain, at the foot of a Hill, where lay the Relicks of a tately Edifice, as
might plainly appear by the ruins of it, upon which there tood a Chapel defaced by Antiquity, o that it was rather venerable than beautiful, only the ituation of it made it eem one of the weetet places in the earth; neer the Chapel, there was a Crytall Rivulet, whoe curled treams ran oftly along, murmuring that their Envious puruers would crowd them thence o oon. And paing through a Grove he came to the Chapel, and entering into it, he epyed a Lamp, and an Inkhorn and Paper lying upon a Table of Stone; he took the Paper, and looked into it, in which were written thee Veres:
Then mut I live, and will none pitty lend,
By ending me, at once to put an end
To thee my pains and tears, which ne're will ceae
Untill by death my Soul obtains releae?
Then when (O Soul) wilt flye and leave thee Chains,
Wherewith this Body cloggs thee, and thee pains,
Thee never ceaing pains, tormenting fires,
Which daily burn, to feed ome fond deires?
But (Ah!) poor Soul, long ince th' art fled and gone
To her, 'twixt whom ther's uch an union,
Made by affection, that although by death
I hould this body to the grave bequeath,
Yet ooner can thy elf diolved be,
And looe that knot of immortality,
Which makes thy woes eternal, than be able,
To looe that Union, which Love makes o table.
Pasions are like the flame, which once being felt
Within the breat, the Soul like Wax both melt;
Th' Idea is th' Impresion, which receiv'd,
Of it the pirit ne'er can be bereav'd.
What then if thou above the Clouds wert fled,
And left this clayie body, pale as Lead,
What wilt avail, if when thon dot divet
Thy elf of it, thou cant not be at ret?
Though left this Prion, if thee pasions fly,
And till bereave thee of thy liberty?
If when this body's burnt, and in an Urn,
Yet then with greater endles fires dot burn?
Only this hope remains, that though they may
Acend great Natures dictates to obey;
When thou their flaming Center dot attain,
They with that fiery Element will remain.
Mean while to all vain pleaures bid farewell,
Since th'art exil'd from her that doth excell
What Earths vat Wombe, or Heavens influence,
Did e're produce, all other excellence
Is but an Empty name, if not in her,
She is the ubtance, others hadows are;
They'r wie, fair, vertuous, if like her, for he
Is Wit and Beauty, patience, chatity.
Then ince by cruel fates, we parted are,
Henceforth I will be wedded to depair.
She read the Veres, and her own Experience made her to pity the Author, o that more out of Compaion than deert, he commended them; conidering alo they were the lines of one ubmert in orrows, and therefore unable to oar aloft, on the wings of an airy fancy. And having paued a while, he heard a igh accompanied with a ilent, but a deep-fetcht groan, which was eccho'd back by another from her, being moved thereto by the thoughts of her own hard fortune, which thoughts made her the more to pity him, whoe condition o neerly reembled hers, inomuch that a Pearl-like tear was ready to ditill from her Eyes; but her curioity putting her upon a farther inquiry, he took the Lamp, and went to the place whence the air
convey'd thoe ad accents to her ears. The firt Species that preented it elf to her view, was one in black upon a bed, and eeing him poes'd with Sleep, Deaths image, together with his pale looks, orrows continual concomitant, he almot thought he was a Carcae, not a man, but that he remembred he heard him igh. About his writ was a Bracelet of Hair, in which were wrought in Letters of Gold thee veres,
Though cruel fortune makes us part,
Yet you remain within my Heart,
FLORINDA.
With her looking upon the Bracelet, by the dazeling Lamp, he waked him, which he perceiving, Pity, a quality ineparable from the bet Natures, made her thus addres her peech to him; Sir, whoever you are, that thus eparate your elf from the World, by being Cloytered within thee doleful walls, let not a too paionate orrow prevail over all the faculties of your Soul, and Reaon it elf, which ought to be the helm whereby we teer our coure through the fluctuating billows of orrow. Take advice of one, who though a tranger to you, yet not to thee paions wherewith I perceive you burn; do not lavih out your elf in a pontaneous grief, let your tears prove Omens, and preage a greater evil. Tears are too brackih to quench, and Sighs are but wind, and more apt to excite than extinguih thee flames; therefore leave this retirednes, and who knows but Florinda may be yours, although hitherto ome Siniter frowns of Fortune hath blated your proceedings, which continually attend thoe who by Vertue apire to Honour and Happines.—Periander's pirits (for uch was his name) receiving o weet an alarm, uttered in uch a compaionate manner,
as made it plainly evident, her own paions bred that ympathy, made him think he was ome tutelary Angel ent from Heaven out of pity to direct him; and as if the very name of Florinda had as it were by a prophetick Enthuiam thus derived to him, breathed new life into him, he rouzed up his enes, and with a trembling, and as it were dying voice uttered this reply; Who is it that thus by endeavours cruelly merciful, rips up my wounds, fondly thinking thereby to cure them? Is that the way to eae a grief-burthened oul, to deny all eae? ure the mot Flagitious Villain the Earth bears, whom the World abhorrs for his improbous actions, may not be denyed a leave to mourn; The mot inhumane Tyrants that ever plagued the world with their horrid immanity, when they trove to make a dying oul urvive with cruciating pain, would uffer them to bewail their State; ouls laden with Woe, though ballated with Hope, will ink under Fortunes tormy frowns, unles they pump out thoe griefs that threaten detruction. But ah! my heart is tos'd with the urges of depair, and charged with overwhelming orrows, which unles I eek to diburthen, will augment to my unrecoverable ruine. And what though I hould abandon all Corroding Paions, would that repair my irreparable State? would that regain Florinda? Oh what more vain than uch deluding thoughts? Heaven jutly thinks me unworthy of o much Blis, and therefore interdicts me its enjoyment. Oh, if there be any parks of pity yet remaining, either put a period to my mieries, by ending my life, that I may no longer contemplate in my elf a pectacle of woe, or ele remove this light, that o no Object may be preented to my eyes, that may divert my mind from the thoughts of depair, and leave this penive place to me alone, being fit for none but thoe
devoted to miery, that o I may take my fill of orrow, ince nothing without Florinda, will give me contentment, but that wherein there is no content. And with that he fetcht a deep igh from the Heart, which intimated where the ditemper lay, which Cleodora hearing, he was at firt perplext in her mind, not knowing what coure to teer; one while he depair'd of ever framing conolation able to appeae uch vehement orrow, and therefore according to his deire thought to leave him a prey to his paions; but then compasion would utterly forbid that; at length the natural deire that is iucident to all humane pirits of knowing others afflictions, with the hope of giving ome eae by her advie added, caued her thus to break ilence; Sir (aid he) though the black clouds of Depair have o over-pread your Soul, as that there is not the leat ray or glympe of hope, whoe bright apect might revive you, yet let it not caue you to degenerate from Vertue, which makes the poeor inflexible under all adverity, like the rock that remains unmoved, though aaulted with the impetuous rage of the hoiterous Winds and roaring urges of the troubled Sea. He in whoe rich Soul Vertue hath once taken up her reidence, hath always a Halcion erenity within, whatever the tempetuous changes and chances of Fortune may be without; uch a one is placed in the mids of the variety of Viciitudes, as the Centre in a Globe, which remains fixt, notwithtanding all the Gyrations and ucceive Changes of poture in its adjacent parts. Hence Vertue to a wie man is not only as a lofty mountain, on which he may overtop the mity region where Fortune minteth and Contrives her various accidents, but as wings, that tranport his Spirit above the Stars, by which means he over-rules, controules, and bridles them at his pleaure, and hath
a greater influence on his own felicity, than all the Contellations in the Heavens. • orth treams of fire at his eyes, that made his face look like a prodigious Comet, that • ortended evident detruction to Pandion, his blows lighting like claps of Thunder, following the Ligh • ning that flahed from the Torches of his Eyes, which yet erved but to enkindle the flames of Pandions courage, o that at length uch a torm of Rage and Fury grew betwixt them, as howers of bloud decended from them both. So that whoever had een the Combat between Apollo and Python, Theeus and the fell Min •• aure, Hercules and the Nemean Lion, would have aid, that this had been a perfect reemblance and image of thoe, or rather they had been types and models of this rage, Hatred and didain exaperating the one, Fury, emulation and didaining to be didained anima • ing the other, o that if the one was prodigal of his bloudy gifts, the other was as generous to repay, and that with interet, even beyond the receivers deire, though hort of his own
will; (doubtful it was whether the one was more liberal or the other more thankful;) Clauus, Minotaure rus like, aaulting Pandion with uch a voluptuous appetite of Bloud, as though nothing could atisfy him but to broach all Pandions veins, encountring him with uch a labyrinth of trength, skill, fury and courage, that Pandion had no other thread to guide him out, but to cut the thread of Clauus's life, which he endeavoured to do with uch well-guided violence, as that though paion and dicretion eldome concurr, yet did he keep his paion within the limits and compas of dicretion, or rather teered his paion by dicretions compas, thruting and guarding with uch opportune activity, as that they both eemed but one Motion, and yet with uch active courage, as that he had oon reolved the doubt Periander was in, which would be the Conqueror, had he not found Clauus to be a man of invincible courage, and peerles excellency in matters of Arms; o that if Reaon and udden atonihment ever moved together in one Sphere without diturbance each of other, they did in Periander, whoe mot impartial and reaonable mind found reaon to be atonihed at the unexpected valour of uch a Youth as Pandion, who upplyed with his courage, wherein his trength was defective, and ince Nature had made him the leer of the two, he made skill attend and not contend with Nature, avoiding rather than guarding Clauus blows; but when opportunity preented, he would give his thruts with uch well-governed force, as that he would both offend his enemy, and defend himelf; fain he would by his frequent feignings have enticed Clauus to diadvantage, but he having more experience than Pandion, had as much skil to know how to defend himelf from harm, as the other to proer, o that they pent ome time in contending
Pandion layes Clauus page 61.
how to do, whilt that tyred them more than the very act of doing.
Clauus, whoe fearles mind, and matchles valour, and frequent ucces, had raied him to a confidence above hope, finding himelf thus matched by a Youth, inraged and ahamed that he hould be o long in conquering one, over whom though his valour hould render him victorious, yet he hould not merit the title of a Victor, ummon'd together all his active powers, and with united force, gave uch a blow on Pandion, that all the protection he could receive from his well-managed Sword, was to moderate the violence of the troak, which yet nevertheles lighted on the ide of his Head with uch a force, that it dipoeed his memory of its bruied habitation, and drove him ome few paces from the place where he tood, which Clauus perceiving, reolved not to neglect uch an opportunity, but purued him with redoubled blows, and reunited power.
But Pandion, as if his veins had been filled with Spirits, as fat as they were emptied of Bloud, mutring all his trength, skill and courage together, being to give a gallant Farewell, like the lat blaze of a dying light, ran with uch a vehement courage upon Clauus, that he not aware, but rahly proecuting victorious Fortune, the Sword run thorough his Heart, or rather he ran his Heart upon it, conque • ing himelf jut when he was triumphing on the conquet of his enemy; which when the Knights of the Catle p • rceived, not regarding the Laws of Arms, • lew in • o defend their Captain, or rather themelves, knowing that on the thrid of his Life hung all their Privileges, which • ut in two, mut needs fall to the ground, which conideration made them fall inconiderately on Pandion: which Periand • r eeing, enraged with
contempt of their Datardly baenes, to et upon a wounded man gaping for Life, and more to think that uch cowards hould be allotted him to be the Subjects of his valour, and mot of all to think that his friend and he hould receive their Deaths from the hands of uch micreants.
Being near over-preed with the multitude, he ruhed upon them with uch a torrent of violence, as drowned whomoever he encountred withall, in a lake of their own bloud, though urrounded with them, he could not avoid receiving ome blows, yet they erved but to encreae his rage to the extremity, o that with a mad violence, or furious madnes, all the powers of his Soul, and the Strength, Dexterity, and Activity of his Body transfer'd to the one arm, he dilived ome and diarmed others; his valour being cruhed between the two extremes, neceity of preerving his Friends and his own Life, and the difficulty of accomplihing it, made it o well within his breat, with the madnes of a terrible fury, that to the detruction and admiration of his enemies, he went beyond himelf in his atchievements, killing where he hit, and hitting where he pleaed, eparating ome not only their Souls from their Bodies, but their upper parts from their nether; others that were aiming where to lodge their blow, with the greatet advantage, he deprived of blow and ight and all: Whilt Pandion, not able to ait his friend, was forced to refreh his fainting body by reting himelf upon the ground. But they were oon aited by the Knights imprioned within the Catle, who knowing that their Jaylors were imprioned by Death, and eeing Pandion betrid by Periander, and he beet with their enemies, they unanimouly aaulted them, all agreeing in the means of their preervation, their enemies detruction,
though all diagreeing in the end, ome fighting to preerve their own honour, didaining to be enlaved by uch unworthy Villains; others for their Ladies; ome out of Love to the Commonwealth, to quit it from uch a net of Petilent Fellows; others out of hatred to their enemies; o that in fine there grew a deperate combat, as it mut needs—the Combatants growing deperate, the Clauian Knights reolving rather to loe their lives by whole-ale on the point of the Sword, than retail them out by the hand of Jutice, which they knew would befall them hould they urrender, grew fearles through fear, o that Courage in the Valiant grew deperate, and depair made the Coward couragious; that at length the conflict grew o cruel, that the very ground was overflown with a deluge of bloud, and the earth that was wont to bury mens bodies, mens bodies now buried the earth; o that it eemed like Mars's owing time, the eeds of cruelty being implanted in each Breat, and watered with Bloud; but like Deaths reaping time, uch an Harvet of Bodies there lay in heaps, erving as Bridges to tranport over Rivers of Bloud, that treamed in the pavement
Hard it was to determine which way the ballance of victory would poize, Fortune for a while carrying her elf a Neuter; till at length Periander being a too partial Umpire, by the mediation of his valour decided the controvery, ending uch throngs of Souls of the Clauian Knights, that were loth to anwer for their unanwerable crimes before Melampus his Tribunal, to receive their eternal doom, that the mall remainder yielded, craving mercy, which they found. Then Periander receiving the Keys of the Gate, gave the Captives that were the Keepers, to the Keepers that were the Captives, till Pandion whoe right it
was to command, hould otherwie order; who appointed Sentinels on the wall, and a watch for that night, intending the next morning to march in triumph to King Melampus's Court.
But no ooner had each man took his Station, but their Ears were arreted with the crys of a Female voice, which as well as they could undertand, demanded entrance; the Gates being opened, they all traight knew her to be Roxana their Kings Daughter, who eeing the event of the Combat, came with peed to the Catle to perform her lat obequies to Theon, and to return thanks to Pandion and Periander for their hazardous adventure. And being admitted into the Catle, he was received with all repect and joy, by all the Knights and Ladies there, but epecially by Pandion, who blet her ears with the happy tidings that Theon was yet alive, pointing where his Chamber was, who would have aid more, but the tranporting joy, not only divorced all orrow from her Heart, but her Body from the place; o that both his words and thoughts were prevented with her udden • light, calling as he went, Theon, Theon, her Tongue not being able any more to expres her unexpreible paion; but as oon as the eyes of Theon, nay his Heart, nay his Soul was ravihed with the ight of Roxana, as if her beauty had been ome divine quinteential extract, or ome ray of that celetial fire, that inpired life into Prometheus Image, he felt a vigour infued into all his fainting limbs, and the Darts of Beauty to triumph over the Darts of Death, and her words to blow up the dying parks of Life into a flame, o that aembling all his powers together, he cat himelf into her Arms, his Legs being unfaithful and feeble upporters of his Body. But, alas! as their arms were linked each in other, and their very
Souls intwin'd by a weet ympathy, Theons Spirits that, like the dying blaze of a Taper, before gave uch a udden flah, choaked with the moke of that affection that gave them life, uddenly fled from their battred dwel • ing.
Roxana amazed to ee this ad unexpected adventure, remained like one uddenly thrown from a high precipice, who hath his breath topt ere he know whence he fell, or whither he is falling, o was he rackt between the extrems of joy and grief; all the powers of her Soul being overwhelmed with a udden confuion. Two extrems over-flowing Tides of contrary paions meeting together in one Breat mut needs ink it in a Whirl-pool of amazement. But he was recovered from that living trance, by the recovery of Theon, who did but by the hortnes as it were counterfeit a Death, that he might be buried in that Lilly vale, beet with welling Mounts of driven Snow.
What wanton reaks, aid Rozana, doth Fortune play, bandying me from one extreme to another? no wonder that Vertue and Fortune rarely meet in one, ince that moves always in a mediocrity, and this drunk with madnes, reels to extremes. But her Farther peech was interrupted by the coming of Periander, followed by a Gentleman that came from her Father, who having firt performed his duty to her, and acquainted her of her Parents health, told her, how that the ame of the Catles winning, and of her being found had been blazed in her Fathers e • rs, who knowing, that the Eccho's that re • ound in her Temple, are uually reduplicated, and that her Tranlations and Comments eldome agree with the Original truth, therefore had ent him to make a more trict inquiition, that he might have certain intelligence, intending,
if it was truth, to end ome of his chief Noble • to honour that Hero that was their deliverer, not only according to, but beyond his ingagement. And that he ent ome of his principal Doctors and Chirurgeons to cure the wounded.
She returned him many thanks for his pains, and for his acceptable news, and requeted him to end for a Chirurgeon to Theon, whoe wounds like gaping mouths eemed to beg for help. But the Chirurgeon being called, by means of a overaign Balm that he had then with him, he preently topt thoe bloudy leaks, and in a hort time retored him to a great meaure of health, a • d no les did the other Chirurgeons effect upon Pandion, and the ret of the wounded; o that after the burials of the dead, Pandion attending upon Roxana, and attended with all the Ladies, and mot of the Knights, excepting ome few that he left in the Catle to keep it in the Kings behalf, marched towards Melampus's Court; but they were met by a glitring train of Nobles, Knights, and Gentlemen, ome coming in obedience to the Kings Commands, others to meet their delivered Ladies, and all to bring Roxana and Pandion to the Court with great olemnity; having performed their dutiful alutation to the firt, they in the Kings name returned many thanks to the latter for his great ervice to the Kingdom, acquainting him with what high acceptance his heroick Act was received by the King, and betowing large Encomiums on his valour; who yet willing that Periander, that was o great a partner in the victory, might alo hare in the honour, endeavoured to tranfer the chief praie of the Action upon him, extenuating his own part, but extolling his, to whom alo they performed many Ceremonies; All which being pat, they proceeded in their joyrny, beguiling the time
with delightful pleaancy, till the end of their journy put an end to their dicoure, where they were brought to the Palace of the King, being conducted into pacious Courts, adorned with uch beauty, riches, and pompous magnificence, as tranported Pandion (who never beheld uch State) with an exces of atonihment, that he thought Heaven and Earth could not have afforded o much glory. Such was the glitring habit of the Nobles, as eemed to contend with the golden Pillars which hould reflect the Suns rays with the greatet lutre, or rather with the Sun himelf for brightnes; uch the rich Attire, replendent Ornaments, and admirable Beauty of the Ladies, their Ornaments adorning their Beauty, and their Beauty beautifying their Ornaments, and both adding uch particular graces to the olemnity, that held the Eyes and Heart of Pandion and Periander dazled between contentment and admiration.
Being convened into the Kings preence, he aroe from his throne, and after he had embraced his Daughter with joy and affection, turned to Pandion and aluted him with as great Condecention as Majety would permit, telling him that he eteemed himelf beholding to Fortune, not o much for ending one who by his valour had rid his State from uch a brood of Villains, as honouring his Court, by that occaion with the preence of a Peron of o great worth as he approved himelf to be; and requeted him to acquaint him with his name, and what he was, that he might know on whom, as well as for what he hould confer his intended Honour.
Pandion (who had reolved to conceal his name, knowing that to reveal it would be utterly detructive to his deign, and therefore agreed with Periander to go under the name of Danpion, which is the ame with
his own, the Letters being tranpoed in a different order) made this reply.
Great Sir, aid he, the Honour you have already done me is ufficient to reward the worth of one that had the whole worlds excellency contracted together and united in him, much more the mean deerts of o mean a peron as my elf, whoe meannes is uch, that it may be ufficient excue if I am ilent, accounting my elf unworthy to trouble the Ears and Thoughts of o great a Prince with any farther relation and knowledge of me than my name, which is Danpion. Melampus perceiving his reervednes, conceiving he had ufficient reaons, forbare any further importunities. And taking Danpion on his right hand, and Periander on his left, acco • panied with multitudes of Knights and Ladies, he led them into the walks, where the lofty Trees were ranked in uch delightful order, as that none durt retreat, and all eemed equally ambitious of being foremot, their plumy tops, waving with gentle puffs, and the dancing air. On the one ide were goodly Gardens, where the mooth Lillies were incloed with fragrant hedges, underneath whoe weet protection dwelt air-perfuming Roes, whoe Vermillion looks eemed to bluh at their own perfections, and wrapped in lovely folds, as if the Angels themelves had taken delight each morn, to contend one with another, which hould dres them with the mot pleaant intricacies, each bed clad with uch lovely ra • ified flowers, as if Flora her elf had there been brought to bed of her mot delightful of-prings, and all the borders o trewed with the prings inamel'd Tapetry, as if they had bordered upon the Empyreal Paradie, o that the whole eemed as if it had been Natures Treaury, wherein he kept her richet beauties. On the other ide tood a tately Summer-houe,
Melampus ye King with Danpion and Periander • page 68.
mounted on twice twelve Marble Pillars, beleagured round with a little murmuring River, whoe curling treams like liquid Silver reels to and fro in wanton mazes, part whereof endeavoured with its tranparent garment to hide Diana from Acteons ambitious eyes, her naked Nymphs tanding round, ome in the Crytal water, ome on the Lilly-paved brink, trampling on thoe humble Flowers for comparing with them for whitenes.
Much time they pent in pleaant dicoure, and viewing thee delights, and many more than my pen can decribe, till at length the Sun began to diplay his golden locks to the inhabitants of the other Hemiphere, and the carlet evening to fly over Heavens arched Roofs; when Supper being prepared, the King commanded to have it erved into the Banquetting houe, where they at down, more curious to atisfy the appeti • e of their eyes, than deirous to feed upon the various Cates that there were marhalled in tately order; The Ladies darting amorous looks upon the two trange Knights, no les admiring them for their beauty and comely deportment, than for their valour, and Pandion epecially, who though he had not uch a Majetick, manly, and evere look as Periander, yet of a more pleaant countenance, and attractive grace, his tarry eyes hining with a radiant plendor, like two Quivers filled with Darts of Love, re • lected back their wanton glances with no les delight and admiration, and rowled to and fro in that Garden of Beauties, as if he, Zeuxis like, pickt out here and there a heavenly feature, to compoe a Poie and mixture of all excellencies and perfections.
But all this joy and contentmenr did but beget orrow and dicontent in Periander, by bringing to mind depairing thoughts of Florinda, from whom one
mile were better to him than all thoe eye-pleaing delights, one accent from her lips, than all the ravihing warblings of thoe Angelical voyces, that there ang to Lutes and Viols, and other charming Intruments: o that his dejected eyes eldome afforded any there a look, as though they corned to look on any, ince Fortune forbad them to look on her whom they preferred before all: but the internal eyes of his Soul continually gazed upon the picture of Florinda, that was lively painted in his Fancy by the Pencil of affection. But Supper being ended, after ome Masks and Revels, and other pleaures, the night being far pent, they all retired to their Lodgings.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOK OF PANDION AND AMPHIGENIA.
div.p:
SWift-footed Time feathered with flying houres, of it elf pots away with uch celerity, that we are no ooner entred upon the Stage to act our parts on the Theatre of this world, but ere we are aware the Scene is concluded, and Death pronounces an Exit; yet the mirth and jollity of thoe happy days eemed to add wings unto it; while unhappy Periander, and the more unhappy, becaue o in the mids of o much happines, would not permit the leat joy to intrude into his heart, but abandoned his thoughts wholly to mournful meditations which though in themelves unpleaing, yet weet to him, becaue hovering in Loves Dominions, till
lighted on o weet a Centre as Florinda. Oft would he walk alone, and recount to him • lf his various mifortunes, and then account them all as Cyphers compar'd with his exilement from Florinda: but then joyning both together, with a multiplying addition, how far (would he ay) doth it urmount my Souls Arithmetick, to number my innumerable griefs! Had ever any one uch mountains of orrows heaped upon him, and not overwhelmed? Cetainly, they are not et for teps to climbe to a Heaven of happines, rather a •
Tombes, where all my hopes, deires and joys may be interred.

Thus as the Torpedo, when it feels it elf innared by the deceitful hook, vomits • orth a bane-full humor into the briny Ocean, and not onely fills the places neer adjoyning to her with a Chilling Ice, but ends it up to the Anglers hand, wherewith in a moment it
<> and Charms his enes into a death-reembling leep: o Perianders orrow intangled with Loves Bait, not only fill'd his heart with the fumes of dicontent, but infected all thoe Joys that eemed to Angle for it, with their delicious Baits; And one morning, by that time Aurora had pread her Vermilion Mantle, on Heavens Azure floor, and the Suns glitering Beams had gilded the mountain tops, Periander leapt out of his Bed, a • d went into the Walks, where the hadines of the Trees, the coolnes of the Air, which was fann'd to and fro with Zephyrus wings, and the weet agreeable murmuring of the Fountaines, fomented in his Breat that humor which fed it elf with the remembrance of Florinda.

What trange unruly paions are thee (aid he) that thus tand Centinel at the doors of my enes, and deny Ret entrance, and if any Joys are uters for the poeion of my heart, they oon forbid the Banes, and
thus domineering within the Kingdom of my troubled Breat, chae all contentment from me, o that methinks I could conume an Age in thinking, and make my Griefs keep Time with the Spheres harmonious motions, till time hall be no more; for as they do rie, but never et (for when they eem to et to us, they then rie to our Antipodes) o have my orrows a beginning, but never ending, keeping a perpetual motion in my Breat; and when the morning begins, then doth my Heart greet the approaching light, with a hope-abco •
ding Cloud of ighs, exhaled by the heat of Loves Paions, from the Ocean of Grief within my mind; and when the Evening begins to cloe the Day, then doth my Heart conclude it with howers of dewy Tears, and all proceeds from the remembrance of Florinda.

Ah weet remembrance (aid he) happy were I, wouldt thou make me forget all other happines, or mother the thoughts of my preent miery. But more weet Florinda, ince all abtracted weetnes is lodged in thee, how could I part with Thee, and not part with Life? or rather how could I part with Life, in parting with Thee, and yet live? What was I eneles, that I could hear the fatal Meenger pronounce that more fatal entence, and the very Cadence of his peech not tab me to the heart? Sure the very ound would have truck me dead, but alas, miery had o filled my Heart, that there was no room for death. Oh envious Fortune, couldt thou find no other time to blat my happines, but in the blooming of it? In what poyonous compoition didt thou dip thy invenomed haft, that feathered both with Life and Death, hot Death to my happines, but Life to my miery? Come once more, bend thy Bow, and ince thou dot delight in my detruction, draw thy Dart up to the head, and here's a Bret prepared for thee.

As he was further proceeding in his peech, he was interrupted with a doleful noie, which being handed to his ears by Eccho's reverberations, eemed as if he had a freh begun, with pining lamentations, to bewail her more pining Narcius; but er'e he could conider what it was, or whence it came, his ears were arreted with a train of mournful tones, that followed their flying predeceor, and then a peircing drilling cry would eem to be a treble to a murmuring Groan; but drawing neer, hoping to find one to ympathize with him in his miery, he heard the voice formed into thee words.

Oh heavens, were it not enough to take her hence, but you mut take all mercy with her; alas, what need is there for mercy, where there is no miery? there is nothing but a boundles Sea of Happines, and here nothing but a bottomles abye of Wo. Oh command Death to unlock the doors of happines, that I may enter in and exchange thee Heart-infringing Groans, for the Heaven-bred Raptures of that Seraphick Quire that urround the Heavenly Throne, and thee Soul-melting Tears, for thoe Nectarian tream • of immortal pleaures. Come, Death, thou that art o prodigal of thy Darts, to hoot a Virgin in the Aurora of her days, whoe freh miles would have melted the mot flinty heart into mercy, come pare a haft to me, whoe age awell as mieries inviteth. Oh! why art thou grown thus prepoterous to take the young, and leave the old? would not her Beauty move pity in thy heart? Methinks her bluhing Cheeks might have made thee ahamed of thy cruelty. How couldt thou find in thy heart to thrut thy Sithe into her tender ides? Sure, no uch thing as Love could be the caue, no, Love never reides in an obdurate Heart. And ah, the Grave is too hard a marriage Bed, and thy looks too gatly for her
to delight in thy cold embracements. Come then to me, to whom thou halt be wellcome, puff out this blaze of Life, and let my fledgd Soul take her Wing. Thinket thou that a few Tears can upply with moyture, what o many griefs and years have dryed up? No urely, long it cannot be, ere my ublime Soul mut bid farewell to all thee tranitory Griefs and Joys.

Having poken this, he concluded with uch a groan, as if he had ended his peech and Life together. But Periander, no longer able to conceal himelf from, nor from himelf him that was the author of thee ad lamentations, which he thought could uit with none as with him, accounting (as it is the property of all men) his own condition mot lamentable, dicovered to himelf, and himelf to an ancient man apparelled in a Gown of gray, reembling a Pilgrims weed, lying along in a darkom Cave, the darkomnes whereof made it reemble a Vaul • or Grave, as his palenes made him reemble a Ghot, o that he lay as if he had been entombed alive.

Periander at firt tood till, having his thoughts ditracted between pity and amazement, and gazed upon him, but then returning to himelf, he requeted the Pilgrim (for o he eemed to be) to inform him of the caue of his mournful complaints, telling him, that he had a ufficient hare of orrow, and therefore knew how to bear a part in that doleful Conort, and that he had found by experience, that when he had a partner in grief, it eaed him of half his miery, two being able to upport that burthen, that one will ink under. And that if it lay in his power, no way ele to avail him, yet he could ympathize with him. True (anwered the Pilgrim) but you your elf ay you have a ufficient hare already, and therefore I need make no addition: and alas the tory of my fortunes would make an Adamantine
heart relent, and move pity in a Soul that had for ever exiled all mercy from it. The relation (anwered Periander) may add to my griefs, not to my miery, and detract from them, as much as their relating may give eae to you, which will be ome though mall, becaue one grief concealed, more grievous is, than ten imparted. Since you are thus deirous (replyed the Pilgrim) of a thing o undeirable, I hall conent.

Know then that my name is Geryon, by birth a Nobleman of this Realm, I had a Daughter (and then the tears tood in his eyes, as doubtful whether they hould leave their Aged Manions, or continue there) her name was Helena, her Parts and Beauty made her both deireable and deired, by many principal Noblemen in the Court. Many uters he had; among the ret, there came a young Gentleman, named Pentheus, a man (as I mut needs ay) of incomparable worth; though as I then thought, too undeerving for my Daughter, but now I both ee and rue my pride (and then the tears guhed forth, but proceeding) the wealth and honor of the ret o ecliped his merits, and dazled the eyes of my judgement, that I thought him fitter for her menial ervant, than a ervant in affection. But I diliked him not o much as my Daughter liked him, or rather I diliked him the more, becaue he liked him, not out of want, but exces of over-vehement affection to her. But my hate to him, could not quench her love to him, but rather encreaed it, which for a while was interrupted upon this occaion. Often had I forbad him coming to my houe, threatning little les than Death, charging my Daughter alo upon penalty of my utter dipleaure, not to entertain him in her Arms, or in her heart; but as the latter was impoible for her to effect, o the former was attended
with little les difficulty, being as unwilling to do the one, as unable to do the other; o that they continu
• d till their tollen meetings, which was not o private, but it came to my ear, o that perceiving, they little minded my threatnings, I minded little to threaten, but laid an Ambuhment to entrap them one Evening, who paing along as they were toying and dicouring and uing their wonted Dalliances, my ervants tarted up and apprehended them; her they brought home, and him they carried into a Wood, that was ome miles ditant from thence, with intentions to kill him, but they were et upon by the Knights of Clauus Catle, and ome killed, others wounded, and many carried prioners to the Catle, among which he was one. Thoe few that remained and ecaped, fled in hat to acquaint me with the event of the action, which did then exceedingly delight and content me, uch was my wicked folly, that I never conidered what would be the event of uch a wicked event; the eyes of my affection and judgement being blinded with the dazling of that happines I flattered my elf withall, which I thought nothing then could impede, when uch an obtacle and impediment was removed away; but ah, there was a greater obtruction, my wickednes, that I minded not to remove, which is that that now more afflicts me, than all the miery and misfortune that is inflicted upon me; uch is the adverity that attends wicked properity, and ucceeds properous uccees in wickednees, they do but harden the actor in his enormous coures, and by that means fit him for inevitable ruine, whilt he taken with the appearing weetnes of uch tranient happines, regards not to repres thoe exorbitances, which in the end depres him with miery.

Pentheus being gone, nothing now remained, but to match my Daughter to the mot deerving of her noble
• uters, amongt whom was one Trebonius, a young Nobleman, of great etate and power. As his affections were mot vehemently bent towards my Daughter, o were mine towards him, eteeming him in my overpartial judgement as far to excell Pentheus, in worth and excellency, as he did exceed him in riches, though that worth to my grief I found chiefly conited in worthles wealth and honor. To him was I determinately reolved to marry my Daughter, and to that end ued what arguments and perwaions I was able to prevail upon her affections; but as they were not in my power to command, o neither could he compell them to obey; which I perceiving, was forced to ue my paternal authority, by which at length, with many arguments and threatnings, I got her conent, not becaue he was pleaed in her choice, but becaue her choice was to pleae me, o that in fine marryed they were, to my great joy and contentment. But, alas, what contancy is there in humane etates? for when we are urrounded with the greatet properity, then many times are we alo invironed with the greatet diaters; good nor evil never abiding in one poture, o it was with me. Little did I preconceive what a part Fortune, or rather misfortune had to act in this Tragi-comedy. But whatever I conceived, that montruous birth, that Fortune was then conceiving, made me a monter of miery, which was Midwived by this occaion.

Of late two trange Knights by their valour, killed the Captain Clauus, took the Catle, and redeemed the prioners, (all which I uppoe, you cannot be ignorant of, for its not only the dicoure, but the admiration both of Court and Kingdom) amongt which he was one, that was releaed from that Captivity, but,
ah! to be innared in a greater Captivity both of affection and miery. For no ooner was the Catle won, but with all peed poible, he ran, firt to inform the King, of the Catles urprizal, and then with greater hat, purred on by a depairing hope, to inform my Daughter, the Queen of his heart, of his own delivery. But the firt object that aluted his eyes, was to behold Helena in Trebonius arms.

Here a mot Rhetorical Orator might have a fair field to emblazon with Eloquence, the trange diverity of Paions, that abounded in their hearts at the firt encountering. He whoe mind before was ditracted between depair, and hope, was now wholly ditracted with depair. In his face, one might have read a combat between the Beams of Love and Beauty, and Cloud of grief and hatred, and all thee tunned with a maze of amazement; whilt he no les anwered his affection with reciprocal interchanges of Paion, at firt he bluhed, as ahamed of her unfaithfulnes, and then looked pale with fear, let I hould perceive her bluhing; but then he bluhed again, let her palenes hould be dicovered, o that there eemed a weet contention between the Roe and the Lily, which hould have the poeion of her face.

At length Pentheus, like one returned from a • rance, flung away with uch a frowning mourning didainful pale countenance, as if anger, grief, hatred, and death it elf, had all begun to prey upon him, and all trove which hould have the greatet hare. Which poor Helena eeing, no longer able to contain, gave a igh, as if that breath had been her lat, after which the tears guhed out, which trickled down her Cheeks, like Pearls diolved, jut as the bluhing Roe, watered with Heavenly dew, when the oft Air gently breaths upon it, thoe Crytall drops leave their perfumed
dwelling, and ditill upon the ground; o did her tears blown with weet gales of gentle ighs, leave the Crytalline manions of her eyes, and decend upon the floor; which he trove againt with o weet a violence, as added uch a grace to her orrow, that intead of retraining it he contrained us to imitate her tormy eyes, o that there were carce any preent, who were not drawn into ociety of their tears. But at length winging out of her Husbands arms, with a hateful look in a lovely countenance, counting him the only object of her hatred, and caue of all her miery, he run to her chamber, and there made this complaint to her elf, which I her Husband tealing after her, over-heard.

Hard-hearted Father (aid he, and well thou mait call me o) could a little etate bribe your affection o, as not to regard the mierable etate of your poor Daughter? True it is I derived my being from you, a bleing which I can never requite, but alas, the bleing of a being cannot countervail the miery of a mierable being, which I have alo derived from you: for better never come into this mierable world, than come into uch a world of miery, as I am now involved in, o that my Heart, Head, Eyes and Tongue are too barren of Sighs, Thoughts, Tears and Words, to expres my unexpreible grief; come all you fountains, fill my head with Springs of Tears, and all you Clouds diolve in houres, and come and inhabit my eyes, that o thee thirty Eyes which before quaffed in uch draughts of Love, may now be punihed for their weet intemperance, and atiated with over-flowing treams of briny tears, or rather that this inking oul of mine might be wallowed up in a deluge of urging griefs. Ah hateful Trebonius, from thee flows all my miery, oh that my eyes had been masked with
an eternal night, when firt they beheld thy loathed face, or that my marriage bed had been my grave, and intead of my Epithalamum, that they had warbled out my Epicaedium; then might my touring oul, whilt they were chanting forth their dolefull tones here below, have bore a part among the Angelical Hierarchy, and there unskreen thoe awful ecrets, which are only reerved for the eyes of purified ouls, where no woes dare crave for entrance, but all joys injoyed in their full perfection. Ah my dear Pentheus, little thinkt thou what a faithful lover thy poor Helena is to thee, and what a killing thought it is to me to think that my foolih, but neceitated levity, hould occaion thee to harbour any hard thoughts of me, the very thought is able to put me beyond all thinking. Oh my weet guardian Angel (if any uch be allotted to my protection, which ure if there were, all thee mieries would not befall me) I ay, if any uch I have, prepare thy wings, hate quickly, fly to my Pentheus, and tell him that he is more dear to Helena •
than ever, and that a forced marriage hath only changed her State, not her, and though another to her endles grief enjoyed her Body, yet none her Heart, which he hath kept intire for him, and that her chat untained oul, hath not embraced a thought or deire, that hath thought of or deired any other but him. But why do I fondly bemoan my elf to thee eneles walls, hate I will to him, without whom to Live, were wore than Death, and with whom to Dye, is better than Life. And therewithall he ran out of the chamber, and ran down tayres, but her peed was topt by an affrightful meenger, that lookt like one arien from the dead, to bring news from thoe dark Regions, and as one that regarded not, or indeed knew, neither what nor to whom he pake, in a mournful
tone, belched out by parcels the death of Pentheus.

Helena, whoe former griefs had carried her to uch an exceive raging, that they had tranported her beyond her elf, o that at firt he minded not what the meenger pake, but Trebonius and I who till followed her, he jealous of her, and I, what would be the iue, demanded of the man the manner of it; He like one newly awak'd from a terrible dream, who looks about to ee whether his pat thoughts were realities, or only the productions of his fancy, mutering up his ences, and collecting his thoughts, told us, that paing by, it was his fortune to come jut as Pentheus was peaking his lat words, ome of which, as well as his confued memory could retain, he aid were thee, Oh Helena, how willingly would I reign my life, might my remembrance but lye intombed in thy weet thoughts, where thy dayly meditations of me would be better than embalming pices; would Heaven grant me uch a favour, I hould then count the divorce between my oul and body, the weetet marriage to the greatet happines. How oon would I build my Funeral Pile of woes and mieries, and enkindle them with the flames of Love, and therein conume my elf to Ahes, might thoe Ahes be kept as a relique of one of Loves Martyrs, within the Urn of thy breat. Well may I call thy Heart, a glay Urine, eeing I have found it both brittle and tranparent. But ah! what woman is not o? he mut have degenerated from her Feminine nature, or have been ome third ex, had he been endued with a faithful contancy; for Woman he could not be, and Man he was not; Oh what a thing were Woman, hould her viage alter with her mind, and her external form hould receive contant figurations from that incontant mould!
he would be twenty everal women in a moment. Never was any Chamelion or Proteus more ubject to various mutabilities. But why do I blame the whole Sex for the unfaithfulnes of one, and why do I blame her for my own unworthines? ah it was not her incontancy to me, but my incontancy to any thing of worth, that made her hate me. I that was the reaon, I am not worthy of her; of her? no, not to live. Then once more I bid farewell to all my hopes, farewell all fale deluding pleaures, painted woes, ugred lyes, and farewell Helena, the um of all; thou hat already peirced my heart with a wound more deep though not o deadly as this; with that I ran in, but ere my trembling feet could convey me to him, his bloudy knife had made paage for his oul to fly from her claiy prion. My daughter who had by this time o far come to her enes, as enibly to undertand the equel of the tory; no ooner heard it, but overwhelmed with the raging agony of a furious paion, ran up tairs, whom till we carefully purued; but ah! my tongue falters, and my heart fails to peak the ret, and then the tears began to glide down his Cheeks in uch a liberal manner, that Periander could not forbear to incorporate his with them, but intreating him to proceed, he thus went on. Ah aid he, the ret is o tragical, that it cannot be heard or related without a fractured heart; for we could not follow her o fat as he followed death, neither did we overtake her, ere he had overtaken it; for eeing her elf purued, and no other way to bereave her elf of life, he leapt out of the window; which Trebonius eeing, as one already carried out of himelf with horror, depair, and amazement, knowing himelf to be the caue of all thee bloudy Tragedies, to appeae their Ghots, which otherwie he thought might continually attend
him with affrighting repreentations in this world, he would attend them in the other, and thereupon leapt after her; o that as if Fortune had tudied how to exercie her uttermot power in making me mierable in one moment, I was deprived of Son and Daughter, Joy and Comforts all at once, o that hopeles of ever uperviving uch extremity of mieries, I reolved to pend the re • idue of my few days in preparing for death, which my age now begins to ummon to. Scarce had he concluded his lamentable relation of a more lamentable tory, but a panting meenger came running with uch hate, as if his ambitious legs unenible of their burthen, had contended which hould be eteemed the wiftet, or attain the period of their journy the oonet. His meage was to require Geryon from the King with peed to hate to Court; who accordingly aroe, and accompanied with Periander, preently walked thither, where the firt pecies that did greet his eyes was the King and his Daughter Helena, with their hands intermixed, coming to meet him; no ooner had his eyes beheld her, but as if they had retained their viive power only for uch a ight, and now atiated with that, reolved for ever to exclude all other objects that might exclude it, determined never to ee more

His aged Heart rent with the violent extremities of over flowing exces of miery, and now a too prodigal acces of comfort, not able to contain his vital pirits, he in a moment, jut as he was going to alute and embrace her, malicious Death, as envying him o much happines, tript up his heels, and rob'd him of life and kis and all; which Helena eeing, hewing no les dutiful affection to him dead, than living, after many vain endeavours to recall his revolted pirits,
caued his funerals to be olemnized with as much tate, as his quality required and her ability could perform. Fortune who had hitherto filled the eyes and ears of all men, with nothing but dimal Tragedies, was now minded to play a wanton reak, and as ated with o much bloud, for its better digetion brought in this Comical adventure amongt them.

It happened that one evening as they newly concluded their Supper, a meenger came, and privately whipered in Helena's ear, telling her that an ancient Gentleman without deired the favour of ome convere with her. She granted it, bade the meenger to invite him in. He drawing neer, after humble obeyance made to the King, and the ret there preent, directed his peech to the Lady Helena in this ort.

Madam, aid he, it was my fortune to be preent at the death of unhappy Pentheus (but who can be unhappy, that ever was beloved by uch a Lady as your •• lf?) who bequeathed his lat gap into my mouth, which as well as I could undertand, breathed out thee words. Go tell dear Helena, aid he, (and dear may I well call her, ince he hath cot me my life) that here I dye, a mirror of Love and Faithfulnes, and a true pattern of a faithful Lover. And moreover commanded me to beg of you, that if any parks of love or mercy to him yet remained, and conjure you by the former tetimonys of affection, and the weet remembrance of your more weet embracings, you would for your own ake, if not for his (for otherwie his unquiet Ghot would never ret appeaed) entertain my Son as your ervant, whilt Trebonius remains alive, and after as your husband, that o the reemblance that he bears of him, may be a continual Memento to you. And now, Madam, aid he, I have performed the Will of the dead on my part, the reidue of obedience only remains on yours.
of which I cannot but promie my elf performance; for ure o much cruelty and unfaithfulnes as to deny, cannot be diguied under o weet a viard as Nature hath adorned your face withall. And then he topt, earnetly waiting Helena's anwer, who firt making many ighs and tears a prologue to her dicoure, made this Reply. Sir, aid he, I call heaven to witnes to my faithfulnes and contancy, whoe All-urveying Eye ees into the mot abtrue retirements of the Soul, and knoweth all its mot ecret productions, to whom I dare appear. Surely, had I been faithles to uch a one, had the whole worlds contracted powers, endeavoured to Barricado me againt heavens vengeance, all their united force had been but as paper bulwarks. My potles innocency is the only Brazen Wall, that can protect me from its Cannon hot, which I humbly importune heaven (and then he kneeled) that the very Clouds might dicharge againt this breat, if there be any other than truth and faithfulnes in me toward my Pentheus. Madam (anwered the other) uch imprecations are unneceary; he whoe ditrutful breat, dares lodge an unbelieving thought of what comes from o weet a mouth, may Caandra's cure in its full extent light on him, never to be believed by any, though he hould wear by all that • acred, no, not by himelf, that o when he himelf by an infernal intinct, hould prophecy his own ruine, his bae mitrut might not permit him to ue means for anticipation.

It is my confidence of your pereverence, that makes me perevere in confidence, to urge his dying requet, than the conceion of which, there can be no greater manifetation of your love and contancy; but the refual would not onely by actions contradict your words, but oppoe that which Fate and Nature eem to conjoyn their powers, and combine together
to accomplih; the former, by removing away your husband Trebonius, the only Remora, and the latter by betowing uch a reemblance of Pentheus on my Son, as I am perwaded, when you ee him, you will not eaily be convinced, that it is any other than he himelf. What an unfaithful faithfulnes were that (replyed he) that were to commit the highet fal • enes, veiled with a pretended fidelity. No (aid he) let Fate and Nature conpire how they will, all their combinations hall never make me love any other but Pentheus. And whatever imilitude your Son may have of him, it cannot be a greater reemblance, than his Idea indelebly engraven in my heart.

Then (aid he) ince you will have none but him, here he is, and with that he pulled off a vizard, and dicovered himelf to be Pentheus indeed. Helena, in whoe mind grief had o fixed the death of Pentheus, that hard it was by all Arguments for him to eradicate the belief of it thence, but he tood rather as if he had been affrighted with his Ghot, than delighted with his preence, but Pentheus continued till his perwaions, telling her the truth, how that when he went away from her, he was o tranported with the rage of a paionate madnes, that he reolved to kill himelf, and therefore fled into the next Wood, where meeting with ome men, he to hide his intentions, ran into a Cave, and when he thought that the Coat was cleer, and none to interrupt his bloudy deign, he ran a kni • e into his breats, but his good fate more careful of him, than he of himelf, fenced o well for him, as broke both his thrut, and his weapon, by glancing it on a rib; the wound made him give a grone, o that ome undicovered perons, that till remained in the Wood, came peedily in, and carrying him to the next houe, compelled him to be dreed, where having • ain ome
time, the trange news of her death and recovery came to his ears, and every circumtance of it, how he leapt out of the window, and her Husband Trebonius after her; how her fall brake his heart, but his, his neck, and how he had onely bruied her fair limbs, and the breath for a while expelled out of her body, but that loath o oon to be turned out of its weet Tenement, reolved till to continue, and bles the world with the injoyment of o much excellency. This news (he aid) was a greater Cordial and retorative to him, than all the Galenits and Paracelians in the world were able to compoe, and he that before was o deirous of death, was now as eager of life, and had rather he had a thouand lives to regain, that he might pend them all in the fruition of Helena's weet ociety; o that now willingly accepting, whatoever might retore him, he was in a hort time, by the diligence and care of the Chirurgeons, perfectly cured, and reolving to make a tryal of her contancy, and whether Fame had not been a lyar, he came in this diguie. This peech being confirmed by ome Gentlemen, Companions of Pentheus, convinced Helena. Then no longer able to withtand the Invaion of their minds, they mutually embraced each other, o that by agreement and conent of all, the Nuptials were the next day to be celebrated.

After the joyful Nuptials of Theon and Roxana, Pentheus and Helen •
were olemnized, with great joy and admiration, Periandor and Danpion took leave of the King, and the ret of the Court, to proceed in quet of their Fortune, and after many fruitles importunings from all there preent, but epecially the King, who eemed to be paionately deirous of their tay, telling them that as their worth was uch, that no place in the world but would be proud of uch Guets, o his etimation of them was uch (though hort of their merits)
that their preence hould be more acceptable to none than to him, Danpion replied, Great Sir (aid he) to be enthroned in your Royal thoughts, and etimation, is a reward that would trancend an Angels merits, much more my poor deerts, which if I have any thing mine, that can arrogate this title, it is but the reflection of yours. If I have any worth in me (anwered the King) it conits in this, that I delight to ee it in any, and to reward it, where I ee it, which your departure diinables me to do. Royal Sir (aid Danpion) the many glorious and happy days, we have already pent under the heaven of your Court, hath o involved us already in a Sea of obligations, that we deire no longer to live, then our obequiounes hould attend your commands, but to continue longer, were to plunge our elves yet deeper, and by that means enforce our elves, in depight of our greatet gratitude to dye ingrateful. King Melampus eeing his perwaions vain, with many ceremonies, dimit them.

Periander and Danpion having conumed many days, in a long and tedious journey into Thealia, and paing thorow many Cities therein, to inform themelves the better how the affairs of State were managed, as Trica, and Phthia, and Trachys, and Phyllus, and over the high mountains Oa, Oeta, and Pindus, where they met with many trange adventures, at length they came to Tempe, a place not undeervedly renowned for pleaure. It eemed as if the whole worlds delights had been there Epitomized, and contracted into a leer volume, but more excellent Character. There were delicious fragrant Gardens, enamelled with odorierous flowers, large and invious Woods, whoe • ady locks wept the Chambers of the Air, and eemed to dance to the harmonious retortings of the reverberating Ecchoe's; delightful Groves, within whoe embracing
boughs dwell the winged Muicians of the Air, chanting forth their Love Sonnets in Care-charming accents; walks of love betrewed with Roes and Lilies, bedewed with the weet drops pouted from Crytall Fountaines; freh purling rivulets, whoe delightful treams tuned their agreeing murmurs to the oft whipers of the wagging leaves, frizled by Zephyrus wanton wings, the preading boughs cating uch pleaing hades on the miling ground, like the hadowy trokes in a picture, made it more florid and delightome; the trembling leaves moved by the freh breathings of the healthful Air, dancing to the harmonious curlings of the Azure treams, with uch peaceful pleaure, as would have forced a Stoick to have indulged his mot obdurate mind to loves melting paions. And all this urrounded partly with lofty mountains, whoe high towring tops eemed to cale the Clouds, as ambitious both to behold and embrace thee rare delights, and partly with little hills of meaner acent, whereon there blew the mot pure refined guts of clarified Air. Many Palaces here were, for the nobles and Knights of Thealia, but in the centre of all tood the Kings, a mot magnificent tructure, the Walls of Porphiry, rough-cat with hining Carbuncles, and other precious tones, cat in devies, Scutcheons, and Emblems, incloed with a Quadrangle-platform of Japer, made level with battlements. At each corner, a umptuous convent, wherein was a tately Temple dedicated to Venus, Diana, and Pallas, ignifying the three chief feminine Excellencies, Chatity, Widom, and Beauty. Within, were Magazines of Arms, Wardrobes, rich edifices, for the Kings Attendants, beides many Groves of Cypres and Cedar, goodly Gardens and Fountains encompaed with Balliters of Copper, and fair Arches, upported with Brazen Pillars.

Danpion and Periander, that they might the better view thee glitering buildings, and the other ravihing delights, that the place did abound withall, went up a little hill, on whoe brow, they beheld in the bottom, a pleaant Vale, with a more pleaant Garden. In the midt of which there was a Bath, urrounded with a Wall of Jet, and over head to defend it from the Suns peircing rays, an Arched Roof, upported by Statues, tanding upon gilded Columnes, each Statue holding in her hand a ilver Rod, on which hung Curtaines of white Damask, fringed with green Silk and Gold; one of which being drawn, Pandion epied a mot lovely Lady, reting her oft Limbs in a Chair of Jet, made at the Bais of a Pillar, Combing her golden Trees, newly come out of the Bath, o that the Silver drops, as it were grown ponderous, with over-burdening grief, that there nature hould compell them to leave the poeion of o much perfection, fell in Tears from her Snow-white Limbs. Each part was enhrined in o much excellency, that Pandion felt his heart arreted with trange paions, o that he could not retrain his eyes from urveying her rapting features, and the more he gazed the more he deired to gaze, and the more admirable he eemed.

Her eyes like two Lucent Stars, hining with uch a tranporting influence, as Pandion grew an Atrologian, and his eyes Star-gazers, fixedly oberving the motions of thee two wandring Planets, whoe every Beam darted a living death. Her arched brows, where at a mild weet Majety, eemed like two bows of love, trung with his heart trings. Her eye-lids like Ivory covers to two Cabinets, filled with Diamonds, at their opening a thouand parkling Gemms would hine with a radiant fulgor, and at their cloing, as many would be ecliped. Each cheek eemed a Roie Paradie, intermixed
with Lilies.
