Her lips like hreds of Vermilion Sattin, incloed two poliht rows of Ivory teeth, from whence uch weet peruming fumes teamed forth, as the very Air, when he drew her breath, eemed to pres with delight into her delicate mouth. Her noe, chin and neck were of o pure a whitenes, as the Lilies lookt pale with grief to ee themelves o far excelled. Her breats were like two Ivory Caskes of Nectar, from whence leads a milky way to Cupids Palace. Her lovely hair, which the wanton wind portively toed to and fro, one while from her, that it might the more freely kis her Snowy skin, then twit it in intricate Curles, and then divide it, now take a Tres, and fan her face, and then a golden thread, and dally with her eye, o that it eemed to weave a Net to entangle Pandions heart, whiles her Lily hand endeavoured to repres thoe lacivious exorbitancies with a ilver Combe, o that Pandion was in doubt, which was the more happy, her hair to be methodized by o weet a hand, or her hand to handle uch excellent hair, o weet both by Art and Nature, as would make one wih for Mars his fortune, to be ennared in a Vulcans Net, were it made of uch Heavenly Wire. Her leggs like two Columnes of Alabater, or Atlaes, which upported this little world of Excellency. Pandion whoe ight was reited by nothing, but his avaritious eyes had full freedom to fill their Pearly Coffers with thoe weet treaures, had the flames of affection o augmented with admiration and delight, that loath to trut the brittle treaury of his eyes, he locked them in his heart. And having his Wit refined by love, and he inpired with a Poetick fury, he to himelf, let Periander hould hear, in mournful Aires, warbled forth this Song.

q.l: What trange untrained pasions do controle,
And domineer within my troubled Soul?
What means this crowd of thoughts within my breat?
Hath ome trange antick fury dipoet
Me of my Reaon? Oh, 'tis Love I ee,
That of my mind uurps the Soveraignty;
And hath depos'd my Will. Oh traitrous Eyes!
You are the inlets of my mieries;
You are th'incendiaries of this Civil War,
Within my breat, anwer to Reaons Bar,
My heart's two Crytall Forts, how durt y' uncloe
Your Ivory doors, to admit uch throngs of Woes?
Ah tis her Conquering Beauty, that's the Key,
That hath unlockt my Heart, unveil'd my Eye,
That th' one cannot but look, the other love,
And both admire, what Deity above,
Mindles of us, poor lovers here, doth give,
To rapting Beauty uch prerogative.
A skin where Roe and Lily do intwine
Themelves in lovely mixtures, and combine
To make a box, where weets compacted lye;
Perfections quinteence is heav'n's Alchimy,
Divine Elixar, that turns all to Gold,
Her hands do touch, or her fair Eys behold,
This heav'nly extract, tampt with weet, divine,
And heart-attracting features is a Coyn
Might pas among the Gods; what is't they prize,
But he excells? the lutre of her eyes
Exceeds the Stars; hould he her fair hand lay,
On water, treight 'twould turn Ambroia.
Not all the Goddees can pin o rare,
So fine, o oft a thred as is her hair.
Oh, how my heart's intangled in each Curl!
Whilt my eyes envy the rude wind hould hurl
Such golden treaure, and have free acces
To her, for whom I pine without redres.
In fine each part is fine, rare and divine,
A mine of worth, oh would her worth were mine.
Well then my Eyes, ince thus you'd bribed be,
My heart too render to my enemy;
And uffer Cupid in a golden howre
Of beauty, to decend into the Tower,
And ravih there my Heart without controle,
This is your mulct, to quench my burning Soul,
You are amerc'd by Loves all-conquering power,
Tributes of tears to pay, each day and hour.

div.p: But having concluded, he look'd about to ee if Periander perceived his Paions, but as he turned his head aide, he aw a Gentleman on horsback, a pretty ditance off, beckning with his hand to come to him. They rid up to him, and as they approached neer, he met them with this alutation, Sir (aid he) pardon my abrupt interruption of your pleaing meditations, and impute this eeming rudenes, not to my incivility, but my care and repect, for I perceive you are trangers in Thealia, and as unacquainted with the place, o with the Laws and Cutoms. Acteons punihment is allotted to Acteons Crime, whooever is een to gaze into that Bath, though they cannot transform his hape, yet he hall peedily be apprehended by a kennel of bloud-hounds, that lye in wait to devour all paengers, that dare once glance their eye, to pry into thee forbidden ecrets.

They gave him humble thanks for his care, and requeted him, further to inform them of that Cutom, let their ignorance hereafter might expoe them to any danger, which now his civility had freed them from Sirs (aid he) that I may make ome atisfaction,
for that Error, which in part I mut acknowledge I am guilty of, be pleaed to accept of entertainment at my houe, which that I may ingage you not to refue, I hall defer any further relation, till we are there.

Periander and Danpion received his courteous invitation with all gratefulnes, and rode along with them, untill they came on the top of the hill, whence they beheld in a great Plain beet with many rankes of Trees, a fair houe, bordering on a River, whither with peed they rode. The houe was built of fair Free-tone, both trong and delightfully eated, that hewed a kind of thrity prodigality, and that they had conideration both to profit and pleaure; where having entred in a while, and refrehed themelves, the Gentleman began this Relation.

This Country of Thealia, as it hath been ever famous for pleaure and delight, being counted the Flower of the World, a Paradie upon Eearth, and a place where the Golden Age, that had foraken all other places, hath neted it elf; but alo for a well-tempered Government, being a kind of Monarchical Aritocracy, which neither derogates from the Royal power and prerogative, nor yet detracts from the peoples jut rights, liberties, and proprieties; Till of late Agis our deceaed King, by his many tyrannical Impoitions, and illegal Uurpations, rendred both himelf and the Covernment odious and contemptible, o that in fine he was deprived of Crown and Kingdom by Hiarbas King of Caonia, who now reigns, and as he ucceeded him in Regal power, o in Tyrannical Invaions upon the peoples Liberties, Ruling by the Sword of Conquet, not the Sword of Jutice, o that of late, mot of the Nobility, and great numbers of the Commonalty have adhered to young Pandio • s
Interet, Son to Agis, who is now up in Arms, and hath eied upon mot of the principal Cities, Forts, and Garrions, in the Kingdom, and grown o trong, that Hiarbas perceiving it was not in his power to quell uch a mighty force, without great hazard of his Life and Kingdom, and loath to refer the deciion of o great a controverie, to uch an uncontant unfaithful Umpire, as the Fortune of War, to accord all differences hath proffered his only Daughter Amphigenia to be joyned in marriage with Pandion, and no les than the whole Kingdom of Caonia as her Dowry for the preent, and to ucceed him in the Kingdom of Thealia, after his Death.

Thee great propoals one would think would be a Soveraign remedy to heal all differentes, the Lady Amphigenia being in all repects o incomparably excellent, that none but would eteem themelves gainers, to exchange a Kingdom for the poeion of her; Her eyes containing more precious Gems, than ever yet adorned a Princes Diadem; her fingers Scepters for the God of Love, uch as all Kingly Scepters mut do homage to. If your eyes ever were blet with the ight of her, I am ure you would ay, that none but would refue a Crown, to be Crowned with her Love, much les would any reject uch a Paragon, laden not only with all Heavenly perfections, but with Earthly Crowns and Scepters, having one Kingdom in preent poeion, and another in reverion, and all to purchae Pandions conent to his own happines, which notwithtanding he more blind than the Fortune that doth attend him ees not, but proceeds in his warlike preparations, and reolves to have all or none, whether it be evil Counellours that inconiderately timulate him to thee rah proceedings, or what the reaon is, ome conjecture, few know, and
mot admire. But however thee two things are known to be the main obtructers of our peace, the one is, Pandion hath long been in love with a Nun, who by reaon of her indipenable vow, cannot conent to his deires, o that he is reolved not to purchae a Kingdom with the los of his Love, which he conceives he can obtain by force. The other is, the Lady Amphigenia hath uch a perfect Antipathy againt all men, (but her Father, which nature forbids, let it hould contradict it elf,) that he abho • s the ight of any, and will not endure to hear of marriage, though upon the mot advantagious and honourable terms, and with the mot excellent and abolutely compleat peron the whole world could afford. And her Father Hiarbas, taking exceeding joy and delight in her, accounting her the only prop and taff of his age, hath granted her this requet, that as he hath vowed, that if ever he become an Amorit, and place her affections upon any peron, he will never joyn her elf in marriage without her Fathers conent, o neither hall he injoyn her marriage with any without hers. And moreover hath obtained this, that none hall o much as make ute to her, or once behold her, without their mutual conent; And who hould dare ignorantly or otherwie to cat an intruding look into that Bath and Garden whither he frequently reorts to port her elf with her Female companions, forfeit no les than their eyes for their aw • y preumption. And that was the reaon that I beckned to you to come away with peed, not daring ingage my elf to run o great a hazard as to go to inform you of your errour, which otherwie civility would have obliged me to, let we hould all be ennated, and then my punihment had been equal, if not exceeding yours. <…> five of Pandions Knights were riding over that hill, and being
exceedingly taken with the gallantry of the place, tood awhile to gaze, ignorant what would be the event, and it happened that at the ame time King Hiarbas, and his Daughter Amphigenia were walking together in the Garden, and no ooner epied them, but ent everal Knights after them, who overtook and apprehended them, and brought them to the King, to whom they acknowledged who they were, and humbly craved of him, that ince their chief crime was ignorance, and their ight as precious as their lives, they might dye like men, by the valiant hands of ome of his hardy Knights, who durt encounter them. Some of Hiarbas Knights being preent, provoked with o bold a challenge, begged of the King to permit the combat, who after much peruaions granted it; but becaue Pandions Knights were then unprovided of all accoutrements fit for the duels, and Hiarbas Knights corning to take any dihonourable advantage, the day was appointed, which will be about three days hence, the place in an open plain, equally ditant from Hiarbas palace, and Pandions Catle.

Danpion hearing this tory was truck with uch a maze of ditracting thoughts, that all the whole trength of reaon could hardly curb, depairing of ever obtaining his Kingdom, or her whom he prized above it, and amazed to hear that another had uurped his name and power, all which he endeavoured to conceal, as well as his unbridled paions would permit. But both he and Periander, betraying by their looks the thoughts of their mind, that they were deirous of ome private conference, the Gentleman withdrew and left them to their deired privacy, when after ome dicoures that paed betwixt them, they concluded that the only way to accomplih their ends, was for the one to ininuate himelf into the Kings favour, the other into
the Impotors, that o they might be informed and inform each other of the mot private determinations of them both, and by that means foment new diviions in either party, and interrupt any reconcilement betwixt them, and o in time detroy them both; and then Danpion engaged, that if ever he attained to the Crown, he would raie what forces he was able, and invade Corinth for the regaining of Florinda. And (aid Danpion) the fates themelves could not have devied a more fit and happy opportunity than this that now preents it elf, for when the combat is, we will tand at uch a ditance, where uneen of any, we may behold which party hath the advantage, and are mot probable to prove victorious, and which declineth, and aid he, if Hiarbas Knights are much worted then will I come in and defend them, and if I chance to prove a victor, do you then immediately come and make a challenge to me, which I'le accept, and after a few skirmihes betwixt us, you may kill my Hore, and with ome other accidents, that our wits refined in the heat of courage, will be then pregnant to invent, you may diarm me and give me my Life. And the ame part hall you act if Pandions Knights are overcome, by which means we may both be accepted of, the one by Hiarbas, the other by Pandion. Periander much approved of his witty politick advie, and willingly embraced what Danpion had propounded.

The day being come, whereon Mars was to be the bloudy arbitrator between the two dicording parties, Danpion and Periander having fitly armed themelves for their intended enterprize, rode to the place appointed, where they found the Tents were pitched, and two Scaffolds erected on either ide the lits, covered with crimon velvet, and Chairs of cloth of Gold
within, the one for Hiarbas, the other for Pandion, each holding a golden Rod in his hand, and attended according to agreement, with two hundred armed Knights.

Then came Lord Petronius, clothed in a robe of Gold, that by conent of both was choen Lord High Contable for that day, and entred the Lits, before whom came ixty Gentlemen and Squires, bearing two Royal words before him, the one • eathed, as Lieutenant to Hiarbas, ignifying that the power of his word was inveted with overaign authority; and the other naked, as Pandions Lieutenant, betokening that as he was unjutly tripped from his power by the word, o he would defend his jut right, naked, from any fale deluding gloes, with the word.

After them followed two Heralds clothed with the Apparel of their Office, and carrying two Coates of Arms, the one belonging to Hiarbas, being his Coat, quartered with the Arms of the two Kingdoms of Thealy and Caonia, and the other Pandions Arms, quartered only with the Arms of Thealia. After them many young Pages, in Vermilion Sattin, richly embroidered with Gold.

The Lord Contable having urrounded the Camp, and viewed it every where, he caued the Kings Heralds to make this proclamation, in the name of King Hiarbas, that if Fortune hould incline to his advere party, and his Knights hould be conquered, he pronounced freedom for any hardy Knight (excepting thoe appointed to guard his peron) that out of loyalty to their King, and to defend his jut Authority, and to merit honor, would hazard his peron againt the Conquerors, to encounter them, at the holding of the Kings golden Rod, and if he overcame, he hould be rewarded, according to his high merits. The ame,
mutatis mutandis, was alo proclamed by Pandions Herald.

Then entred the Combatants into the Lits, where after the ounding of the Trumpets, and other warlike noies, that were the terrible preludes to a more terrible and ill-agreeing Muick, of breaking of Lances, clahing of Armour, neighing of hores, and reounding of blows that preently followed. The Hiarbian Knights, as corning that their valour hould be tryed by condemned Rebels, who were rather deperate than couragious, gave them o fierce a rancounter, as if they meant at once to wallow them up with an over-flowing tyde of valour. But this torrent of fury was oon topped by a more violent Cataract of rage from the Pandionians, who fought for their lives, but the other onely for their honors, o that the hivered Lances lew in pieces, ome one way, and ome another, as if they had led to avoid the madnes of their guiders. But the place was oon upplyed by the merciles words, wherewith they o minced each other, teeping their fleh in one anothers blood, as if each had been an infernal Cook ent from Hell, to dres a Breakfat for Pluto. So that terror it elf grew more terrible, by being dreed in a terrible garb. The glittering of words, the hining of gilded Armor, that at firt made terror it elf delightful, being now totally defiled and defaced with blood, dut, wounds, and fractured bones, incloed with mangled fleh, and that again defended with broken Armor.

In fine fortune had long been dubious and indifferent, whom to betow the victory on, till at length Zethus and Alcanor the two principal Hiarbian Knights, being too confident of their valour, that had rendred them triumphant, over o many victorious Champions, too frequently ingaged themelves, in the midt of
their enemies, and never retreated without ome notable markes of their Antagonits reolute fury, untill at lat their lives treamed out with their blood; which the other three perceiving, as if with them, they had lot their valour and all ene of honor, eeing themelves exceeded both in number and reolution, they retyred, endeavoring to ave their lives, though with the irreparable los of their honor. King Hiarbas oberving this, waved his golden rod, whereupon came everal Knights, ruhing into the Lits, contending which hould be foremot; but Danpion watching his opportunity came in oonet, o that by the determination of the Lord High Contable, he had the precedence, and the Combat was allotted him, with thee conditions, That he was to fight with them ucceively, and not at once, and that if he conquered he hould not be ingaged to incounter with any more than one freh Knight, that would undertake to defend Pandions interet. Then entering the Lits, apparell'd in sky-coloured Armour, where the firmament eemed to be over-cat with Clouds, excepting in ome few places, where the tenuity of the Air would not o forcibly reit his rays, and there the Sun was painted to peep through, and teal a view of the Earth, o to the life, that the reflection of the Sun Beams from that counterfeit Sun delineated in Pandions Armor, made the dazled beholders believe, they aw a Pare ••• s.

On the Cloud there was engraven this Imprea, Hope appears. In his hield he had a Cancer. His hore was of a coal black, but his furniture all of ilver Swans, whoe gli • tering made it look like Stars at midnight. The Trumpets being ounded, Scodius came forth, but in uch a bloudy poture, and o deformed with wounds, that Danpion could hardly ditinguih, whether he was
a man or a monter, but ere they had exchanged many blows, Danpion perceiving himelf much to overpower him, didaining to conquer a conquered man, referred the victory to his hore, who enraged with ome blows he received, fell into his Career, and over-turned both Scodius and his hore, and with his hinder food trake the wind out of his body; the Chirurgions having conveyed him away into his Tent.

The econd, which was Gentius, appeared in the Lits, but he having lot his right eye, Danpion had the better aim at his blind ide, o that having a dexterous and teady hand to direct his hore, and his hore as nimble to oberve the motions of his hand, he ere Gentius was aware, cut off his right hand; o that he lot both weapon, hand and all, and had alo lot his life, had he not begged it of Danpions hand.

The third that came was Maurius, who encountred Danpion, with another manner of violence than his predeceors, his confidence and reolution being chiefly augmented by the prophecy of a blind Atrologer, who ome few days before had told him, that he hould dye by an intemperate atisfying of an immoderate thirt, and therefore fearles of Danpions word, he boldly and fiercely charged him, confiding in that prediction: but his own rahnes oon unridled the meaning, for Danpion gave uch a wound overthwart his mouth, from whence uch an inundation of blood treamed down his throat, that having two mouthes, that luce-like exonerated themelves into that narrow gullet, oon atisfied his unatiable blood-thirtines, by putting him in a capacity never to thirt more.

Then came Hypenor, who aaulted Danpion with uch an impetuous torm of rage, as if he thought all valour had centred in him, which preerved by the impenetrable
uperficies of his Steely Armor, would protect him from the detructive influence of that travering Planet, whoe terrible (though beautiful) apect, had truck uch a kind of delightful terrifying amazement into the pectators, and amazing terror into his enemys; but he oon ound that Danpions word had made large Pores in his Armor, through which he had too frequent recoure to, and intimacy with his body; but the <> of blood did but augment the urging Sea of rage, o that elevated with a tranporting magnaminity,
<> gave uch a blow, as cleft Danpions hield, Armor, Breat, and all, and had reacht his heart, had not the uddennes of the troak made his hore tartle back. Danpion eeking to revenge his injury, conjuring all his pirits into his •• newy arm reolving to give a plenary requital, lets lye at him, with all his might and courage, but Hypenor awarding his blow, it light upon his hore, which tunned with the trength and fury of it, tumbled and fell upon his rider, o that whereas before, his hore bore him, he now bears his hore, which Danpion perceiving alighted, and in a Martial corn tamped with his victorious foot upon his bruied paunch with uch a madnes, that the blood iued out of Hypernors mouth, but compleating his victory, he buryed his dagger in his bowels.

The fift and lat was Machaon, but he approving himelf, rather a Forlorn than a Reerve, eeing o many puiant Champions conquered before him, and perceiving himelf to faint through want of blood, but more through want of valour, he came with unbended brows, and a flattering look to Danpion, extending his arm, intending to deliver up his Weapon. But Danpion thinking he had contemned his youth, more en • aged with thoe glozing looks, than he could be with the mot grim threatning and tern viage, the countenance
of a Hercules could have framed, gave Machaon o fierce a blow on his head, that down he fell, haking his heels, as if he purned at heaven, becaue it allowed him no more protection, or as if he trove to ride in the Air, ince his hore proved uch an unfaithful upporter.

Scarce had Pandion given the ignal, by haking his golden rod, but Periander appeared in the Lits, his hore was of a Chetnut colour, on his Baes and Caparion was embroidred two gilded Eagles, which preading their Wings, with every motion, made the hore eem as if he flew. On his Armour was painted a waving Sea, which cat uch a reflection, as the water doth, when the Sun in the Meridian views it. On his hield, for his Imprea, he had the Fih called Cantharus. The word was, Living contant, though living in uncontancy.

They no ooner aw each other, but they charged with uch a diembled fury, as if at the firt hock they meant no les than to end each other to the dark infernal Regions, when as they meant nothing les, for if they hit, they mied of their intents, but if they mied, they hit of their will. And yet with uch guileful Art, cating a mit of rage before the pectators eys, each aaulting, and retorting with uch tormy Cuffes, and counterbuffes, as when they mit, it was imputed to the Defenders skill, not the Offenders will. The Lances being broken, they drew out their words, and with a counterfeited gallant bravery, encountred each other, but Danpion feigning a faintnes, which his hore Caparioned with bloud, and his Armor of the ame dye, not a little confirmed, tumbled off his hore upon the ground, and with the fall, brake his word, which Periander perceiving, pretending to ue the favour of occaion, alighted, and would have redoubled his blows, but the
Lord Contable commanded the contrary, affirming, that it was neither according to the Law of Arms, and true Chivalry, much les to principles of Honor, to kill a diarmed man, and one that had diabled himelf with the Conquet of o many. Periander told them, that they fought not for their own honors, but for the interet of their Princes, and he was aured, private quirks mut ever veil to publike concernments, and therefore craved the Combate might be concluded. The Contable Replyed, that his will mut veil to his commands, and they had already put a period to it.

Periander in fine, with a eeming unperuablenes, was forced to conent. All being dimit, the two Champions Danpion and Periander, that had defended the differing quarrels with uch puiant bravery, were received with all honor and applaue, into the everal Campes, epecially Danpion, who had hewed incredible Gallantry in all the Combats, o far exceeding the expectations of any from uch a youth, that it was to admiration of all, o that there was none that did not bear a part in the Conort of his praies, ome commending him for his graceful deportment on his hore, how fat, teady and treight he ate, how he made him perform all his neceary motions, with uch time-ordered skill, as that his hand and the hore eemed to move both together, as if the hore and rider had both willed together, and the ame, or rather both had the ame will. Others for his dextrous management of his Lance, how the advancing it from his thigh, the couching it in his ret, and the letring it ink downwards, eemed o to be done, as if they could hardly dicern whether they were done at all, whilt their appearing not to be done, made the doing more delectable and graceful. Some extolled him for his force and
Cleodora and Periander pag: 1. 6. etc.
courage, others for his beauty, which as it rendered him more delightful, o his valour more admirable, that one that eemed more fit for the oft Camps of Venus, hould be a Scholar of o high a Clais, in the School of Mars.

In fine, their diagreeings in the matter of his praie, made the more agreeable Muick in the harmony of his applaue. Neither was the King a les admirer of him, but vehemently deired his abode with him, telling, that his great worth had made him ambitious of having uch a Phoenix to adorn his Court. Danpion replyed, that his Court already abounded with perons of uch incomparable worth, that he hould be no other ornament to it than as a pot in the face of the Sun, or as blacknes is the foyl of beauty, and he preumed that it was the lutre of their merits, that had dazled him, and obtruded an erroneous etimation of him, which otherwie his over-peircing judgement would not entertain. And ince your Majety is pleaed (aid he) to term me a Phoenix, although its not my happines to merit it by any thing ele, yet it hall by this, that my fortunes, life and honor, hall be ready to be acrificed, when the rays of your commands hall enkindle, and I hould account uch an immolation, as the greatet felicity the heavens could betow, it being the onely way to conecrate me to an eternity of honor, among poterity; Acts of Loyalty to ones Prince, being as embalming pices, to the names of faithful ubjects. Oh that it were my fortune to expire in uch a net of pices, inflamed by your Royal Mandates. Let this command (anwered the King) to remain with me, be for an exploration of your obedience, which you o highly profes. Let me be tigmatized with an eternal brand of infamy (aid Pandion) if ever I let a command drop from your mouth in vain.
Thus with thee, and ome other expreions, was Pandions abode there concluded, and he was led among them to the Palace.

And thus did Danpion play this firt Act of that real enterlude, whoe Scenes as they had been hitherto generally mourntul, Fortune dreing her elf in Tragick attire, o they continued; for during the pace of everal Months, that he remained in the Court, he never could have opportunity, either to reveal himelf to Amphigenia, the Mitris of his heart, the main reaon of his continuance there, nor to meet with his friend Periander, at the place appointed, and agreed betwixt them. Some few groundles hopes he flattered himelf withall, was his only upport, which daily encreaed, as his favour with the King increaed, which was alo every day more and more, o that in concluion, within a hort time, his graceful deportments, unconquerable valour, acute wit, and all beyond his years, and that which added grace to all, his delicate beauty, were all as o many letters of admiion into the Kings heart; o that nothing of moment was done in Court or Kingdom, without Danpions conent and advice. All Offices and favors were ditributed and dipened by him; no affairs of conequence in the State, but he had an influence upon and inpection into. A great olecim in Policy for o great a Politician as Hiarbas was to commit, for by thee favors, did he weave a webb to intangle himelf to his utter ruine. Princes had need beware, whom they imbrace in the booms of their affections, much more whom they entertain in their Cabinet Counels. For as the eye being the mot tender part of the body, will therefore leat endure any injurious uage, and we are mot careful to preerve it; being the directrix of the whole body o a Princes undertanding being the eye of a
Kingdom, which ought to be of a Lynceous Sagacity and acutenes in the dicerning of Counels and Counellors, and be able to peirce not only into the widom of their advice, but integrity of their very thoughts and purpoes, therefore mot perillous to have it corrupted by the poyonings of unfaithful Counel, which like fale Mediums repreent the tate of things, in another poture than as they are in themelves, and by that means their Government is under-min'd, their honor ecliped, and a gap made for all innovations. This Hiarbas conidered not, his judgement being blinded by his affection, but let all things be wayed by Danpion, who notwithtanding was little atisfied with all, whilt he was barred all means of obtaining her, whom he preferred before all. And one Evening as he walked out, to feed his love-tarved heart, with the weet repat of his fancy, he heard a voice deliver it elf in uch ravihing Airs, as might have compared with the Spheres dancing harmony, and drawing neer, the more to enrich and refine his thoughts, with thoe heart-pleaing trains, with the ditance interrupted, he aw a Lady playing on a Lute, with accents o weet and oft, as if each note had been a cloze of Angels Muick; the Air with uch weet vibrations danced after her fingers, as if the wind of it elf had breathed Muical Tones, and drawing near, he heard her ing this Song.

lg.l: Phaebus lend me thy fulgent rays
To pencill out my joy,
Free from annoy,
None ele can to the life expres,
My heart-tranporting happines:
Gild with thy Beams my happy days,
Expell each interpoing Cloud
That eeks to mask thy face, and hrowd
Thy golden locks, and dim my joy,
Free from annoy.
On lively pieces, Artits cat
A pleaing darkning hade
On what th'ave made:
Umbriferous troakes of black depair,
My infant joys, oon would impair,
And them compell t' expire their lat,
Should Fortune eek, out of her hate,
In triving to delineat
My blis, to cat depairs dark hade,
On what he' as made.
You rowling Spheres, lend me your tones,
To warble out my joy,
Free from annoy:
A Lutes weet note-producing womb
Is far more fit to be a tombe
To interr the joys of mournful ones:
For her bet traines are weet and ad,
And makes the hearer ad and glad,
According dicords; but my joy
Hath no annoy,
You Quire above, lend me your Lays,
To twit a heavenly vere,
Joys to reheare:
My wit's too barren to expres
My words-trancending happines,
Unles you it refine and raie;
Draw wits Elixar from the Nine
Patrons of Poeie, o that mine
Heightned with that, may in a vere
My joys reheare.
Sure Love's no Vertue, for it moves
Its heart-inflaming beames
Sill in extremes:
If deep depair, racking annoy,
But if ure hope, ther's rapting joy;
He loveth not, that meanly loves;
Rather 'tis Vertues quinteence,
The pirits of their excellence,
Theauriz'd in its Hive of beams,
Still in extremes.
Lovers have Poles to which they tend,
But if in love th' excell,
No parallel:
Or if they have, thee Parallels kis,
And Poles do meet, which makes the blis,
In Lovers hearts, which hath no end.
Then hence all cumbrous grief be gone,
Here's room for nought but joy alone,
Our hearts do meet, our Loves excell
All parallel.

div.p: Having ended her Song, there aroe a Knight that had lain undicovered on the ground, and taking the Lady by the hand, thus proffered to alute her, Come my divided Soul (aid he) my weetet half, let me fix on thy Roie Lips, the eal of my contant affection; and let our kies be as the endorements of that delight, which by mutual vows and tipulations written in our hearts, with a Pen pluckt out of Cupids Wing, we have obliged our elves to bles each other.

Danpion calling to mind, he had heard that voice, and therefore preumed he might not he unacquainted with the peron, drawing neer to ee who it hould be, he preceived it to be his friend Periander, whereat not a little rejoyced, he demanded of him, if that was not the Lady Florinda, which honored him with her affections, for (aid he) my dubious thoughts collect o much, from that Song which her Syren voice lately warbled out. Periander acknowledged, he was.

Then Danpion turning to Florinda, thus accoted her, Madam, aid he, accept of this rude alute as an oblation to your Beauty, where the glory of all perfection is enhrined, and which makes me eteem Perianders felicity above expreion, and uch that were he not Periander, I could freely indulge my thoughts to envy him, but my heart is wholly devoted to his happines, and mine's involved in his.

After mutual gratulations that pat between them, Danpion requeted Florinda to honor him with the relation of the manner of her ecape, from Acatus King of Coninth, and how he fortuned to meet with Periander, which he conented unto, and thus declared.

The fates (aid he) who expoe not their decrees to vulgar view, though for a time they eemed to thwart my deires, and bury my hopes in the grave of depair, yet they intending in concluion, (as the event manifets) to crown me with my long-wihed-for joy, to bring about their reolutions, thus ordered it.

It happened that Novellus the Kings Nancius that brought me that ad citation to the Court, no ooner aw me, but he fell into his Maters ditemper, and grew fondly amorous, and carried me to the Palace, but put me in the cutody of Octavia, a Lady, as great an admirer of him, as he was of me, and told the King, that the preent tate of my body required purification, ere I was fit for his Royal embraces; which Octavia no les watchful than Argus, nor jealous than Juno, readily confirmed, of all which I was ignorant, but amazed at my imprionment, and what hould be the reaon of my invitation to the Court, untill at length privately inquiring of Abra, Octavias Woman, he fully informed me of my condition; I perceiving by Novellus faint ighs, and mind-dicloing countenance, his paionate affection, reolved to make a vertue of neceity, and by his means to make a way for ecape, and therefore cat frequent favourable glances • t him, and ometimes let fall ambiguous expreions, to encourage him in his affection, and the more to provoke Octavia's jealouie, who nor able to uppres thoe ardent flames that run thorough all her veins, preently uggeted to the Queen the whole matter, who no ooner heard it, but her heart was arreted with the Tyrant pangs of Jealouie, in as great a meaure as Octavia; o that between them both they thus plotted my detruction, either to convey me privatly put of the Kingdom, or to end me to Deaths
cold confines, with a poyonous drop, ecretly infued into my cup, and then by commixing ome dangerous drug with my Phyick, bereave me of my life, and them of their jealous fears. But my courteous tars, whoe benign rays were as o many Bucklets to protect me from the inolence of thee two Furies, would not permit this horrid contrivement to take effect; For one morning when Octavia had reolved to attempt her intended murther, Novellus as he was wont came to viit me; but Octavia knowing how contrary to her bloudy deign Novellus preence was, refued him admittance into my chamber, pretending my indipoition of body rendred me unfit for any ociety for the preent. Novellus the more deirous of entrance preed o rudely, that with the trugling Octavia pilt the venemous draught which he had prepared for me; which my Dog preently licked up, and fell into a languihing ditemper, that in few days killed him. I perceiving this, not daring to trut my elf with one o barbarouly perfidious, reolved to go to the King, and impetrate a releament from my imprionment, or if it was denyed me, to effect my freedom by a plot which I then contrived. Accordingly chooing a convenient opportunity when the King was olitary, and none to interrupt or oberve me, I went into his preence, and fell on my knees, and thus addret my elf to him.

Royal Sir, (aid I) ummoned by your Majeties Command, I thought it my duty to attend your pleaure, but ome in the court, I preume unknown to your Highnes, have not only retrained me from the performance of my duty, but from all liberty; o that my humble ute to your Highnes now is, to upplicate a freedom from uch retraint, and I cannot but hope your Majety will not remain inexorable, if you retain your <> clemency

Before I could have ended my peech, the King aroe, and with a miling countenance took me by the hand, and made me arie; Come aid he, my hearts weet Jaylor, let me ingraft thee on my heart with thee embraces, and let us mingle our united ouls with mutual kies, this is my pleaure and the pleaure I command.

Oh Sir, aid I, will you thus contaminate your untained honour with o foul a blu • ; you whom the world hath honoured for a Prince, that could govern your mot exorbitant paions as well as your kingdoms, and by that means fabricked a kingdom of honour in each noble breat, who pay you the contant tribute of aiduous Prayers, for your long life, and whoe perpetually admiring thoughts are your ubjects, will you now expoe your glorious name to the blats of vulgar opprobry for the obtaining of a little beial pleaure? By that time I had aid this, there came in one of the Nobles, who eeing the King to frown upon him, for this interruption of his privacy, uddenly retired, and let us to our elves. The Kings lacivious <>
were not all extinguihed with what I aid, but he continued his endeavors to obtain his lutful deires, but in a more gentle manner than before, uing nothing but inticements and perwaions, untill in the conc • uion I eemingly conented to meet him the next day in the private walks, where none were admitted without pecial licene, whither the King was wont to reort for his private meditations; but with this provio, that the Queen hould be conveyed the next morning ome ditance from the palace, let her jealous vigilancy hould deprive us of our happines. The King was as ready to conent to that as my elf, o that with a countenance bewraying much affection,
and how ill I brooked o long protraction, I parted from him, and hated to Abra, whom I made the contant depoitory of all my ecrets, and bid her go to the Queen, and with a great deal of pretended zeal to her honour, inform her of the plighted vows between the King and me, and of every circumtance of our agreement, and advie her to attire her elf in my habit, and Abra in the Queens, and o they might dicover and prevent our libidinous machinations. Abra the next morning, according to my requet, carries ome of my vetments to the Queen, and as I had counelled her, informs the Queen, and peruades her to dres her elf in thoe garments of mine, which to that end he pretended he had ecretly conveyed out of my chamber, and brings the Queens robes along with her, as I had requeted.

The Queen tung with this report, greedy of revenge, impatient of delay, thus diguied hats to the walks, which I being acquainted withall by the means of Abra, put on the Queens Robes, and in as majetick a poture as I could frame, eated my elf in the Queen •
bedchamber: But long it was not ere my ignorant deliverers came, and uppoing me to be the Queen, ubmiively delivered this meage.

Madam (aid they) the Kings Majety attends your preence below, intending to bles himelf with your company abroad this morning, to alienate thoe griefs from his breat, which your abence hath revived. Many perwaions you may conceive were uperfluous to me, who deired nothing more than this happy means of releament. Therefore thus attended, I rode abroad in the Kings coach, ome miles from the Palace, untill I perceived a place where I thought an opportunity to ecape preented it elf: Then I deired the coachman to et me down, for I told him the
time and place eemed to invite to contemplation, and o commanding him to wait untill I came, I walked out; but when I thought my elf out of his fight, I ran to a Town adjacent, whence the next day I went to range the wide univere in earch of my dear Periander, and hearing of his abode in Thealia, hither I fled on the wings of Love, and by the means of ome Ladies in the court, who have hewed extraordinary favour to me, I got to be an attendant to the Princes Amphigenia, who is o male affected to the Male ex, that he will not admit any to have a view of her, not retain any of her Ladies of Honour, whom he finds in the leat degree amorouly affected; o that now I am chained with as great a bondage as before, though not o dangerous and dihonourable. And as for my happy meeting with the Crown of my joyes Periander, it was this evening, that walking out to take the freh air, I heard a Lute, o admirably played on, that methought I felt my very oul tuned in conort with the trings; o that nothing would atisfie me till I had reolved my elf who was the Author of thoe melodious trains, but ere I had taken many teps, I plainly perceived it to be Periander, the weet Saint, to whom I had gone o far in Pilgrimage,

Florinda having finiht her relation, Danpion and Periander informed each other of the tate of affairs in both Factions, how they much debilitated the trength of both parties, the one by perwading the King, and the other the counterfeit Pandion, to turn out many, and frown on mot of thoe Lords and commanders, who were mot faithful to their trut, and placing uch of mercenary pirits, who mut be cudgel'd to loyalty with a ilver wand, and others, that had revolted through diaffection, and the ecret ininuations of private perons et on work by them for that purpoe; and
farther, how that m • ny great perons on either ide, that might prove potent and irremoveable obtructions to their germinating deign, that through dieteem they had caued to turn from the one ide, they had alo diobliged them on the other, by repoing little or no confidence at all in them, that o they might remain as Neuters, and finding Incivility from both parties, they might be affected to neither, and in fine when their contrivements were come to maturity, Pardion dicovering himelf as he intended, thee might be the perons that might defend his interet. And for men of ervice and action, that till adhered to their ingagements, and that by their magnanimous exploits had fixed themelves in favor pat all remove, they endeavoured that as little countenance might be hewed, and reward conferr'd as poible, thereby to uffocate thee Martial parks, in thoe brave loyal piri • s, which every blat of infamy blown at their Maters honour, was ready to increae to a flame of revenge, to conume the detractors to Ahes. Then they agreed on the time and place where they would meet, to acquaint each other with their Plots and Counells, that o what the one had advied to or diwaded from, by the others aitance might take effect, and both be confirmed and fixed in their Maters favour.

And latly they concluded, that Florinda hould yet continue to wait on the Princes, who having o great an influence on her Father, by the mediation of Florinda, many things might be done, which Danpion would be unwilling to appear in. After mutual te •• imonies of great affection, they parted to their particular habitations.

Danpion that had conumed many days in fruitles endeavours to get but a minutes conference with Amphigenia, could not during all that time that he remained in Hiarbas Court, by all the ubtilties his Wit could invent, once bles his eyes with the ight of her, but he daily pined in the midt of exces; o that his cutom was to withdraw himelf frequently from all ociety, to convere with his thoughts, accounting himelf never more accompanied, than when ecluded from all company, entertaining himelf with oliloquies and paionate dicoures; one while lamenting his hopeles condition, then extolling the beauties of Amghigenia; ometimes charging himelf with extreme folly, and baenes of pirit, that he was not able to bridle his paion. Hath propitious heavens (would he ay) profuely howred down their choiet favours on me, and hall my ingrateful oul repine, becaue it is their pleaure to detain Amphigenia from me? It may be the Powers Divine ent her hither, to triumph over the ret of Natures works, and to hew in her Snowy skin, how pure a grain they were able to <> and fearce ou • , out of the coure Elements; and in her heart-captivating eyes, what Jewels they yet retain, farr exceeding any that ever yet adorned our Mother Earth. <>
may be they eteem her, as he jutly merits, too fair a trancript of divine excellencies, to be blu •• ed by humane embraces, and intend to ix another Virgo in the heavens, having tellified her on earth, with o many heavenly beauties and graces, as he is already grown a Con • ellation. Shall I then oppoe the powers ublime, that are able to diffect me to inviible, to indiviible Atomes, when with their bounty they have o liberally bribed me? Am I not above expectation ecurely riveted in the Kings boom? Am I not placed next the Throne in power? Do not all the inferior
Orbs receive motion from me, as their econd moveable? and all powers dye or vegetate according as they receive warmth from the Sun-hine of my favour? What can be more atisfactory to a lofty pirit than Supremacy, and hall I lament becaue the Stars of Amphigenia's eyes refue to hew their lutre at the high noon of my properity? Amphigenia did I ay? Can I name that name and not adore it? Could I in a Poetick rapture admire her trancendent beauty, and not be thought an Idolizer, I would tranlate my very Soul into a vere, that might expres the mot pure Elixar of my Love, which if I thought he would vouchafe the reading, I would diolve my heart into a tear, which black with contant griefs might erve for Ink to characterize my mind. With thee and the like peeches would he bewail his depairing and deperate affection. All his hope was in Florinda, whom he had prevailed with to be his Interceor to Amphigenia, to peak in his commendation, and to dive into her thoughts, what he could, and to try whether it were poible to root out that humor in her, o antipathetical to the Maleect, and inect her with amorous inclinations, and latly to advie him how he might procure a view of her. To all which he received little atisfaction, the lat excepted; For Florinda had dicovered a ecret vault under ground that conducted to Amphigenia's Chamber, this he informed Danpion off, who as Florinda had advied him, on an Evening took a Lute, and tole to Amphigenia's Chamber, and there behind the hangings thorough a crevice uneen, he might dicern all over the room; on whoe Arched top, ome rare Apelles had deciphered many excellent Hieroglyphicks, devies and Imprea's. There was This • e newly returned from the Cave, where he had hid her elf from the Liones, and beholding her lover Pyramus fallen on his word,
he tood as if he was tatuized, the Painter having pourtrayed in her countenance, the paions of grief, grown inenibly profound, and confounding admiration, o to the life, that the beholder might ee a contention between them both, and yet a predominancy of neither. Not far ditant was Narcius, kneeling over a Fountain, beholding his face in the Crytall treams, augmenting them with his tears, and with a weet lovely pining countenance lamenting, that uch a thin tranparent Wall hould part him from his imaginary love, whilt the feigned pecies o lively reflected back his weetly languihing looks, that one could not tell, which mot deired the others embraces, which mot lamented and pined for their unhappy eparation. There tood the fair Phrygian Shepherd giving the golden Ball to Venus, who receiving it with a pretty inulting mile, looks on Juno and Pallas, whilt corn revenge and envy diplay themelves in Juno's countenance, but a modet bluh veils Pallas's beauty. There was Jupiter courting Io, with a look dicovering both a venereous affection, and a fear to be dicovered by jealous Juno, who was painted to come out of the Clouds with uch • lahes of rage from her eyes, as if he had been a thudnerbolt; and here the Painter ued uch Art, that if you looked on the one ide, it was as here is repreented; but if on the other, you might ee Io meramorphoed into a Cow, therein imitating Jupiter himelf, who (as Poets feign) was • ain to tranform his Concubine into a Heifer, thinking thereby to hide his alacity under a Cows Hide, from his wives jealouie. Hard by this at Hercules in womans attire, pinning at Queen Omphales commandment, with a furious countenance, and a Beard like the Tow on his Ditaff; who would have moved a Stoicks pleen to laughter, whilt the Queen its in State, and with a
Majetick mile beholds him. By thee in Landskips was double-topt Parnaus, Atlas-like upporting the Clouds, on his ide at the Nine Mues, and Apollo the Preident of that Virgin Quire; from his top tragling rivulets treamed down. Near that was Mercury like a Shepherds Boy, toying with Hebe under a preading Oak. In one part Ganymede, carryed by an Eagle up to the Clouds, and wanton Jupiter, looking down from heaven, with a greedy delight on his fair Boy, and blaming his winged Embaador for his loytering. In another, was Phaeton, thrown among the Clouds, and Titans
• aging Palfreys, having broke their reigns, galloping through the flaming sky, the Chariot tumbling, and Heaven and Earth of a blaze, as if the Elements had exchanged their places; the hungry Fire foraking its lofty dwelling, and comming to feed on the earth, the Clouds dipoet of their Airy manion by the moak, and the Earth and Water acending, only refined and minced into leer A • omes, and in the midt of all this Combution Phaeton falls into Padus; His iters bewailing his misfortune, weeping, as if thoe flames had exhaled all their moyture, or as if with the moyture of their tears they endeavoured to quench thoe flames, are turned into Trees, but o retaining their natural forms, as it was difficult to ay, whether the drops fell from dewy boughs, or tears from their eyes. Under a Canopy repreented like a Cloud, held up by four winged Angels, whoe golden plumes pread erved for Curtaines, was a rich Bed, covered with a counterpane of Tiue. The Table was pread with Carpets, of Violet Damask, bordered with Gold. Amphigenia was et in an Ebony Chair, covered with purple Velvet, attired in Carnation Sattin, embroidred with Roes of Gold, her hair which hung in heartintangling Curles, was powdered with eed of Pearl,
her face eemed a compendium of all thoe excellencies, a treaury of all thoe riches that Beauty and Majety can betow to make humanity adorable. Danpion that thorough the crevice could perceive this miracle of nature, as if every beam hot from her eye had darted into him an Enthuiam, ravihed with a kind of divine afflation he ings this Song.

lg.l: You Angels that reide above,
Refine my wit to' expres my Love,
And ing her praie.
In Nectars pirits let me teep
My brain, for Hyppocrene's too coure,
T' would tain my wit, which wants a ource,
And flowing fount of fancies deep,
To ing her praie.
Inhabit then my teril brains,
Inpire me with Seraphick trains,
To ing her pie • ,
Whoe each part is a Mint of heavenly treaures,
Excelling all Elizum's feigned pleaures.
Each eye's a hive of radiant beams,
Whoe heav'nly rays that thenceforth treams,
My oul intrance.
There Venus Doves do build their nets;
Thence Cupid hoots his fiery Darts,
Would melt and peirce the teeliet hearts,
And ouls with rapting love divets,
As in a trance.
There wanton Love in ambuh • ys,
To natch my oul out of my eys,
And it intrance.
Raviht with her perfections, here I lye,
Wrapt in a Soul-tranporting extaie.
Then mut I lye here in a wound?
And is there none can cure my wound?
The darts themelves
That gave the wound, the wound can cure;
Love with thy wings come gently fan
My burning Soul, ther's none ele can
Heal me of my Love Calenture,
The darts themelves
Except <> with Love balm,
My raging oul can't cure nor calm.
The Darts themelves
Thus ript with love and beauty oon would eae
My burning heart, and raging oul appeae.
Pure threds of puret gold's her hair,
Which amorous hearts oon do innare,
All pearls trancending;
The Down that's under Angels Wings
Is not o oft, Titans bright fair
Rich dazling trees can't compare
With that curl'd up in curious rings,
All Pearls trancending.
You heav'ns, come hew your power and art,
Transform into a Gem my heart,
All Pearls trancending,
That having lutre from her eyes, and there
Fixed, may make rings for the Gods to wear.
Ah is there none the way can find
My captiv'd fetter'd • eart t' unbind,
Bound in her hair?
The more this bow-knot I unlooe,
Ah me! the fater it doth knit,
And triving more, I tangle it,
And wind it in an endles nooe,
In her fair hair,
A bow knot, well I may it call,
Since from Loves bow is all my thrall,
Strung with her hair.
Soon would my heart be eas'd of all my trouble,
Would he but tye this ingle Love-knot double.
Her lips are beauties nets that well
Pregnant with weets, where graces dwell
Wrapt in Vermilion.
Th' Arabian Aromatick gales,
When they the bluhing Roes kis,
Breath not uch weet perfumes, as is
Her breath, which her pure lips exhales,
Wrapt in Vermilion.
Each word an Eagle oaring high
With wit, that from thoe lips doth flye
Wrapt in Vermilion.
When he peaks, Angels liten, and the Spheres
Stand till, neglect their Muick, wih th' had ears.
No wonder all means prove o vain
To make her heart love entertain,
For Love is lain,
And plunder'd too of every weet,
In her hard marble heart he lies,
Intomb'd, his hafts are in her eyes,
Her puret white's his winding heet,
Poor Love is lain.
Her lips with his blood prinkled are,
His wings are now become her hair,
Ah! Love is lain.
His bow is turned into her arched brow,
And thus poor Love is lain, but none knows how.
My Lute, let's ing his obequies,
You Clouds with tears upply my eyes,
For Love is dead.
No marveil then that all things war,
Love tunes the whole worlds harmony,
Whoe diapazon still doth lye,
In weet conent, where is no jar,
Ah! Love is dead.
Oh no, the wanton awcy Boy
Would with his mother port and toy,
Love is not dead.
For which he hath exil'd him, and he's fled
Into my heart, and feigns that he is dead.

div.p: Amphigenia that had attended to this Song with delight and atonihment, admiring whence the Muick came, for by reaon of the thicknes of the hangings, and largenes of the room, the Lutes weet Airs were not o cleerly conveyed to her ear: But directing her teps by the obbing voice, he came to the hangings, behind which Danpion at; where calling for Florinda, demanded of her, if he knew whence thoe trains hould come. Who replyed, that it mut be ome Angel that was turned inamorate, and fled to her Chamber, mitaking it for Loves Paradie, for ure no mortal dares or can attempt (aid he) o neer an approach, when retrained by your Fathers pecial prohibition.

Danpion hearing Amphigenia make uch trict inquiry, hated thence, let he hould be dicovered; but now the flames of Love burned with more vehemency than before; o that the torment had been inupportable, had it not been fanned and cooled with hope, which began to breath upon him with ome gentle guts. For having uch a paage, where undicovered
to any, he might have reort to her Chamber, he reolved to peronate ome Intelligence, till he might have free admittance to her preence, which in time he thought he might be able to effect, by reaon of Florinda's intimacy with her, who by her ininuations, would confirm in Amphigenia's apprehenions what he hould do, not to be deluions, but realities. Accordingly the next night after, when he thought the time of night might invite fair Amphigenia to refreh her elf with weet lumber, he took his Lute (as before) and oftly tole to her Chamber. But as he went, his mind was filled with ditracting thoughts, How well (did he ay) doth this blind paage reemble thoe blinder paths I thus tread to my happines! Thee dark windings, and craggy turnings, that this Vault abounds in, methinks lightomly repreents the inexucerable difficulties, and inextricable intricacies, I am forced to pas thorough, and mut be involved in, ere I can arrive at any glimmerings of hope. But my comfort is, that, as this conducts to an Elyzium, uch a one, as the Gods would exchange theirs for, uch a one as the Antick Poets inpired with a prophetick as well as Poetick fury did but typifie in their fictions; o the various windings of my unhappy love, when my Cloudy fortune hall unmask her dusky face, will at length be unwound, and come to a bottom, where they'l centre in an Elyzium of happines.

Being come to the end of the Cave, he perceived Amphigenia fat aleep, her Wax Taper burning by her. As he lay his eyes carved uch ravihing weets, as tranported with the violence of o many Darts, he thought he had attained the Zenith of his felicity. The Pillow blet with a kis from her Cheeks, as pregnant with delight, welled on either ide. Her eyes Canopyed in leeps dark veil, hewed lifes triumph in the
Map of death. Her hand contended with the Lawn for whitenes, and being partly covered with it looked like a Lilly through puret Crytall. A lock that had tollen from its weet prion, folded in cloudy curls lay dallying with her breath, ometimes triving to get a kis, and then repuled flew back, ometimes obtaining its deired blis, and then as rapt with joy, retreats in wanton caperings. Her body that lay arayed, or rather diarayed in a thin Smock, wrought with blew ilk and ilver, obcured not her skin, but rather made it appear the lovelier, if lovelier it could be. Her breats at liberty diplayed, were of o pure a whitenes, as if ones eye through the tranparent skin, had viewed the milky treaures they incloed. Her Violet veins that treamed in branched Rivers, eemed like Azure paths in a milky heaven. This confluence of delights, put Danpion beides himelf for a while, but recollecting his thoughts, he took his Lute, and tuning it in Conort with his Soul, in a Love rapture ang this Song.

lg.l: Were I immur'd in fleh and blood,
And might enjoy o weet a good,
I'de not exchange my blisful tate,
With any earthly Potentate.
Ah now I ee that beauties Darts,
Can penetrate the Angels hearts.
I ee thoe lucid Stars that hine
In Heav'ns bright Orb, neer the divine
Empyreal throne, though they trancend
Earths beauties all, yet love can rend
The heav'ns, and peirce the Azure sky,
And rapt them with loves extaie.
Who'd think the winged Boy could climb
Through all the tarry Spheres ublime,
His quiver fill'd with beauties rays,
And though o blind, yet ee uch ways,
In heaven to teal, and durt enthrall
The very powers Angelical?
Sweet Amphigen' thy beauty rings
Through Heavens Court, each Angel ings
Thy praie, and poor I, to behold
What ame had eccho'd there, and told,
Came thence; but now flames from thine eye.
Hath indg'd my wings, I <> rie.
And more, this Love, a power divine,
T' inlarge his wings, hath piniond mine:
My pain here ende not; for uneen
Poor I mut bear his arrows keen,
npittyed, whilt he humane ene
Prefers before Intelligence.
Sure fitter tis, for uch a gem
Heav'ns King to wear in's Diadem,
Than mortal man t'injoy alone.
What fitter may b'ingrafted on
An Angels tem, or in heav'n fixt
A Star, than with uch dirt commixt?
Poor flehy puddles will but tain
This Gem, which none can cou • e again,
Time will but mask thy face with rut,
And then convert thee into dut;
Whereas an Angel ca • t an • ate
Thee to a high immortal ta • e.
But weetet, take thy ret, and leep,
Whilt here Ile it, and gaze and weep,
And trive to pend my elf in groans,
And lull thee with my mournful tones;
My power extend Ile, what I can,
Fair one, to be thy Guardian.
The fates decrees are, there mut none
Injoy thee, but great Danpion,
And happy he mut glut his ene,
And atiate with thy excellen • e,
Whilt I will eek all what I can,
To be to both a Guardian.

div.p: Scarce had Danpion ung the firt part of the firt Stanza, ere Amphigenia awaked, and attentively litning to the Muick, her watchful enes, by that time the lat was concluded, were bribed by the Muicks Charming Airs, to re-enter Morpheus drowie Cell, which Danpion perceiving returned, and left her to her weet repoe.

No ooner were the hadows of the mity Night dipered, by the Roie mornings purple beams, but the leepy Deity dimied weet Amphigena's enes, out of his drowzy prion, when calling to mind, what her ears had been entertained withall, in the beginning of the Night, he began to doubt, whether it was not a viion; but long he had not revolved thee things in her ambiguous thoughts, ere Florinda came into her Chamber, and after alutations that paed betwixt them, Amphigenia acquainted her with the whole relation of what he heard, demanding what her judgement was concerning it, telling her, he was perwaded it was a deluion, for (aid he) it conits
not with Angelical purity to admit of muddy paions, we may as well think a dunghill can tain the Sun beams, becaue they view it, as that an Angel hould be enamored with humane beauty. Will they whom Nature hath refined to uch a purenes, that they eem to be termed pirits, in that they are the very pirits and quinteential extracts of heavenly excellencies, will they, I ay, delight in uch earthly dros as we are, who are at bet but well-complexioned dut, cemented with a little moyture? our Souls, though their inferiours, could not be blurred with fond contaminating paions, were they not immered in fleh and blood. 'Tis true, what you ay, Madam, replyed Florinda, but yet the loud fame of your trancendent beauty, which Ecchoes from one Kingdom to another, might reound thorough heavens hollow Arches, and the piritual inhabitants might draw the Azure Curtain of the sky, and gaze upon their Makers workmanhip; and ome one of that winged crew, more ravihed than the ret, with his Creators power and widom, in framing uch a compoition, out of uch coure principles, might decend to bles himelf with a cleerer view of you, which he aw, but imperfectly at o great a ditance. I hould be mierable vain (aid Amphigenia) hould I heed thy words and were it not that my contant experience of thee confirms in me the reality of thy affection, I hould think thy hatred to me, made thee ue thoe adulatory expreions to make me conceited of my elf, and thereby to render me ridiculous. Madam, anwered Florinda, you are above the power of adulation, no tongue can be liberal enough, much les too profue in your praies.

Pray forbear (aid Amphigenia) unles you will incur my irreconcileable dipleaure. But (aid he) what did he mean, when he aid Danpion hould enjoy me,
and glut his ene with me, as he termed it, mut he deflour me? You put too hard a contruction on it, aid Florinda, Danpion is a peron of too much honor, to commit an act o vile and dihonorable, and I am confident would kill him that hould dare to ugget o bae a thought to him. I rather think that heavenly Intelligencer had • urned over the pages of your fate, and read your detiny, which it eems is, that notwithtanding your trange avernes to all men, yet Danpion is deigned to be made happy with your affection, and in concluion, with the fruition of you, who is one, that though he cannot challenge to himelf o great deervings, as to merit you, et o adorned with Beauty and Vertue, inriched with all things, that may make a man incomparably compleat (Nature intending to hew in him, what humanity is capable of) as methinks he eems the man that heaven hath endued with thee excellencies, on purpoe to make him a fit conort for you.

After thee and many other the like peeches that paed betwixt them, they heard a noie of Drums and Trumpets, and other Martial ounds, as if there were a udden preparation for War; but ere they could conider what hould be the caue, a Lady that attended upon the Princes Amphigenia in her Chamber, came running panting and in an affrighted poture told her that Pandio •
was coming with all peed with an Army to beiege the Palace, but the King her Father, having intelligence of it was newly marched out with his guard, and as many as could be in Arms on the udden, intending to give him battel; and hath left Danpion to Rule and Govern the Palace in his abence.

This news did for the preent ta • tle Amphigenia, untill the conideration of the jutnes of her Fathers
caue, the valour of his peron, and the continual ucces that ever attended him, as if he had made a League with Fortune, banihed all affrighting Paions, and reduced her to her elf; and then he began to entertain a thought which never before enter'd into her mind, and that was to ee this Danpion whom the pencill of fame had painted with o many excellencies; and in whom her Father repoed o much con • idence; and concealing her deires, he ought all opportunities, when undicovered he might have a view of this darling of Nature. And perceiving her endeavours to be vain, he ecretly acquaintnd Florinda with her inten • s; who inwardly rejoycing at thee beginnings of Amphigenia's converion from uch a hereie in Nature, endeavoured to augment thoe deires in her; and told her that he ued to reort to the Walks frequently to meditate, and that in the Cypres Grove neer the Fountain undicovered he might ee him if he took the benefit of opportunity when he went ab • oad, which was either in an Evening, or early in the Morning.

Florinda having given this advice to Amphigenia, preently pots with all hate to Danpion's Chamber, thorough a private paage, where he and he had egreed to have their continual entercoures; and informs him of her deires, and advieth him to appear in as gallant habit, and as richly accoutred as may be, that o if poible to lide into her affections, & <> upon her complying mind. Danpion, who had never been yet acquainted with any mediocritie, grew as boundles in his joy as before he was in his grief and depair, and oberving Florinda's counel, furnihed with all rich habi • iments, went down into the Walls jut as Titans moking Steed • were poting to bath themelves in the Wetern Waves, where accordingly, as he had told
him, he perceived Amphigenia tanding in the Grove of Cypres, and peeping thorough the leaves, with a look that betrayed rather a Feminine curioity, than any affection or delight. But Danpion tanding on o high a precipice of happines, lippery with affection, could not retrain his over-fond deires from hurrying him down into uch an error, as had like to have broke the neck of his deign: For his reaon being overwhelmed with uch an accumulation of encouragements, as that conidering nothing but opportunity, he teals into the Grove where Amphigenia was looking and expecting when he would return from the other end of the Walk, and thought to have powred out uch a floud of eloquence, as hould have drowned her former harh thoughts of his Sex, and wholly conquered her affections; but jut as he was entring into his Rhetorical Oration, Amphigenia looked back, and eeing him o near gave a hriek that ecchoed thorough the Grove, and ran as fat as her fair Leggs could carry her, whilt Danpion more enible of love than fear, and through this udden amazement in a manner enibl •
of neither, tands till in a tranporting admiration; but he was oon recalled out of that atonihment by the beauties he dicovered to his twice wounded eye; for the awcy wind too immodetly porting with her cloths, dicloed that which otherwie he would have concealed: o that ere he was gone, Florinda was come to her recue, with ome other Ladies that followed her, which when he perceived, he ecretly conveyed himelf away, and thence to his Chamber, where we <…> to bewail his own indicretion, and the unkindnes of his hard • ortune that ucceeded him no better.

Amphigenia, who before with Danpions majetick deportment, beautiful and yet Martial countenance,
Amphigenia and Danpion page. 134.
there being a lovely mixture of Venus's weetnes, and Mars's ternnes, began to entertain uch thoughts of him, as though they deerved not the title of affection, yet might properly be termed a good eteem or liking of him, grew now to uch a mortal ditat of him, that he began to conclude with her elf, that her pretended Angel was ome Impotor that Danpion had hired to delude her; then he began to doubt of Florinda's fidelity; at length he reolved to end her Father notice of his ignoble carriage toward her, and conidering with her elf, that though he was the Kings Daughter, yet he was the Kings Minion, and that they had need be well advied, that go about to traduce a Princes Favorite, therefore he writ her Letter, in thee ininuating terms.

body.p:
SInce my Infancy, I have ever perceiv'd in your Majety, uch an innate propenity to your peoples good, that you could never take any felicity in all the Trophies, and Triumphs that Fame and Fortune conpiring with your Valour, have erected for your eternal renow • , if the leat infelicity befell your Subjects: o that I cannot but conceive that the preent Civil broyls and dientions that diturb your Kingdomes, caue no mall diquiet in the Kingdom of your Royal thoughts; which conideration had impoed upon me an eternal ilence, rather than I would have caued any additionary ditractions in your Princely mind, had not I thought it my duty timely to inform you, let you hould nourih uch infection in your boom, as for want of mature anticipation may bring ruine
and dihonor upon your Majeties peron, Government and Poterity. Now, Sir, to forbear any abtruenes, and prolixity, and that I may not detain you too long from your erious thoughts, the occaion of my writing is this. My Lord Danpion, whom your Majety hath left here to Rule as your Vicegerent, notwithtanding thoe many favors you have heaped upon him, enough to have rewarded the highet merits, much more to have bribed the mot unfaithful peron to Loyalty, hath abued the confidence and Royal trust you have repoed in him, having not only diobeyed your trict commands, that none hould invade my privacy in the Walks and Groves, your Majety out of your Royal goodnes, hath et apart for my retirednes, but eeks to ruine my honor, and fraudulently to poes me, and in me your Kingdom, I being the immedi • te Heir. Sir, did the injury redound onely to my elf, I hould bury it in eternal oblivion, rather than perturb your breat with the relation of it, accounting that a dear purchaed felicity, that is acquired by your thoughts leat diditurbance: but if my overforward zeal clouds not my judgement, thee actions peak ambitious thoughts, and uch thoughts as dare a flight too neer the beams of Sovera • gnty. But I leave that to your Majeties all-wie conideration, and my elf to your Royal Care, not doubting but if he attempts to oar above his Sphere, the Waxen wings of his ambition will melt before the rays of Majesty, and plunge him into a Sea of miery and contempt, but much les doubting of your Princely and paternal affection and protection towards her, who hath the honor to be

div.p: This Letter he gave unto one of her principal Pages, commanding that with all diligence, care, and celerity, it hould be preented to her Fathers hands. But now to acquaint you with the raging fury, that even ditracted Danpion, when Florinda told him of Amphigenia's hatred, and what he had done to incene her Father againt him; I had need to dip my pen in Neus blood, or infue Alecto's poyon into my Ink, for never did any one o neerly reemble raving Hercules, when he had put on Deianira's invenomed Shirt, as he, when he conidered, not only that now he was unhappy, but fallen from o high a pitch of happines, and that through his rah folly, and that not onely he had incened the Mitres of his heart, but the Mater of his life, and by one inconiderate action at once cut off all hopes of ever attaining that happines he promied himelf, both in his Throne, and in his Bed.

But this tempet lated not long, for though he had not Socrates his compoure of pirit, under all fortunes to remain the ame; yet he had uch a power over his Paions, as they eldom raged beyond uppreion, or could claim uch a predominancy, but he would make them ubmit to his Reaon, as now appeared. For conulting with his thoughts, how he hould prevent this torm, that threatned his ruine, he concluded there was no way but it mut inevitably fall upon him, unles Florinda would prove his friend, but yet eem his enemy; which he conenting to, they both together agreed upon a plot, which we hall after declare.

The King, when he had received the Letter, and read the Contents, Heavens! how did he lift up his hand and admire, as though he was viewing ome proprodigious Comet in the Air. What an Age is this (aid
he) what dares not man attempt? Faithles Danpion! is this the requital for my unparallel'd goodnes to thee? is this thy gratitude? how am I abued through fond credulity? is it not enough that I have a publike adverary, that daily incroaches upon my honor, and eeks to uurp my Royal Power and Dignity, but I mut have a private Pioner to undermine them all? but no matter, Ile make him know, that Kings have thunderbolts to hurl at thoe that dare to mount the Chariot of Majety, and take the reigns of Soveraignty into their preumptuous hands, And ince he dare to Arouze my anger, he hall oon find its Lion-like roarings hall awake him, out of his dream of imaginary dignity, and then hee'l wih his ambitious thoughts had flown at lower ditance.

Thus the King tormed for a while, but recovering himelf, he began to conider, that it was not afe to continue his Daughter and family under the command and inpection of Danpion, that ought o baely both to blow up her honor, and his power; and that it was les afe, to call him before the Tribunal of publike Jutice, his affairs being now in uch a ditracted poture, ready to be beleagured with a potent Army; and therefore he had more need endeavour union amongt his men, and by that means, to fortifie himelf againt his common enemy, than to diminih his trength, by augmenting and fomenting more diviions, which he feared would follow, if he hould on the udden totally degrade him, and confer his honor on another.

And therefore to avoid this Scylla and Charybdis, he reolves to couch his reolutions underneath his ecret thoughts, and end for Danpion from the Palace, and put him upon omething that could not be effected without the los of his honor or life, or both. And
this way he counted the more ecure, remembring, that uch Court Minions, that like Stars of the greatet magnitude, move in o high a Sphere, are eldom ecliped and obcured by the interpoition of a new Favorite, but rather by the bright lutre of the rays of Majety.

To proecute his intents, he ends for Danpion, who in obedience to his ummons, marches from the Palace, and as he thought from all his honors, hopes and preferments, but being of an unconquerable pirit, bears it with as much magnanimity as he was able, and comes to the Kings Camp; but above and beyond all his hopes and expectations, the King looks upon him with a mooth brow, and tells him, he had found him to be a man of an impavid pirit, and greedy of renown, and therefore he had ent for him, to perform a piece of ervice, the very attempt whereof would redound to his great honor, but the execution of it, would not only crown him with immortal fame, but be highly advantageous to the Kingdom; Danpion ee-uch an unexpected event, began in his thoughts to inult over this reult of Fortune, and thus replyed, Great Sir (aid he) I were unworthy of either life, or honor, hould I refue, at your commands, to part with either, ince to your exceeding munificence I owe more than both; neither can all I were able to do, could I accomplih more than Hercules, return uch retributions as might compenate thoe trancendent favours, your Royal goodnes hath been pleaed to confer upon me. Therefore were it to cale the heavens and fetch Atlas thence, to conquer the Rebels your enemies, though your valour needs it not, yet were it your commands, I would do it, or dye in the attempt.

Then (aid Hiarbas) I am informed that Pandion hath
an inchanted Standard, whoe Magical force, o ingages all the Subterranean powers, Pluto's black Legions on his ide, that he is invincible, untill ome valiant Knight, by his ingle fortitude, takes it from him, and I know none in my Army or Kingdom, whoe great undanted courage would provoke them to undertake uch an enterprie, except your elf. If that be all (aid Danpion) my word hall oon cut the Charm in under, and end the infernal pirits themelves down to their dark manions. Whereupon he went and furnihed himelf with Hore and Armour, and all things requiite for his encounter.

Pandion being come with his Army in ken of his enemies, draws them up into a Battalia, intending to fight, which Hiarbas having notice of before, by his Scouts, he draws his men alo up into a form, and after a brave Oration, to incourage them to fight, he himelf in peron marches before them into the field. Where, as if the very fight of their enemies had been a Loadtone to their courage, their Martial pirits were o provoked, as that it was difficult for their Commanders to retrain them from making an untimely onet.

The ignal for the battail being given, there began uch a terrible conflict, as that within a hort time, thouands lay dead in the place, both ides maintaining their aaults with uch impetuous rage, as if the Gyants had been come, to heap mountains of Carcaes, to aail heaven, and beiege the Gods; nothing but fury reigned in every b • eat, ome that were thrut thorough with Lances, would yet run themelves farther on to reach their enemies, and require that morral wound; others, that were jut expiring through want of bloud, would yet trive to bequeath another death as their lat Legacy to their
Sabillus and Bonous p: 141.
enemies; the earth grew of a anguine complexion, being covered with bloud, as if every oldier had been deaths Herald, and had come to emblazon Mars's Arms, with a Sword Argent, on a Field Gules There was Panomphaeus a Commander under Hiarbas, that fought a ingle combat with Sabillus, who after he had his Breat ript open by an unfortunate blow, yet held his ides together with one hand, as if he had bee •
buttoning an upper Garment, whilt he encountred Sabillus with the other, till Bonous came, and thrut his hand into his body, as if he would have pull'd his Soul out of her dwelling by violence, and tare away his Vitals.

Sabillus enraged that he had thus natch'd his victory out of his hands, lifted his Arm, intending to have cleft Bonous's head, but the word by an accident flying out of his hand, only cut off his Noe; which unexpected blow o tunnied Bonous, as in an amazednes, looking on one ide, and the other, to ee which way the blow came, as if he would not take the advice of his eyes, now he had lot the Moderator that ued to interpoe betwixt them, and in a fury ran forward, and (as the Proverb hath it) followed his Noe, and ere he himelf, or Sabillus were aware, thrut him thorough the throat. Here lay hivered Lances, and broken words, and there dead Hores, and Carcaes of men mangled, as if they had been newly anatomized.
