In one place lay Heads depoed from their overaignties, yawning and ta • ing as if they looked for their Bodies; In another heaps of mutilated Arms, Hands, and Legs, as if Death had there kept its Shambles. Long did the fight continue dubious, Fortune equally haring the Laurels, untill at length it began omething to incline to Hiarbas; which Memnon
a valiant Warrier and great Commander under Pandion epying, rage and contempt o burned in his boome, that his eyes flamed, as if they had contained the whole Element of fire, and he thundered forth a roring voice, as if his Lungs had ucked in the middle Region of the Air, and with his breath he could blow away a World, upbraiding the Soldiers for their bae puillanimity, to give ground to uch a datardly crew as he conceived his enemies to be, and running into the mids of Hiarbas men, with uch a boiterous madnes, as if with his ingle valour he could end an Army to Tartarus, and by his trength could unhinge the Poles, and top the primum mobile's career, he laughtered all that tood within the reach of his weapon, decollating ome, making them horter by the head, and diecting others, ome he thrut thorough with his Sword, pointing out plainly what death they hould dye, and cleft others skulls, and thus he unmercifully triumphed over his enemies, till at length Death put an end to his victory, by a flight of Arrows that, feathered with detruction, lighted upon him. And thus was he lain by this winged Army, which otherwie would have lain an Army had he lived, and at his Death haled hundreds of ouls out of their claiy prions, and compelled them to attend him in the other world.

His followers provoked by his example, to make good what he by his valour had gotten, had engaged themelves o far in the mids of their adveraries, that at length they were urrounded on all ides by Hiarbas his policy, who had caued his men before to retreat ome paces backward for that end. Danpion who had all this while been butcherring of his enemies in the rear, intending to cut his way thorough them to come to the Standard-bearer, perceiving o great a
breach, and Cham (as it were) in his enemies party, improves the benefit of opportunity, and rides up to the Standard-bearer, kills him, and in the fight of all his enemies carries away the Standard, which Phoedon a Commander of Hore under Pandion epying, purued with full peed with all the men under his command. Others that knew not of this accident, eeing their Standard flying, and o great a party fled after, thought the day was lot, and time to ecure themelves, and thereupon flung down their weapons, and hated after the ret, with uch confuion, as put them into no les diorder than themelves. With that a party of the Hiarbian Hore, to compleat their victory, purued them, and put them o to the rout, that they le • t few to complain of their harh uage, and ome recued Danpion, who being overtaken, having indeavoured to keep his prey in depight of his adveraries, that invironed him, had almot reigned it up, had he not been relieved by this fortunate chance. In the mean time thoe few that were incloed by the Hiarbians, were acrificed to appeae the revengful fury of their enemies.

The victory being thus obtained, and Danpion contrary to Hiarbas hopes and expectations won the Standard, by this valiant act got o much renown, that he was more admired than before; the general applaue of the Army o cried him up, that Hiarbas grew more jealous of him than ever, and reolved if that which his Daughter had writ was true, to cat him out of favour wholly, and put him in an utter incapacity to accomplih any of his high projects. But though thee were his ecret intentions, yet he carried himelf with as much external erenity towards him as before, and arriving with great triumph at the palace, after he had abode there ome time, he ecretly inquires
of his Daughter, whether any one ele could affirm, what he had writ, to be truth.

She told him every circumtance of it, and how that Florinda was come to her recue, before he had fled from her, and that he preumed, that he was able to inform him more ditinctly of his intentions, than her elf, to whom he was and ever hould be an utter tranger.

With that a Lady was preently dipatched as a meenger to Florinda, to acquaint her that the King deired a few minutes conference with her in Amphigenias Gardens, where he tayed expecting her coming. Florinda obeys the ummons, and accompanies the meenger to the King, who after ome private convere with her, is exceeding inquiitive to know of her whether he could give him any particular information about Danpions deign; whether he ever had dived into his thoughts, and could tell whether he had any aim at the Soveraignty or not, and many other quetions to the ame effect, he demanded of her. Florinda gives him little or no atisfaction to all his Quae • ies, but endeavours to confirm his upition, what he could, and inveighs againt Danpion with more bitternes than Amphigenia, and at length uggeted to the King this Counel, that ince they had no reaons to convince any man of Danpions treachery and diloyalty, but what was grounded chiefly on upition: if his Majety would deign to honour their advice with his acceptance, he would inform him a way, • how he might ranack his very intrals, and dicover all his intentions, and read the very inide of his heart. The way he aid was this, that the King would pleae to counterfeit himelf uddenly eized upon with a malignant ditemper, and
for a time retire himelf in his Chamber, and admit none of his greatet favourites to wait upon him, nor viit him, but only the princes his Daughter, and her elf, that o there might be no grounds of upicion for Danpion; and in concluion to feign himelf dead. And then (he aid) he quetioned not but that he had uch an influence upon him, by reaon of more than ordinary affection that Danpion bare to her, as in his preence to make him confes to her, if he had any thoughts tending to Amphigenia's dihonour, or of diloyalty to the King.

This advice was accepted of, both by Hiarbas and Amphigenia, and accordingly put in execution; So that uddenly the ears of all were filled with the ad news that the King was fallen dangerouly ick. The Courtiers warm like Bees at the King Chamber door, to perform their Allegiance to him, but none admitted, amongt whom Danpion was a contant viitant, but as contantly as the ret repuled.

In fine, Danpion was ecretly informed that the King was dead, and that care mut be taken for etablihing his ucceor before his Death hould be divulged, let the knowledge of it hould caue any broils and tumults in the Kingdom, which it might be apt to occaion, there being uch warms of dicontented perons, and thoe that affected novelties and alterations, though for the wore. And if he received not this information for truth, his eyes hould convince him, if he would come to his chamber, for Amphigenia (they told him) durt not dioblige uch a potent peron as himelf, who might hazard to interrupt her ucceion.

Thee things being privately buzzed, and whipered into Danpions ears, by ome that were Florindas
engines, he accordingly repairs to the Kings chamber, where he finds him tretched out on a bed of State, and covered with a Pall of black Velvet, the body lying in a poture lively repreenting Death, and none but Florinda in the room. Danpion having contrived all this before hand, and by the aitance and fidelity of Florinda, thus far effected it, was not now to eek in the latter part of his plot, but thus begins to confer with Florinda. Since Heavens (aid he, eignedly weeping) have thus deprived us of our King, and me of my Royal Mater, accounting us unworthy of him, and him more worthy to inhabit among the celetial dwellers, than uch as we are, it is both our widom and duty, firt to proclame his Daughter Amphigenia, let an interregnum hould occaion any inurrections among this people, prone to rebellion and diorder; And then to honour his Memorial, with the celebration of his Funerals in as great State as may be, both to tetify to the World our Loyal affections to our deceaed King, and alo that our Forein and Intetine wars have not o exhauted the publick treaury, but that we are able to upport and maintain the honour of our King and Country. Tell not me (my dearet) aid Florinda, of State affairs, they belong not to our Sex, but if I have found any place in thy Heart, let me conjure thee by the many vehement protetations of affection, to dicloe a ecret to me, the faithful revealing of which, I hall eteem as a far greater confirmation of thy loves reality, than ten thouand aeverations. Prethee be free and ingenuous in thy expreion, and leave not my thoughts a prey to their own anxiety, to doubt will more torment me than all thy tongue can utter, Firt let me dye (aid Danpion) before I let a word drop from thy mouth in vain. Then (aid Florinda) what was the meaning of your attempting
to invade Amphigenia's chatity in the Grove? Invade Amphigenia's chatity (aid Danpion) may I ink to the Center of the Earth, if ever uch a thought poet my mind; what Devil breathed this abominable report of me? hould I rip up my breat, and diect my heart, thou houldt find nothing but Contancy and Loyalty there, which when it is otherwie, may the powers above tear it out of my body, for a preventive pattern to future Ages. What occaioned your being there? (aid Florinda) were not my eyes pectators of her affrightful flight? did I not ee how a palli •
whitenes had uurped the poeion of her beauteous face, and expelled the Roie rednes thence? did I not ee, how every part of her fair body was hook with a timorous Paley, jut as the Apen leaves tremble, when the gentle Air oftly breaths upon them? did I not ee you in the Grove tand benummed with atonihment or pannick fear, I know not which, as if you had been Planet-trucken, or ome uneen Nemeis had tatuized you, on purpoe to dicover that dihonorable intention of yours, which you would have concealed? Prethee then dicloe the caue of this that I have aid, unboom thy thoughts to me, how can I think thou dot include me in thy heart, when thou dot exclude me out of thy mot retired reolves? If I hould deny what you ay (aid Danpion) it were jut the earth hould open me a living grave, and intomb me alive in her dark Cavernes But (aid he) the caue of Amphigenia's flight, may oon be conjectured by any that ever heard of her Antipathy towards all of ou •
Sex, for he had no ooner glanced her eye upon me, but as if I had been ome Demon, or horrid apparition, he fled, as though my very looks had infued a wiftnes into her. But I'le a • peal to her, if I either aid or did any thing, that Dio •• s would bluh to own. And
it was my fond curioity, that prompted me to take a view of that Paradie, which ince, I undertand is reerved only for Amphigenia's privacy. So that my ignorance put me upon that uncivil intruion which otherwie the torture of a thouand deaths hould not have compelled me to. But I hope my future fidelity hall crave my remiion at Amphigenia's hands, and confirm my innocence.

No ooner had Danpion ended his peech, but the King tarted up out of the Bed, at which Danpion flew back, pretendingly amazed, at this uddain reurrection. Nay (aid the King) let not our eeming retitution to life, urprie thee with a caueles fear. Our ears have been auditors of thy expreions. This was but a contrivance to earch the truth of that which my upitious thoughts uggeted to me. We have found thee truly Loyal, and thou halt find out Royal goodnes extended to recompence thy all-deerving worth. Thou art now fater rivetted in our boom, than before. Danpion hearing this, fell down on his knees, and humbly begged pardon for his offence, which was no ooner craved than gr • nted.

And thus was he more confirmed in the Kings favour than before. And now he reolves to acquaint Periander with his ucces, and advie with him, how he might proceed in his deign of obtaining the Kingdom, which he had daily more and more hopes of, by reaon the breach between Hiarbas and Pandion was till augmented, but their trength diminihed. And one Evening, when as the Sun drawing nee • his occident, extended the hadow of the mountains, Danpion under pretence of riding out to take the freh Air, ecretly teals to the Cave, that little Senate-houe, where Periander and he had agreed to meet and conult about their deigns; and having waited there ome
time, Periander came.
