Danpion and Periander hoping they might meet with better accommodations there than here, accepted of his invitation, and went along with them, leaving Mochus kiing and courting of Daphins. Thyris greedy of knowing who thee perons hould be, eeing them to be likely and hopeful young men, demanded of them their names, and whom they erved.

Periander (according to the agreement between Danpion and him, to change their names) called himelf Troilus, and Danpion, Thetilus, and told him that they were ervants to a couple of Gentlemen, that lived the one neer the Court, and the other retyred himelf in the Country, and they two being of acquaintance, had incon • iderately travelled together, o far into that Foret, that they had quite lot their way, and intreated no other courteie of him, but if poible to direct them out of the Foret, for otherwie they feared, if they hould tay untill Battus came home, they hould exceed their time limited, and incurr their Maters di •• leaure. Truly (aid Thyris) this many a long day have I been a hepherd upon thee Plains hard by, and yet never in all my life did I tray any where, unles after a tragling heep, but up and down from one neighbors houe to another, and none about us knows the way but Battus, that I can t • ll of.

With thee and the like dicoures they paed away the time, until they came to the houe that to ••
upon a pleaant plain, mantled with the verdant <> , and checkered with eye-pleaing Flowers, which <>
to a little hill, upon whoe apiring brow, you might urvey the Country round, which though it abounded with enamel'd Meadows, pread with Flora's Tapetry, and Patures for Sheep to graze on, watered with bubling Springs and murmuring Streams, and all things for a Shepherds life, yet it was inriched with invious Woods and Forrets, not pervious for any but thoe well acquainted with the paages, o that it eemed like a weet pleaant pot of ground that they had cull'd out to encloyter themelves from the reidue of the turmoiling world.

Troilus and Thetylus (for o they now termed themelves) having a while viewed the pretty delightom propects that the Country preented to their ight, went into the houe with Thyris, where there was his two Daughters Phyllis and Arethua, as buie as Bees, running up and down the houe to fit it againt their Father came home. Phyllis was a pretty black wench, of a loving nature, but proud and coy, and though deirous of a Husband, yet thought few good enough for her, but would lift up her noe, and wag her head with many a coy nod, as though he lookt higher than uch as they, and tell them, that truly he could live without a Husband, whatever they thought. Arethua was fair and modet, and mightily itched for a Husband, and therefore would cat many loving heeps eyes at young men that came in; but yet if any came to her, her foolih bahfulnes would not let her conent, but he would pule them out all

Aoon as thee two aw Troilus and Thetylus come in with their Father, oberving diligently that they were prettier and more proper men than ordinary, and hoping they might come as Suters, fell inamoured preently with them; Phyllis he began to feel her heart tumble up and down in her, and he could not but
skeu at Troilus and wih that he was her Husband; when his lips opened to peak, he imagined they mack'd together, as if they were kiing of her, and if he chanced to look awry, he thought preently it was an amorous look at her; and he would make many occaions to pas by, and then he would look more demurely than ordinary, and skrue her face into a poture, that a bit of looking glas flatteringly made her believe was handom, and dip down many dainty dops, as though omebody had truck her in the hams. Arethua, he was taken with Thetylus, and he was not o confident as her iter, but would tand behind the pantry door, and peep through the key hole at him, and oh! he wihed that he could entice him a milking with her, and he reolved if ever he came a wooing to her, that he would pluck up a good heart, and ay Yes at firt word, for by that ugly word No, he had lot many a well favoured uter, that would have had her otherwie. But hey, the joy there was when their Father came and told them, that thee young men were come to be their Husbands, and bid them be kind to them; that is a very unneceary command, thought they. Phyllis he felt her heart wamble, and pant, and keep uch a tir in her, that he could not ret in a place, but mut needs hop up and down the houe, and was ready to go to Troilus and tell him he conented, before he knew whether he would have her or no. Arethua was o netled, that he flung to and fro, as if he had a gad ly in her tail, and both of them were o over joy'd, that neither of them knew what they did. And thus were the poor wenches enes almot rackt out of coure between the extremes of Joy and Love.

Many days Troilus and Thetylus here continued to their far better contentment than at Battues. Phyllis
and Arethua being very obervant, wooing them by their officious carriage, and Thyris hewing all manner of kindnes, according to his rutical generoity, hoping to win them in the end; daily telling them how many teems of Oxen he would give Phyllis, and how many flocks of Sheep he would give Arethua, and what Meadows and Paturage he would betow upon them, and thus continually ty • ing their ears with uch kind of dicoure, untill at length the nine days were expired, but yet no news that Battus was come home, for Thyris would fain have continued them a • his houe, till he had enticed them to have married his Daughters, and therefore concealed Battues coming as long as he was able.

But at length for all Thyries policy, one morning there comes a couple of young Shepherds to his houe, and deires to peak with the trangers that he harboured there, Thyris
<> they might come to bring the fatal tidings that Battus was returned, began to deny that they were within, which Troilus hearing, upecting there might be ome plot in agitation, calls out to the Shepherds, and tells them that if they had any thing to ay to them, they were within, and might be poken withall: whereat the young men preently marcht in, and being pretty burly chuffs, and
<> their countenances to chumping looks, the bigger of them, and as he himelf thought the touter, comes up to Troilus, and challenges him to do any manner of <> with him preently, whatever he durt. P • eth • e • ellow (aid Troilus) what dot thou mean? <…> , what dot thou mean fellow? aid the <> ; Fellow me, no, fellows, but
<…> daret, thou knowet well enough
<…> but that thou art wilfully blind, and
<…> cowardie, and art afraid to ee my
Troius and the Sheaphard page. 169.
meaning, for fear then thou houldt be engaged to accept of my challenge; I ay once more come out of thy den here, if thou dart, thou datard, for thy ears; I'le promie thee, if thou dot, I'le beat thy noe flat; what thou thinket to teal away Phyllis neakingly, and no body know of it, but for that trick if thou hat her, it hall cot thee a bloudy noe, for all thy fine gewgaws about thee. Troilus loth to decend o much beneath himelf, as to fowl his fingers with uch a rude lout, told him that he came not for Phyllis, nor his intent was not to have Phyllis, he might do what he would with his Phyllis; what wilt thou lye too (aid the Shepherd) and with that perceiving that Phyllis aw him through a chink of the door, reolving now if ever to hew himelf manful, natches up a fire-hovel that tood by him, and was ready to trike Troilus over the face, but that he quickly oberving it was time to curb his rudenes, nimbly drew out his word and cut off his hand, and with the force of the blow truck him along, o that the hovel falling upon the ground, and his hand upon the hovel, and himelf upon his hand, he looked as if he had been hovelling his hand into the fire. The other young fellow willing to econd his companion, gets up a skene bill, and laid at Thetylus, and had cle • t his head ere he could
• nd his word, had not old Thyris, fearing he hould
• e a Son • in-law, held the Shepherd by the arm, but
<> willing to have his blow before Thetylus could de
•• nd himelf, wings himelf from Thyris with uch
•• lence, that his coat being old and rotten, one that
<> ued to wear in his nonage, he • are off the leeve;
<> he not regarding that, lays, at Thetylus, who by
<> time had found his word, and de • te • ouly avoid
• ng the bl • w erved him in the ame manner, as Troilus had his brother Shepherd, ince he o much deired
to hare with him in the ame fortune, and almot cut off his arm that it depended only upon a little morel of fleh, that kept it from falling to the ground, o that as his tother arm hung without a leeve, o this hung like a leeve without an arm; but feeling the mart of the blow, and eeing the ad effect of encountring with a champion, he flings away his Bill, and falls down on his knees, jut as the other had made a hift to cramble upon his knees, and asks forgivenes, laying all the fault on his brother Shepherd, aying, that he had not come but for him, and calling him logger-head, and all the rutical names that his beetle brain could invent, for bringing him into uch a premunire. With that the other fellow inraged, gives him the lye, and a box on the ear, which was returned him again to the full, with interet, o that there had been a combat between thee one handed men on their knees, had they not been parted by Thetylus: who before he would fully pardon them, laid this penance upon them, that to procure their remiion for their uncivil abues, they hould one of them run to Battues houe, to ee if he was returned yet, and the other remain as an hotage. They replyed that he had been at home thee three days at leat. Troilus and Thetylus hearing this, commanded preently that their Hores hould be fitted ready for their journey, which was readily performed, o that taking leave of old Thyris and returning him thanks for his courteous hopitality towards them (who poor man could not refrain from weeping, to ee that he mut part with them, and in parting with them, part with all that felicity he flatteringly promied himelf in them) they went on their journy towards Battues, but taking the Shepherds along with them let they hould deceive them. And by the way Troilus begins to examine
the fellow that had o rudely affronted him, what was the reaon that he came and challenged a tranger in that unmannerly manner as he did? Ah! (aid the Shepherd) Love, Love was the caue, you would have betirred your elf an you hould have lot your love I warrant you; Why are you in love (aid Troilus) prethee tell us how thou camet about to be troubled with that ditemper, and with whom? Why (aid the Shepherd) one fine Somers-day, as you hou'd ha' een among twenty, I walked out to look birds nets to and fro among the hedges and buhes, but weas me! intead of finding what I ought, I found what I ought not, as well as ought not what I found; for tragling up and down jut like a tray'd heep after my port, I hapned to epy in Thyris Garden, a Buh made of Cupids Arrows, where Venus Doves had built their nets, and poor I, ingrant of loves matters, thinking cunningly to have catcht them ere they were aware, as we do other birds, was cunningly caught my elf, with the lime twigs of beauty; o that though I now deire what I found, yet I found not what I deired: and who d'ye think I found? why it was 'eene Phyllis, amiable Phyllis, dainty fine Phyllis.

Phyllis with face fairer than any new wahed Lamb, with eyes black as Berry, and lips as red as Coral; this Phyllis, I no ooner aw her, but as if her look; had bewitched me, I could not for my life retrain my eyes from tragling after her, but I mut be looking at her, though to my cot, I found, that every look (methought) conveyed a piece of my heart, to her til at length he monopoliz'd it all to her elf, o that I minded nothing but thinking of her, and neglecting my Sheep, would walk all alone and talk of her, ne're caring what a murrain became of my flock, for now I my elf was become one of Cupids flock, and Phyllis eyes were the
heephooks wherewith he caught me, her mouth the Tar-box, and her comforting words the Tar, wherewith he kept me from pining away with the Love-rot; the pond where he daily waht my fleece was made of tears, for indeed when I was by my elf, I could do nothing but whine, as oft as I thought of Phyllis; and as he daily wahed me, o he daily fleeced me, that I was become 'een nothing but skin and bone, that I looked jut like a Skillet (as Doctors call a man, after they have picked his bones) o that when I came amongt the ret of my companions, they amazed got about me like Birds about an Owl, and made jets of me, ome aid, I lookt as I had got the Murrain, and would rub Tar over my face; others aid my bones lookt like a et of keiles, and would tos their bowles at me; and indeed I did look mot piteouly, for I have often een my face in a Spring, but for all that, I in the end obtained Phyllis's love, and was to have been married to her, jut as you came to the houe, but aoon as you came, the cae was altered, Phyllis looks coy (forooth) as though I were not good enough for an husband for her, and he lookt for another-gates husband than I, and the like. Whereupon (dy' ee) I enquired after you, who and what you were, and whether you came to marry Phyllis or not, and amongt my neighbors, at length I heard, that you came to teal away Thyries daughters privately, and no body know of it, but the old man, who had conented, and brought you to his houe for that purpoe, and the young Maids, be ure you would not long tay for their good will, for they were o much taken with you, it paed, that none of we durt peak to them, the Gentlewomen were grown o proud, whereupon (dy' ee) I was o provoked, that I hould be o didained, and my Fathers eldet Son and all, that I reolved to try
a touch with you, for I would have you to know, that though you now were too hard for me, yet I could make my party good with e're a young man of my inches, in thee parts, let him be who he will. And then the fellow began to puff, and look bigger than ordnary, and with that welling made an end of his tory.

But by this time they had gotten to Battues houe, where (as their fellows had told them) they found him at home, o that having dimied them they applyed themelves to Battus, and requeted him to conduct them out of this Foret, and they would recompene him for his labor. Battus willingly conented, and o they went on their journey, when by that time the Worlds great Luminary had hid himelf behind the mountains, and was decending to take his ret on Theties watry couch, they came to the place where they firt met, where having firt gratified Battus for his pains, the two friends Danpion and Periander (now no more Troilus and Thetylus) agreed upon time and place, where again they might have recoure to inform each other of the affairs of State, and of the tate of affairs in both parties; and o they parted, Periander betaking himelf to Pandions Catle, and Danpion to the Kings Court, whither by that time the torches of the night were enkindled in the heavens, he arrived. But carce had he alighted off his hore, ere winged Fame had carried tidings of it to the ears of mot, and by reaon of his eminency it was not long, before it was known to all, o that the King having notice of it, he immediately ends for him to come to his preence, to give an account of his abence, for there wanted not in the Court, thoe malitious and yet ambitious pirits, that repining at Danpions upereminent glories, took all advantages againt him, and in particular this of his
withdrawing from the Court to beget upitious thoughts of him in the King, that o by degrees they might bring him to his Occident, whoe preence thus in the Meridian favour, totally obcured their lutre, and in whoe abence only their dim Star-light could appear. And knowing him to be too potent with the King, and too trongly fixed in his boom, to remove by apparent violence, and impetuoity, they therefore imitating thoe that when they cannot take a Fort by torm, eek to undermine it, ought privately to calumniate and reproach him with treachery an infidelity, to which this preent abence of his eemed to add no mall confirmation.

But all thee obtrectations proved in the end but like Dogs barkings at the Moon, who lackens her pace never the more, nor wraps her face in a Cloud never the ooner, for all his Cholerick yelpings. So Danpion oon obtained his former favour, when he had informed the King, that the occaion of his abence was only an accidental los of his way, as he rode out on an Evening for his recreation.

Danpion having continued ome time in the Court, eeks by all means poible to acquaint Florinda, that he was returned, that he might give him intelligence whether there were any hopes of reconciliation with Amphigenia, and whether all endeavors to that purpoe would be fruitles or not.

Florinda having notice by this means that Danpion was come, ecretly repairs to his Chamber, and there tells how deperate avere the Lady Amphigenia yet continued to all his Sex, and in particular to him, by reaon of the lat affront he offered her (for o he eteemed it) but yet incourages him to proecute his intents, with what prudence and ecreie he could, for he aid the proecution of uch a deign required both
in the full extent of their natures; and moreover he promied him that wherein her aitance could be available, he did oblige her whole power to his ervice. Danpion returning her infinite thanks for her unimitable civilities, takes his leave and goeth and ponders by himelf, and at length concludes upon a plot, which in hort time he thus puts in execution.

It was when the black brow'd night triumphing over the day, ate haking her dewy locks in her Ebony throne, having pred her rorid Carpet over the able Hemi • here, and dul-eyed Morpheus, with his drooping Charmes, and huht the tyred enes to their ret, when Danpion attended on by his Page, ecretly teals through the crankling vault, to Amphigenia's Chamber, whom he finds jut as the drowie Deity had benummed her enes, a book in her hand, and her waxen Taper, a Lovers true Hieroglyphick, burning by her, as if compoed of Lovers hearts, it had fetcht flames from her eyes, and with thoe flames conumed it elf to ahes. And perceiving the opportunity fit for his intended enterprize, he attires his beautiful Boy like one of heavens wift Purivants, with golden Wings, which by reaon of a private Engine, o poyzed his body in the Air, like Archytas Dove, that as if ome ecret pirit lurkt in thoe gilded plumes, he could convey himelf whether he pleaed. About his fair naked body was girt a ilken weed, which partly of a Caerulean-colour, weetly intermixed with purple treaks, eemed as if he had been clothed in a piece of Aurora's mantle, and partly of a mity gloomy colour, artificially interwoven with Gold, looked as if he had natcht a Sun-beam, heathed in a dewy cloud; that golden Zone that encompaed his middle, looked like the Zodiack, the Jewels wherewith it was embot, like the Planets, and the rich Carbuncle, that erved for a
button, whoe nature is to be mot reulgent in the darket night, hone with o much replendency, as in the midt of that darknes, it mot lightomely repreented the Sun. In the one hand, he put a Harp, and in the other a Letter, which was thus upercribed. Venus Queen of Beauty, to Amphigenia, her Succeor.

In this Garb he conveys him into the room, through a ecret paage, like a trap-door, made in the roof of the Chamber, that he had carved out for that purpoe. The lovely Boy, being thus entred into the room, and intructed in all things, gently moves his Air-dividing Pineons, and marrying his weet quavering voyce, to the Harpes ravihing Airs, as he flys, ings this Song.

lg.l: Fair Venus Queen of Beauty's dead,
And hath bequeath'd her white and red
To Amphigene.
And that her Graces all hould lye,
In thee as in a treaury,
Perfections lovely Queen.
Thus runs her will,
And heavenly powers have worn it to fulfill.
And thoe that us'd for to invoke,
Her name, and make her Altars moke,
With fumes of ighs,
And haunted oft her hallowed hrine,
And owned Love a power divine,
Quotidian votaries,
At her lat breath.
(More weet than Myrrh!) to thee he d • d bequeath.
A coyn made of thy heavenly gold,
With melting flames of love that hould
Diolved be,
And Cupids image tampt thereon,
And dol'd about to thee, for none
But uch deerv't (aid he)
And then a groan
She gave, that heav'n eccho'd with the tone;
And ighing aid, as he did mone,
I here urrender up my Throne
To Amphigene.
Her eyes refulgent beams mut be,
Scepters to rule all hearts, and he
Mut now be Beauties Queen:
Go, Boy, proclame,
Through all the world, fair Amphigenia's fame
Scarce this he aid, ere he expir'd,
I'me come to do what he deir'd;
Hail Amphigene.
All hearts mut now revere, adore
Thy rare perfections, nay yet more,
To thee as Beauties Queen
Admiring eyes
And tongues mut tribute pay, and acrifice.
The powers above, to keep their vows,
With Graces all do Crown thy brows,
Her will t' obey.
Her neckles made by Cupids arts,
Of weeping eyes, and bleeding hearts,
Linkt on a fulgent ray
That treaming came
From thy weet eye, they mut retore the ame.
The Coach where he triumphant rode,
And thy Idea hath abode,
Is Danpions heart;
Thy cheeks mut be the milk • Doves
By which the Chariot's drawn, by Loves
Trancendent Conquering Art,
And to retrain
Thy tresing curles mut be both whip and reign.
Then as a Herald from the powers
Above, the Queens Executors,
Proclame I do,
Thee, Queen of hearts, and Queen of Love
That Angels rules, that dwell above,
And men that live below;
Then here by Jove
And Styx thou wear't, thou'lt not a tyrant prove.

div.p: Having ung this Song, as he wav'd to and fro in the room, he gently decends upon the Bed, where Amphigenia lay, and delivers her the Letter, which contained thus much.

body.p:
Let not my death caue thee to entertain any undervaluing thoughts of thy perfections, for though with its ordid embraces it may oil o pure an immaculate trancript, where Nature in Roie t • nctured • eatures, as in golden Characters, hath exactly copied out thoe Excellencies that give immortality to the Gods, yet know, the Original is on • ile in Heaven, which time with his ruty fingers can never come to defile. Beauty is an immortal Plant pringing up in humane oil, an inextinguihable ray of Divinity, or rather an enravihing reflection of the dazling Beams, that tream from Divine Beauty; therefore the powers ublime have decreed,
that though in me (ah me!) their protraicture's defac'd, the trancript's oiled, the oil is poiled, the Plant is withered, the reflection haded and ecliped by deaths malevolent interpoition; yet that in thee their picture hall more lively be pourtrayed, the trancript varnihed, the oil enriched, the Plant tranplanted, and the reflection with greater lutre augmented, and the quinteence of that purity which made all hearts adore me, and gave me a divine overaignty, and unlimited prerogative, mut be tranmigrated into thee. Then ince by the univeral determination and uffrage of the Gods, You mut ucceed me in my dominion, take this advice, as the counel of a dying Queen, and your predeceor, Avoid thee two extremes.
1. Let not your beauty be a pander to venereous deires.
2. Nor let it raie your thoughts to o high a pitch above humane nature, as to didain any community inferior to divinity.

The conumption of that heap of rich perfections once treaured up in me, ufficiently tetifieth the bad conequence that attends the former error. For though my revenews were large, and o large, as that they were not capable of augmentation, without increaing to Infinity, both heaven and earth as tributaries, bringing in the choicet of their treaures, and contending who hould mot enrich the Exchequer of my beauty, of which I need not trouble you with an Inventory, ince in your elf you may read the Total umm, yet my too prodigal expence hath made me turn bankrupt, o that now grim death hath arreted me, and would convey me into the earths hollow womb, there endlely to pore upon my miery, did not fulminating Jove pawn his divinity to Bail me. But what need I
ue uch expreions as thee, to one whoe unpolluted mind was never yet tained with an unchat thought? Ele I might have added, that this counel is not only cononant to Prudence but Policy, for by that means you may contract an inviolable league with Diana, my irreconcileable enemy, whilt I reigned, and procure an union between the two principalities, which otherwie will be a continual pet each to other. But as for the latter extreme, what ever you do, avoid that, as a notorious Solecim in policy, and that that will inevitably tend to the devatation of your Kingdom. For who do ye think will make your acred Altars moke with incene, if you incene them with autere reryrednes, and upercilious behaviour, which above all things Lovers hate? If you would have acces to your peoples hearts, and be honored and adored in the mot recondite parts of their ouls, your Throne mut not be inacceible. You will oon find that love-wounded mortals will didain your Ceremonious rites, if you deny them Hymeneal rights, a fundamental privilege, which all your ubjects will claim as their proper inheritance.

Beauty is Natures Ivy-buh, now, you will be a Cheat to the world, if you either ell that thats naught, or there's nought to ell. What would my ubjects ay of me, think you, if you hould prove a uperficial Queen, having little of the ubtance of Royalty, and they hould ee themelves compelled to embrace a mity reemblance of overaignty in their affections? truely there's caue to fear, if you hould thus imulize Ixions Cloud, you'd be forc'd to uffer Ixions penalty, endlely to turn about the Wheel of your Fortune, and pin the thread of your own miery. To hun then both thee extremes, and tread upright, verging to neither ide, the only Counel I can give you is this.

On the one hand not to debar your elf of thoe Chat weets, wherein epoued Souls are teeped in Bridal nights; nor on other the hand to drown your intellectuals, by an intemperate quaffing & imbibing in that Cream of enual delights, which now my too guilty Soul too late bewailes. Let Hymens acred bands conjoyn your Soul with Danpions. Believe me the Virgin Zone is but a frozen Climate, productive of nothing but congealed deires, and phlegmatick conceits, where the minds Hemiphere is continually over pread with the Sable Clouds of Melancholy, untill the Bridegroom, like the Radiant Sun, darts through his rays, and makes the Zone become torrid, and the oil fertil, and melts thoe conglaciated deires into amorous delights, more weet than Pearls diolved in Nectar; and this your own experience doth in part tetifie; for whence flows that immoderate doting upon that thing called Virginity, which conidered in it elf, is but a meer negation, and hath no being in nature, but from that Melancholick humor, which ditempers thoe in your tate, with a little les than Phanatick frenzy? Philoopher • ay, that one is no number, if o, your ingle life renders you nothing, without Nuptial ociety. Now if you make your choice where I advie you, credit me, he will not prove a Cypher, but augment your number, or if he do reemble a Cypher, it will be in this, that he will encircle you in his Arms with his weet embracings, and prove an endles Circle of joy and contentment to you. Therefore if the counel, nay the commands, nay the requets of a dying petitioning woman, yea of a dying petitioning Queen, yea of your poor dying Queen, take any impreion upon you, let your thoughts pitch upon him, whoe peron, parts, and heroick actions, ufficiently render him eligible, by the mot accomplihed, and trancendently beautiful Lady,
the whole earth can boat of, and uch a one I eteem your elf to be. Ele I could have given innumerable reaons for that choice, deduced from his innumerable perfections, but I thought it would be but to gild the Sun beams, or to refine the pure Elixar of his praie.

Dear Amphigenia, having thus unlockt the Cabinet of my breat, and disburthened my thoughts laden with corroding cares, for thine and my peoples good, unto thee, and have given thee ome directions, for the better waying the Scepter I have bequeathed unto thee, which I hope thou wilt not light, being they are the lat gapings of thy deceaing Queen, and therefore mot to be attended to, as Muicks cloze hath the greatet impreion on the hearers paion, it being the compendium of all the preceding notes: I hall now acquaint thee how I have ditributed the mall remainder of my treaure, and then bid thee farewell.

Imprimis, my Beauty, my choicet Jewel, of highet etimation, I have bequeathed unto thee, not that Nature hath been any thing parimonious of her gifts unto thee, or that Charity founded on the neceitous condition of the recipient, hath been the directrix of this my benevolence; but hould I have betowed it on another, that had been the ready way to have bred endles dientions in thy Kingdom, in creating thee a Peer and corrival, which our Sex and State cannot admit of.

Item, My Venereous appetite, I have given to the Nunneries, it being the only means to et on fire Diana's Kingdom with libidinous • lames, thereby to compenate the injuries mine hath received from her deluded Vota • ies.

Item, The Net wherein my jealous husband innared Mars and me, when we were fighting a Love Duel, and atiating each others unatiable deires, I leave unto the Stews, to fih for thoe that wim down the ame voluptuous tream.

Item, The Sun-beam, which with uch awcy impudence, durt not only pry into but dicloe a Lovers ecrets, at the immodet relation of which, in a full aembly of the Gods, Aurora ever ince hath bluhed, I give unto new epoued Lovers to light them to their Bridal Beds; and as for Phaebus himelf, who ent this bold pye to reveal my hame, I charge you, revenge it, by out-hining him, in his greatet lutre, with your Beauty.

Item, The Golden Ball of Dicord, which the fair Phrygian Shepherd, on happy Ida's top, adjudged unto me, as the prize of my trancending Beauty, I have left unto the rich Miers, to be a continual caue of unappeaable jarrs, between the th • ee powers of their Souls, the Undertanding, Will, and Affections.

Latly, my Husband Vulcans horns, I have bequeathed unto the Citizens of Trachys, though they themelves through frigid terility, have been inclining to Diana's faction, yet for their Wives faithful loyal and ardent zealous affection to, and promotion of, our much depied caue, they are rewarded with them, which will prove as Cornucopiaes, filled with off-prings, riches and all terretrial bleings.

Having thus given thee an Enchi • idion, or Breviary of thoe Legacies, more at large penned down in my Will, I have now nothing to do, but to bid heaven and earth and thee and all farewell: Farewell do I ay? Can my evaporating Soul ait my feeble Lungs, in breathing forth that word, and not expire? <…>
languor runs through all my defatigated limbs, at the fatal ounding of that deadly world! methinks it rings in my ears jut like deaths Orator, the tolling bell, and comes to ummon me to the Grave; at the very thought of it my affrighted bloud congeals within my trembling veins, and a faint qualm urrounds my heart, as if a freezing blat from the glaciated Snow on the bleak Alps tops, ininuating it elf into all my Pores, beieged my Vitals. Ah! cannot heavens doom be revered? mut I decend to the hades below? mut I change my glitering Pall of immortality for deaths winding heet? Ah! methinks I feel my elf already Coffined in his Sable Arms; methinks I hear grim Charon plead for an iue; methinks a dark gloomy Cloud interpoes between me and the half-obcured light, and enwraps me in a black mourning veil. Then weet Amphigenia, once more farewell, love thy ubjects, remember me, be kind to Danpion, and therein thou wilt be kind to

div.p:
Amphigenia that with a pleaant countenance had read part of the Letter, often miling at Danpions ubtilty, ere he had perued half, converts her miles into frowns, and with any angry bluhing look, flings the Letter at the Boy, and bids him carry it back to Danpion, from whom he received it, and tell him, that he was very profue in his own praie, and that he very much doubted, whether any of thoe Hyperbolical commendations were due to any of his Sex living, much les to him; and that if his thoughts were o elf advancing, as to repute himelf a peron o highly accomplihed, the way to have others concurr with him in their judgements concerning his rich endowments (which was the thing he preumed he apired at)
was not (he aid) to reveal o much of his folly; But if he was o ambitious of praie, it had been more widom to have had another tongue, and not his own, to be lavih in his praies, or that if he mut needs commend himelf, it were more honorable to extoll himelf by his actions, than by his words; for he was ure the wiet ort of people would eteem him, whoe name was renowned for brave exploits, was ounded forth by the Trumpet of fame, to merit higher applaue, than he whoe own tongue babled forth his own commendations in uch an exuberant manner; but truly (aid he) for his actions, thoe that I have had experience of, they give the lye to his expreions. Therefore he bad him advie him to sorbear any further troubling of her with his cheating follies, for (he aid) he did but delude himelf, in imagining he hould delude her.

The Boy hearing this, nimbly natched up the Letter, and with his wings fanning out the light, that he might not be perceived how he vanihed, he wif • ly cuts through the fluid Air, and acends to the top of the room, where the paage through which he entred was ready open for his return; o that after he had delivered himelf out of that delightful prion, he neatly cloes again the breach, and flyes to Danpion, to acquaint him with the ucces of the plot, who having all this while ate in the dark Vault, was not ignorant of mot of thee paages. But when he was more fully informed, how he upected the plot, and with what didain and fury he toed the letter to his Page, he preently hats to his Chamber, commands his Boy to be abent, and lings himelf on his bed, permits not his enes to take the leat repoe, but ometimes walks up and down the room, lamenting his condition, and then toing himelf on his Couch, exclames againt all
women, and upbraids himelf of folly, to be innared and captived with uch an incontant vanity. But then he would condemn himelf for calumniating that Sex, when Amphigenia's vertues are ufficient tetimonies of the incomparable excellencies that generous Nature confers upon them.

In this retles manner he conumed mot part of the night, having his thoughts ditracted between depair and grief, which like two potent factions in a kingdom, b • ed a civil war in his breat, the event of which tended not to the predominancy of either, but only to a total excluion of Morpheus, from uurping dominion over his turmoiled enes, grown almot eneles with thoe rude broyls. But then ummoning his wonted fortitude, and invincible patience, under all the advere torms of fortune, he now begins to banih orrow and depair from him, and to rebuke himelf for his effeminate ubmiion to his paion. What (aid he) hall I, who never yet was daunted with the terrours of an enemies murtherous word, and who durt aault an army of Gorgons, Harpyes, Furies, and all the infernal Apes and Monters lited in Plutos Militia, hall I now be forced to retreat from my reolutions with a Females • rowns? and be now compelled to ubjugate my elf to every domineering paion? though I love Amphigenia, and for her ake would freely uncae my oul, and (were it in my power) transform it into a Jewel, which if I • hought he would vouchafe to honour with acceptance, I'de preent her, as a tetimony of pure affection; yet Amphigenia hall never make me unman my elf, and degenerate from my maculine aequanimity into a leaden feminine pirit, whoe embaed flexiblenes will bend and yield to every cros michance that thwarts their deires. And what though I love Amphigenia, mut I therefore do
that that will make me hate my elf? No, henceforth I am reolved to abandon all abject dicontent and grief, and leave whining depair to thoe dejected ouls, who concious of their own mall worth, become Loves footballs, and uffer themelves to be kicked and purned by tyrannizing Beauty. And though the imperious Mitres of my captived heart, doth yet retain her autere reervednes, yet he is a woman, and if a woman, light and uncontant, as the fleeting Air, or floating wave; and therefore as the Air is now tormy, and anon erene, the wave now rough, and anon calm; o who knows how oon he may calm and mooth her tormy brow, and be of a milder apect? it is but waiting till her gameome vein urprize her, and expell her rigid thoughts, and then he will be as toyih, as now he is coy. But tay, who is it, that my thoughts thus malape • tly preume to accue of levity, coynes, retyrednes, and what not? is it not Amphigenia? Amphigenia, the model of heaven, the Paragon of Beauty, the glory of Nature, the worlds ornament, the pride of Thealia, and the Mitres of my heart? Amphigenia whoe peerles perfections o far trancend the Criticim of Owl-ey'd judgement, as that their dazling lutre renders them even unapprehenible, much more incomprehenible, and mot of all uncontrovertible. Can my dim-ighted oul then think to dicern a pot in that replendent Beauty, whoe refulgent rays, though een but by reflection in my thoughts, obcure its purblind ight, with a dusky mit? what if he be coy, and inexorable to the Petitions of her poor Love-ick uppliants? it may be he is an Angel clad in fleh, and if o, her purity debats all thoughts of humane conjunction, but if not, he is a woman clothed with Angelical Beauty, and that thought ubverts all hopes of fruition. Her body though framed by Nature,
of a marvellous Architecture, yet is but a temporary Cell, where her immaculate Soul, for the freer and more uninterrupted commerce with heaven, eparated from all convere may reide, exchanging acred and ublime meditations, the mot pure offerings and weet exhalations of a Chat uncontaminated mind, for divine enthuiams and inpirations. Shall I then to purchae this tranitory Cell, ell my joys, my life, my ret, my heart and all? no my immaterial Soul will not admit of commixture with the mot refined earth, and therefore it is not her corporal part alone, though moulded into an Angelical form, that doth rapt my heart with a tranporting affection; but her Soul, her vertuous Soul, whoe beams hining through her eyes, as through a Crytal medium, reflect round her face, and exhale my affections; but alas! that's too much wedded to Virginity, and taken up with the ravihing delicacies of Chatity, ever to be adulterated and ravihed with paion, o as to parturiate amorous deires, the off-prings of love-enthralled ouls. Depair then henceforth hall be the able heare of my diturbing thoughts, I'le now compoe my interior, diordered by the jarrings of rebellious paions, and make my irrational part reign and urrender up all her faculties to the governance and direction of my intellectuals. And if my dicourteous Stars have not detined me to that happines, to be linked in matrimonial union, with uch a uperexcellent Beauty, and to have our hearts diolved into one, with the ardent flames of pure affection; I mut frame a content, and make my Soul acquiece in heavens determination. But if the kind fates have decreed the contrary, I hall with unwearied patience await, till the happy hour of Amphigenia's miraculous converion (Elixar-like) hall turn all my tormenting thoughts, and corroding anxieties into true blis and contentation.

Thus did Danpion acrifize the night to the vigils of a retles mind, till about the dawning of the day, when night grown gray with age, began to flye with his train of Stars, before Titans •
flaming hores, which were now climing up the gilded Horizon; when leaping out of his bed, he went down into the hady walks, to olace himelf in that Paradie of delights; but he had not walked many paces, ere his ear was arreted with a voice, which according it elf to a Lutes mollitious Aires, was o harmoniouly rapturous, as none but would have thought it to have been ome Seraphim, who blet with a treble portion of Celetial joys, in an extaie warbled forth his own happines; o far did it urpas the Pythagorean accents. Thee heart-rapting trains could not but extort attention from Danpions ravihed ear, o that tealing neerer, the more to atiate his avaritious ears with that vocal melody (which was but parimoniouly conveyed unto him at that ditance, as if the niggardly Grove had treaured up thoe Soul-inchanting notes, to inrich its winged inhabitants) he heard this Song.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Sweet day, o calm, o cool, o bright,
Thou hat expell'd the dusky night,
And Sol begins to mount on high,
And marry Tellus to the skie.
Each thing attir'd in's bet array,
Its purest weets now doth diplay,
As if this was its bridal day.
Why hould not we then court and toy,
And lovers puret blis enjoy?

sp.speaker: Treble.
sp.l: In pearly drops the morning weeps,
And in this dew, her orrow teeps,
To ee her elf excell'd o far.

sp.speaker: Bae.
sp.l: She bluhes in thy Cheek to ee,
So weet a Crimon dy to be,
With which her tincture can't compare.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Thus we conume the Crytal day,
And hours and minutes fly away,
Whilt here we it and court and toy,
And Lovers rapting blis enjoy.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: The Turtles chat with billings weet
Unite their ouls, whilt bills do meet,
The Roe unfolds its picy weets,
With them the purple morning greets,
And marrys her perfumes to th' Air,
The earth and skie now clad mot rare
Pride it like a new married pair.
Why hould not we then Court and toy,
And Lovers puret blis enjoy?

sp.speaker: Treble.
sp.l: The Roie morn thee drops doth hed,
As tears, that Sol her picy bed
So oon will leave, and from her go.

sp.speaker: Bae.
sp.l: Oh, no, they fall to kis the Roes,
Which thy pure Snowy Cheeks incloes,
And in that bed of Lilies grow.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Thus we conume the Crytal day,
And hours and minutes fly away,
Whilt here we it and court and toy,
And Lovers rapting blis enjoy.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: The winged Angels of the Groves,
In hady boughs do chant their loves,
The early Larks to ing agree,
This weet days Epit halamie,
Eccho transform'd by heavenly powers,
To' a voice, that haunts the Groves and Bowers,
Doth eek t' epoue her trains to ours.
Why hould not we then court and toy,
And Lovers puret blis enjoy?

sp.speaker: Treble.
sp.l: Look how the wanton air doth dance,
And then as charm'd into a trance,
Litens to hear thy warbling airs.

sp.speaker: Bae.
sp.l: The wanton wind from thy weet lips
A kis doth teal, and then it skips
For Sanctuary into thy hairs.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Thus we conume the Crytal day,
And hours and minutes fly away,
Whilt here we it and court and toy,
And Lovers rapting blis enjoy.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: The leaves now fann'd with Zephyt's wings,
Marry their gentle mutterings,
To th' murm'rings of the treams beneath,
Still purling, as the air doth breath,
The ilver treams, that gently creep,
And eem in Crytal tears to weep,
Marry the enes to their leep.
Why hould not we then court and toy,
And Lovers happines enjoy?

sp.speaker: Treble.
sp.l: Look how the days bright Harbinger,
Stands till thy charming voice to hear,
The Orbs melodious tones depiing.

sp.speaker: Bae.
sp.l: Look how Hyperion ends a ray,
To ee if thou wilt rule the day,
And eeing thee bluhes at his riing.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Thus we conume the Crytal day,
And hours and minunes fly away,
Whilt here we it and court and toy,
And Lovers rapting blis enjoy.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Fair Phil'mele on her thorny eat,
As he doth quav'ring not • s repeat,
And ing away the winged hours,
Doth trive to epoue her airs to ours.
Sometimes in plain, then by and by,
She decants weet, whilst we reply.
And thus we procreate harmony.
Why hould not we then court and toy,
And Lovers rapting blis enjoy?

sp.speaker: Treble.
sp.l: Prethee no more hyperbolize,
Loves weetet peech comes from thine eyes,
Whoe powerful language charmes my oul.

sp.speaker: Bae.
sp.l: Oh charming word! curt be that hour,
When thy commands hall have no power,
My oul to guide, rule, and controul.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Thus we conume the Crytal day,
And hours, and minutes fly away,
Whilt here we it and court and toy,
And Lovers rapting blis enjoy.

div.p:
Danpion, that for a while lay as it were Iulld into a Trance, with the Muicks weet modulations, as if his Captived Soul had been fettered with the trembling trings, and imprioned in the Lutes charming Womb, now began to be arowed with a new warm of tinging deires, whoe inordinate Curioity would not be atisfied, until he had repaired unto the place whence thoe Harmonious Accents came, that o with the ight of their Author, he might mitigate the Martyrdom he uffered under his tyrannizing-thoughts. But he oon redeemed his enlaved mind, with a full urpluage of Content, when at his arrival at that blet Elizium, he beheld the two great Sharers in his Soul, Periander and Florinda, itting together on a green Bank, under the
protection of a preading-Oak, and with their agreeing Voices, weetly expreing the internal Harmony of their concording Souls; who no ooner had fixt their eyes upon him, and knew him to be Danpion, but they aroe, and with pleaing looks, and humble deportments, the Orators of true Repect, and Affection, thus accoted him:

Our good Angel, My Lord (aid Florinda) is exceeding Prodigal of his favours to day, to bles us with the felicity of your company too, this weet Morning. Vouchafe me your Pardon, Madam, (aid Danpion) for preuming thus to interrupt your weet confederation: how much the harmonious Accents, thee weet Off-prings of your Angel-voyce tranported me, is not within the power of my ravihed thoughts to impart unto you.

Your Hyperbolical expreions, My Lord, almot perwade me to a belief, that my mean Voyce had charmed you out of your elf, but that I am too much acquainted with my own inability to effect things les miraculous: My elf mut witnes againt my elf for my own imperfections, which would oon appear, were they put to the tet of an impartial judgement. But (my Lord) I am not a • tranger to your Rhetorical vein.

Madam (aid Da • pion) I mut acknowledge you have conquered me; yet, were not I o rapt with the wonder of your Vertues and Excellencies, that my Brains incapable to <> a Reply, I could alo ay, that benign Heavens have o <…> with your ociety, that neither and wholly unacquainted with your wonted mode •• y, under which, it was alwaies yo • r endeavour to mask your Excellencies, and with which, as a di • inihing Gla • s, you ever o <> to leen your Perfections. But Madam (aid he) they are too ••
picuous,
ever to be concealed with uch a tranparent Veil; Modety rather ets a Crimon glos upon the ret, and is but a lively Frontipiece, containing a hort Enchiridion of your Perfections.

Well, My Lord (aid he) Women are the weaker Sex, and therefore however we eem to veil thoe things you are pleaed to interpret Perfections, I'm ure we mut veil to you; but this I mut take the liberty to ay, That the knowledge of my own little worth is too much fixed in my thoughts, ever to be unriveted by any Artifice whatoever. Nor hall any Rhetorick Madam, (aid he) ever • avih from me the belief of your Excellencies.

After thee, and many other the like peeches that paed betwixt them, Danpion related the tory of his unhappy love, what means he had ued to accomplih his deires, but how ineffectual; how he had rackt his Wit, and et all poibilities on the Tenters of his Invention; but how froward Fortune, the worn Enemy to Vertue, and Vertuous Lovers, had oppoed his Endeavours, and how more than all Amphigenia had loaden his misfortune with her heavy dipleaure, o that all his Hopes were now Metamorphoed into Depair.

Periander and Florinda, whoe own Experiences had taught them how to pity an unfortunate Lover, could not but commierate his hopeles condition, o that they paed away much time in conulting how to lead him out of thoe mazing intricacyes he was involved in; till at length, much of the riches of the Morning being conumed, and Titan having drunk his Mornings-draught of Crytal-dew, Florinda not daring to continue any longer, upon peril of dicovery, and a total forfeiture of Amphigenia's Favour, with many Kies and Embraces (a Lovers weetet Eloquence) took
Gylcera urpriz • d by a Pirate page 195.
leave of Periander, and with a graceful deportment, bid farewel to Danpion; after whoe departure, Periander informed Danpion what great misfortunes had of late befallen a Beautiful and Vertuous, but unfortunate Lady, whoe Redemption (he aid) would exact his preence for a time. Danpion being importunate to hear the tory, Periander thus related it.

Glycera the Nunn (aid he) that hath o urprized Pandion's affections, as if the Heavens had frowned upon her, becaue he frowned upon him, hath of late undergone uch calamities in Cyprus, (as we are informed by a Knight, that not long ince was a ad Spectator of her more ad miery) uch, I ay, as would Challenge the Tribute of a River of Tears, from an Ocean of Grief; uch as would compel the dryet Eye to bleed or weep, and by as it were an Elemental tranmutation, make the mot flinty heart evaporate in aiery fumes of ighs, or diolve into a Lake of Tears: For no ooner had he ecaped out of the Nunnery, but a cured Pirate natcht her up, and conveyed her to his Ship, where he daily olicited her to part with her Chatity, more precious to her than her life; but he abhorring the motion, continually rejected him, o that in the end, that Rebel to Vertue, hells firt-born, and heir inheriting its damnable practices, perceiving himelf to be lighted, and no means to accomplih his hell-bred deires, reolved to crop the weet bud of her Virginity by force, and rob her of that rich Cargazoon of Vertue, which her weet oul bound for heaven contained; and to that end having on a day mot importunately urged her, with all the intreaties and inticements, a hell-inpired mind could invent, eeing all in vain, locks his Cabin door, and eizeth upon her like a Hawk upon the innocent Dove, whilt he (poor Lady) trembled under his tallons, like a Lamb new yeaued
on a heet of Snow, and falls down upon her knees, and begged for heavens ake, for Vertues ake, and for his own ake, as he would not have the Sea open her devouring jaws, and intomb him alive in her vat womb, as he would not have the Clouds ditill down vengeance upon his head, not to make her innocency become a prey to his lut.

This aid, he wept the ret, bedewing her Lillyed Cheeks with Crytal tears. But he, Marble-hearted Villain, pourtraying in his loathed countenance, a doleful image of what hells cured imps animated him unto, not at all daunted with the Majety of orrow, that ate enwrapped in a Snowy veil, nor moved with her words, whoe woful accents would have melted the mot obdurate heart, and charmed the mot merciles oul into commieration, gripes her in his Arms, and flings his hellih deformed Carkas upon her, and thu • indeavours to poes him of thoe weet treaures, which had been more fit to have been reaped by ome heaven-blet, earth-adored Monarch, than by the filthy hand of uch a lut-defiled wretch.

But alas! he (poor Lady) when through the liquid medium of her tears, he aw, that in depight of her weak trugling, he mut part with her Virginity, that redolent perfume, which had wont to acend to heaven, as the weet acrifice of her Chat mind, how did he bluh, and weep, and wring her hands, as if he would queeze tears from them too, and then look pale, as if grief had wrapped her beauty in the winding heet of a Snowy palenes, being ready to be buried with her Vertue in the loathome Grave of his lut? and then bluh again, as ahamed to think of her hame, and weep as if his lutful flames had thawed her very oul into tears; tears that like Pearls, heart-breaking
orrow, woes factor, had brought from the crimon orient of her bluhing Beauty; but then a Lillyed palenes would exile the Vermilion rednes, and look like a Lawn heet cat over a bed of Roes. One while the thoughts of her dying honor, but never-dying reproach, would dye her Cheeks with a Crimon tincture, as if her heart bleeding for her miery meant to end ome treams out at the Crytal sluces of her eyes, but ah! they were anticipated by an inundation of tears. And then the thoughts of her afflicted, foraken, hopeles condition, the ad thoughts of her unheard, unpittyed, unhelpt ditres; ah! but the killing oul-vulnerating thoughts of her woful dihonor, at length quite changed her countenance (weet countenance, in which there hined a delicate lovelines, a lovely Majety, a majetick weetnes, to the inthralling of adoring minds) I ay quite changed her weet countenance to a gatly look, as if the lovely Roes of her Beauty would not grow in that Garden, where he planted his ra • es, or as if that white immaculate innocency that had hitherto dived into the bottom of her heart, and there inhrined it elf, now grown light, did wim in the top, and cover her face with a pallid whitenes, as if it came to kis her cheeks, and take its lat farewell; or rather to upplicate heaven for peedy ait <>
with hriller cryes, than any her eeble voice could utter.

The all- • uling powers, that are eldom ine • or • ble to the heaven-penetrating hrieks of ditreed innocency, had thus far permitted this flagitious mechator to proceed in his accured enterprie, when jut (oh unjut act, but jut heaven, for o merciful a prevention!) jut, I ay, as he went to unload his lut, he gave a hrie •
as if orrow had eccho-like pin'd her very oul to a voice, that it reounded through all the parts of the
Ship, like ome horrid cry of a guilt-urrounded oul, newly natcht from the clai'y prion of its body, and delivered up before it is aware to the immortal pains of the other world; which arriving at the ears of the Seamen, they like men amazed, in a mad confuion preently run to the Maters Cabbin, and force open his door, where they beheld this dimall pectacle, the Mater endeavouring to abue the dead body of a beautiful Lady (for when he aw that the powers above would permit him to depoil her of her Vertue, her Chat oul, as abhorring to hare with her fair conort the body, in o detetable a miery, fled to heaven to impetrate revenge.)

This woful ight could not but exact tears from a pumice, o that though their hearts hardned by a frequent performance of horrid actions would not relent at ordinary griefs, yet this diater wrung uch tetimonies of a true ympathizing orrow, as no imagination could conceive greater.

The Mater, when he aw himelf thus urprized in the midt of his barbarous impiety, tarted up and tood a while with all his faculties attached, with the raging agony of a furious paion; but though his ilent tongue could pay no tribute to his madnes, yet did his hideous countenance in the terrors of an affrighting look, decipher the deperate fury of his enraged mind, whilt his frothing mouth foamed out a dumbe reply; till at length with extremity of paion arrouzed out of his hellih trance, he vomits forth a tream of montrous oaths, as if he went to conjure down a legion of infernal pirits, and bans his men to the pit of hell, and tamps and wears, as if he would tear the Furies out of Tartarus, and binds his oul with an ear-rending oath, hells damned language, to make fih-meat of all thoe audacious villains, that durt interturb him in
thi • mutinous manner; and with that he begins with the fai • Corps of the dead Lady, having ravihed her oul from her, though not her vertue.

But no ooner did Thetis in her Cae • ulean arms embrace this weet body, but on a uddain, the Sun, as ahamed that his beams hould be acceary to uch an execrable deed, muffled up himelf in able clouds, and the sky (as enraged that the merciles Sea hould make prize of that that heaven onely could lay claim unto) muters together whole Armies of clouds to beiege it, the Sea to fortifie it elf againt heavens furious aaults, raied up cloud-caling mountains, and toes the Ship as if it meant to dart it at the skys; with that all the airy inhabitants of the middle region rendezvouz together, and erect vat Towers in the sky, from whence heavens Cannon-hot is dicharged with uch a roaring noie, as if the worlds Axle-tree were napt in under, and both the Poles jumbled together; the rowling billows, foaming with madnes, clamber up to the clouds, where as it were pregnant with night, they are delivered of a horrid darknes, uch a darknes, as if all hells cured inhabitants had belched forth a able fume, or as if the team that acends from burning Phlegeton, Pluto's Cauldron, had over-pread the Hemiphere. Mean while the ditracted Seamen run up and down in a hurly burly, rending the air, and their throats with confued bawling; the Mater bans and raves and torms at the Storm, and commands neither himelf nor they know what, for all his Sea gibberih is born away with the wind, as fat as born out of his sluce-like mouth; the Sails are torn in rags from the Yards, the Yards and Mats hivered in plinters, and the Shrowds napt like burnt twine, mean while the raging Surges mount and ro • l, as if Death were making wa • ry tombes wherein to intert thee heaven-beieged
Souls. At length a breaking Billow came tumbling along, and boarded the hip with uch a force, as plit her in pieces, and rent her temm from her tern. The poor drowning men to ave their lives catcht hold ome on the Prow, others on the Poop, ome on the Mats, others on the Boat, But Neptune bowl'd his waves o fat, that they were oon overwhelmed, and made a prey to the greedy fihes, as the Mater had worn. The Mater, whoe execrable villany had brought this de • truction upon his men, had notwithtanding awhile aved himelf in the Long-boat, and began to bles himelf with the hopes of ecape, but jut Heaven would not permit uch wickednes to go unpunihed, nor Glyceras death to go unrevenged, but ent a furious gut, which tranported a breaking billow into the boat, and both tranported him to the Port of death, and that his death might be the more ignal, there came two Sha • kes jut as he was thrown out of the Boat, and contending for his body, tare it in pieces.

No ooner had heavens blutring executioners put their jut doom in execution, but there grew a tru • e between the Winds and Seas, the Sun giving his Beams as Hotages for the heavens, the Sea demolihing its lofty rampiers, and both • eas and Skies miling each on other, in token the powers above were pacified. Many mall veels that were fihing, ome on the coat of Pelopenneus, others by Cyprus, and others amongt the Aegean Ilands, were cat away in this torm, ome wrackt on the hore, others foundred in the Seas, ome over-et, and others • lit againt the Rocks, o that few or none ecaped, excepting one mall fiher Boat, that had eaonably disburthened it elf of her Mats and goods, and all things that might make her wim deep in the Sea, and with a mall Sail, fatned to the
main Yard, that then erved for a Mat, pooned afore the Wind, and by that means nimbly mounting over the lofty waves, and again gently decending into the low valleys, it aved it elf in the midt of that hideous tempet; but yet was driven from the Euxine promounts, to the place where this Ship was wracked, that is between Peloponneus, and the Iland of Cyprus.

This Veel thus toed hither, by that time the raging Winds were appeaed, and the Seas allayed, might dicern ome ribs of the torn Carkas of the Ship, floating to and fro on Neptunes bowling-green, and here and there Bailes of goods, Chets and Trunks wimming up and down; which the Fihermen perceiving, conjecturing that they were the goods of ome Ship toed in the late torm, they loaded their Veel with thoe things that were of mot worth, and ailed towards Cyprus, intending there to Merchandie their poils; but by that time they had ailed about three hours, the weather growing more and more • erene, the Sun in his mot glitring attire cou • ting the Sea, and the Sea to appear more lovely, moothing her face from wrinkles, and the sky clipping and embracing the Sea with a clear Horizon, they might dicern in a propective glas at a great ditance, omething move upon the Sea like a man, and (as they thought) cating his arms to and fro, to cry for uccour; they with all peed make to him, and within half an hour, came o neer as to perceive it to be a woman, by her dihevelled hair, but till as fat as they sailed to overtake her, he made from them, that in the end they thought her to be ome Mermaid, o that they were clapping on all the Canvas they had aved in the torm, to make hate from her, but by that time they had sailed ome few leagues, they decryed her • aking towards them, with o much wiftnes, as they thought it in vain to flye from her,
but rather determined to tay, untill he came up with them, which was in a hort time, for by that time they had put their Sails in the wind, he was come o neer as they might dicern it to be a orrowful Lady, itting (as on horeback) on a Dolphin, her face, the Index of a grieved mind, eemed to be beauties Coffin, wherein in lamentable Characters, there eemed to be engraven this Epitaph, Here lys heart-enthralling beauty, murdered by heart-breaking orrow. Fain would her breath formed into words, have broken the weet prion of her trembling lips, but grief, their tyrannous Jaylor, would not permit it, but converted them into groans. At length giving liberty to her tongue to Midwive the dolours which her heart pregnant with was in travel withall, he with lamentable demeanor thus pake.

Ah wo is me, wo is me (aid he) but then the tears interrupted her peech, and her eyes to ait her fainting voice in orrows doleful language, dicourt her griefs, but then tears again as it were ratifyed into ighs, and ighs framed into words, he thus lamented her condition.

Ah (aid he) little did I ever think that heaven had thus many plagues in tore for me. Never was poor woman ditret like me; as though one death were not enough to kill a poor dying woman, but I mut daily be tormented with partial deaths, that methinks tear my oul piece-meal from my body; Oh! hew ome mercy to a mierable wretch, a helples, hopeles, forlorn, foraken woman, beet with remediles dolo ••• , and pity my orrows, as you would ever hope that heaven hould commierate you, when you are beieged with the terrors of death-threatning calamities, which how oon may be your lot is known only to the great dipoer of our fates.

Thee doleful expreions, expreed o dolefully by a Lady beleagured with extremity of miery, would have crued tears from a Rock, and made an Adamant turn Niobe, but yet took no impreion upon the Mater, but he rather (like an inhumane Churl) commands them to ail away, What (aid he) have we nothing to do but to mind a foolih womans babling? let her alone to prate to the Dolphin, and mind you your employments. But no ooner had he tacked about to be gone, but the poor Lady gave a hriek would have rent a heart in under, and cryed out to them as loud as her feeble voice could utter; Oh! (aid he) have your hearts made a league with cruelty? though your ears hould be deaf to the lamentable crys of a ditret woman, yet methinks, your eyes might intercede a little for me with your rocky hearts. Oh that ever o much barbarous immanity hould lodge in humane ouls! methinks it might hame you to ee a Dolphin more merciful than your elves. Shame, do I ay? alas hame is vertues attendant, and reides not where vertue is exil'd, and vertue is ever exil'd from an obdurate heart. Oh you powers above, will you give no truce to my orrows? mut I be quite bereft of all relief? and then he gave a groan, as if he had torn her vital trings, and lifting up her eyes and hands, he thus implored Heaven:

Since it is your will (aid he) to drench and pickle up my oul in Briny orrows, to preerve it pure and untainted, and that the tormy guts of advere fortune mut drive me through a Sea of Tears, ere I can arrive at the Haven that hall put an end to the turmoiling Navigation of this life; Oh then (aid he) let this alo he your will, that when that atome of time, that inconiderable intant that links pat and future, hall unlink my oul from my body; then, oh then, let
it arrive at that blet Elizium, where one eternal indiviible moment chains refined ouls to an immortality of unconceivable felicity.

The Fiher-men hearing thee woful complaints, began to be enraged at the Maters avage cruelty, and in a mutinous manner, with threatnings compelled him to relieve her; the Dolphin all this time, as if by ome intinct from Heaven, wimming o near the Veel, as that they could cat a Rope to draw her in; which in the end they did, the Mater not daring to oppoe.

The Veel thus fraught, with more Treaure than all the Eatern Junks or Caravans, (her Eyes rich Cakets of Diamonds, containing more Gems, and her Breath more Aromatick Spices, than ever yet adorned and perfumed the Orient) moved with oft and gentle Gales, thus moothly lyded along the Seas Briny urface, for the pace of 48 hours; at the end of which, they arrived at Cyprus.

The Mater, who while he was at Sea, terrified with the bold threatnings of his men, durt not vent his Cruelty towards this poor Lady; yet being at Cyprus, he reolved to revenge the affronts he received for her ake, upon her; and to that end, one night, when he had after great intreaties, given her his promie for permiion to go ahore, he unknown to any, old her to an ill-favoured Rutick, that had all the marks of Deformity almot about him; who in a rude manner haled her ahore, and that night conveyed her to his Cottage, ome miles ditant from the Sea, intending the next morning to compleat his felicity by marriage.

But when Glycera aw that Heaven had redeemed her out of a Purgatory of miery, to fling her into a Hell of calamities, Oh, with what doleful lamentations did he (ad Lady) conume the night? Now wring her hands and groan, as if he rang her own Knell; and then
weep and ob, as if her Eyes and Lungs, rivalls in Sorrow, had contended which hould expres mot to the life, a killing Paion. Sometimes her fainting pirits, as not able to endure the intollerable tyranny of domineering Grief, would eem condened into Tears, which diffued through the flood-gates of her Eyes, would leave her urprized with dying languor: but then her enes retored to their natural functions, orrow, with a vigorous impetuounes, would break the damms of moderation, and like a Torrent for a while retrained, return with greater fury. Sometimes he would begin to importune Heaven for mercy: O thou great Rector of our Detinies (aid he) mut my heart be the Rendevouz, where all mieries meet? Thou art the Circumference, from whence thee black lines of Adverity tream; mut I be the Centre where they terminate? Oh let not tyrannizing orrow uurp thy Prerogative over all my Faculties, and ubject thoe Powers to its Rule, which onely ought to obey thy Divine Impoitions: Oh detroy not the oul which thou hat made, nor let my Perdition anticipate that Glory which thou didt propoe to thy elf in my Creation; but hew mercy, if ever hew mercy, hew mercy to one ubmert in miery.

Having aid this, he would paue a while, as it were litning what Anwer Heaven would return, and with ome faint ighs, eem as it were to parley with Death; and then a chilly Palenes would arret her Countenance, as if Heaven, mindeful of her Petitions, had hung out their white Flagg of Truce, and diplayed it in her face, as a Token of that inviolable League, hould ere long be contracted between her oul, and eternal Blis; and that now they were ending their black Embaador Death, to ign and eal the Articles.

Dear Danpion excue me, if I am thus Copious in the
relation of this ad Ladies misfortune; but truly, when I heard the tory firt related by the Knight (that (as I told you) lately came from Cyprus, and heard her elf relate, what his eyes were not pectators of) I could not but ilently bequeath ome drops to the ground; drops do I ay? Alas, had I not been in Pandion's preence, but where I might have let looe the reigns to my Paion, I could have drowned my elf in Tears; for methoughts I felt my vey oul transformed into orrow it elf. But to proceed, thus I ay, She lamentably pent this lamentable night, in Weeping, Sighing, Sobbing, Groaning, Praying, till the bright morning had dipelled the hadowes of the mity night, and Aurora wrapping up her face in a Vermilion-mantle, ilently bewailed her orrows in Crytal Tears.

When Lacon (for o was the Rutick named) awaked by his own loud noring, called to mind his new Bride, and ravihed with joy, his heart clambring up into his mouth, almoat choaked him with exces of contentment, he aries, and in hate runs to bles his Eyes with the ight of her Beauty, and ere he or he was aware, tumbles upon her, who had choen the darket corner in the Cottage, to lament her mieries; and when he aw her elf thus urprized, modety o weetly apparelled her Face, in a Vermilion veture, as that her Cheeks, beprinkled with Tears, looked like Roes impearled with Heavenly dew.

No ooner did Lacon behold his new Sweet-hearts weet-heart-attracting feature, but her Eyes, that might vye Stars with Heaven, darted uch parkling glances, as oon et on fire the tinder of his Affections; o that tranported with the Extaies of love, he boytrouly eizeth on her, and after his rude manner, proffers to fix the Seal of his Affections on her melting Lips: Come (aid he) weet Lombe, let me bus thy
Honny-combe Lips, and with that, by force he mackt her, as if he was ucking the weet contained in thoe Vermilion Hives of Beauty.

Much of the day being pent in this manner, Lacon Wooing, and Glycera Weeping, he labbering her Cheeks with his frothy Lips, and he bedewing his with her Pearly Tears, at length he reolved to conummate his joyes with Marriage, and compels her to go with him to Venus-Temple, to acrifize a pair of Turtle-Doves, thereby to procure the Goddees Benediction. But all the way as he went, uch a Mart of Beauties met in her weet Countenance, as purchaed her as many Admirers, as Beholders, and Beholders, as Perons; her Eyes inviting all eyes to behold, and her uper-eminent Excellencies, alluring all Beholders to adore her; o that few there were, whoe Sex rendred them not incapable to enjoy her Perfections, but would have even pawned their ouls to have bought o rich a Treaury of Beauties.

Her beautious Face, wherein hined the Perfection of all Perfections, was a viible heart-melting Muick; which, as if compoed of Charmes, entranc't Spectators, and truck Harmonious Raptures into adoring mindes. Thus were the Eyes, and Hearts, and Tongues of all led Captive by her Beauty, and forced to pay the Tribute of looking, loving, and commending, to the overaignty of her Excellencies.

At length Supertition wedded to Admiration, begat a conceit in their mindes, that ure he was more than what her external form pake her to be; for there eemed a greater mixture of Divine Exellencies in her Beauty, than ever frail Mortality could boat of; and her trancendent Glories eemed to run Parallel with thoe that have bribed Supertitious ouls to a • ribe Divinity to Venus: o that in the end, they thought it the

Amongt the many Captives, that were enthralled by Glyceras Beauty, whoe hearts were drawn by its magnetick force, it eems, this Knight was one; who (as I told you) is the relater of of thee ad tydings, whoe fortune it was to epie her, as he paed along to the Temple: But no ooner were his eyes fixed on her, but he, as a burning Mirour, wherein all the rayes of Beauty centred, inflamed his heart with the pure fire of chat Affection; and perceiving her Eyes with an inundation of Tears ready to overflow their own Beauties and with ilent lamentation to bewail her perecuted innocency, (for though he endeavoured to uppres any inurrections of Paion, what he could, yet Nature would exact ome tears, that wonted Tribute, that grief extorts in uch like Accidents) but I ay, oberving that internal orrow he dicloed in her Countenance, which (as he rightly interpreted it) could be for nothing, but that he, uch a miracle of Beauty, hould be linked in Hymeneal Conjunction with uch a Monter of deformity, he aid was o moved with compaion, that he thought he felt the quintesence of each tear ditil down into his Soul; and didaining that uch a wonder of Uglines, hould be his Corrival in affection, who might more aptly have contended in Rivalry with ome of Pluto's fiends for deformity, he drew his Sword, and compelled him to reign her up to himelf, unles he prized a moments ight of her, above his life.

No ooner Lacon aw the naked teel, but he flies like an Arrow out of a Bow, not for his wiftnes, but
for the reemblance his hrimpih-limgut body had to an Arrow, as each legg had to a Bow; and all the way as he goes, he howls, and yells, as if he had been beet with armed Theeves; o that in a hort pace, uch a concoure of People urrounds the Knight, and his Lady, as if ome wonder had dropped down from Heaven; ome coming to behold the beauty of the Lady, whoe perfections fame, in o high a tyle, had proclamed in their ears, but could not obtrude upon their belief; others to ee what was the reaon of that Tumult: So that though at firt Glycera was the wonder that drew the concoure, yet at length the concoure it elf became the wonder.

And as is the manner of uch Plebeian diorders, they eldom end without ome laughter; and o it happened here: For eeing the Knight with his Sword drawn, many thought he would have offered violence to the Lady; others hearing Lacon's roaring, thought he had murdered him; others that were no les wounded with her Beauty, than the Knight that had ravihed her from Lacon, and thought their Swords might purchae them as good a Title to her, as he, reolved either to have her, or his life, or both; o that in an intant there was nothing to be heard, but clahings of Swords, cryes of dead men, and all the ymptomes of reigning confuion.

The Knight, that for a great pace had gallantly defended himelf and his Lady, making many of the bodies of his Oppoers fall, and do homage to his rage, and their ouls, which, to what their bodies had done, would not conent, he ent to Tartarus, there to endure an eternal Vaalage under Pluto: But yet having no other Bulwark than his Buckler, to fortifie himelf againt the incurions of his Enemies, he at lat received a Wound, out of which uch plenty of Blood effued,
that he was forced to urrender up himelf, and his Lady to the mercy of his Opponents, and by that means, he ecaped from amongt them.

But now the quarrel grew as hot amongt themelves, which hould bear away the Prize; every man accounting the los of his blood a cheap price, to purchae o rich a Treaure; thus there grew no end of their diorders, till at length ome Officers from the King came, and with the Point of the Sword of Jutice, put a full point and Period to the rude cufflings of this Rabble.

But when enquiry was made after Glycera, no newes could be heard of her; for taking her opportunity, when her bloody Suters were all pleading their Interets, with the Swords harp-peircing Rhetorick, he ecaped away in the Crowd, and fled to a Wood not farr ditant, where he pent all that night in bewailing her orrowful etate; where her Soul would quaff in huge draughts of woe, which, as not able to concoct, he would pour out again in Tears; Tears, that fell like melted Stars from the Heaven of her Beauty.

Thus did he give up her elf to the dominion of an unreaonable Paion, which yet her Paion perwaded her was reaonable. Sometimes grief would permit her thus to lament her Woes: Oh Me! of all women ditret! Mut I be he in whom mieries combine together, to make mierable? Mut all things have their tint, but my griefs alone be boundles? The Sea hath its hore, the Winds their limits, the Earth its centre, and this pacious Globe of Heaven and Earth its circumference; but Ah! No hore, no limits, no centre, no circumference to my orrows: No hore to the Seas of my Tears, no limits to the Wind of my ighs, no centre to my deep-rooted griefs, nor no circumference to the infinity of my mieries: But I am become Fortunes
Ware-houe, where he hoords up her tore of orrowes; Hells Butt, where my Innocency is the White, at which they hoot their invenomed Arrowes, Winged with Malice, and Piled with Detruction; and Heavens Tennis ball, when if with the vehemency of the blow, my Soul chance to bound upwards towards a Heaven of hope (for grief is ever at the lowet, when it is at the highet; and extremity of miery, is ever the dawning of mercy;) I ay, if it chance to bound, ome dimal Accident takes me at the re-bound, and toes me into a Hell of calamities: Come then Death, come quickly, bend thy Bow, and end thy harp-piled Arrowes into this Pile of Dut, that entombs my Soul. But then her Breats would be brim-full with a raging pang, which would truggle for birth; but in triving to vent all, it could vent nothing, but only top the paage of her peech; till at length her breath would be delivered of a Groan, which capring thorow the Bowes and Leaves, would be re-bounded to her Ears by Eccho; which Glycera hearing, the better to pas away the mournful hours of the night, began thus to entertain a Dialogue with her; which becaue the Knight thought worthy the relation to Pandion, as well as I can remember, I hall relate to you.

Who is that (aid Glycera) derides my miery? I, aid Eccho. Who is that I? Is it Eccho? • Tis Eccho. What dot thou mock at woe? No. No ure, thy own woes might make thee pity mine. Pity mine. Thy griefs indeed would extort pity from the •• intiet heart, but oh! What grief's like mine? Mine. • Tis true, thine might extract the tribute of a bleeding-eye. I. But ure my orrows need pity too. Need pity too. Tell me then Eccho, mut thee griefs till per •• ver? Ever. Ever? That's a ad doom; what, mut my mieries alwayes proceed? Seed. What, no ooner • ipe,
and blown, but Seed again? Gain. Gain indeed, to exchange a few joyes, for a million of orrows; but yet, O that Heaven would releae me of my Bargain. Bare gain. Bare gain certainly, to ell my Soul for ighs and Tears; but oh, when hall I find releae? Leae What, not till my lifes Leae is out? But when that's done, whither hall I then fly? High. What, to the Elizium of eternal blis? Yes. When once arrived there, what hall my Soul enjoy? Joy. What joyes are thoe that inhabit the Heaven Empyreal? Real. Mean time will not Heaven hear my cry? Cry. That I have oft done, but yet had no reply. Ply. What if I hould Ply it till, what Medicine will Heaven apply to my Dieae? Eae. What if I hall forbear vocal or mental Prayer? Erre. Why, will not Heaven hear the hrill moans of ditre • t Innocence? No ene. Why are there any cryes more hrill? Ill. Ill cryes aloud for vengeance; but oh, the weet perfumes that acend from the chat Innocent. No ent. What can uch weet exhalations yeeld no ent? No ent. Why is it that uch a redolent Balm as Innocencye, which acends to Heaven, as a perpetual Sacrifice, hould yeeld without Prayer no ent? Without Prayer nocent. When the nocent prayes, what return doth Heaven make to his deire? Ire. What Anwer will Heaven return, if the Innocent pray? Ray. A Ray of Love, or Light, or both? Both. Which of the Powers ublime can affect a Mortal? All. When a beam of Love hines from Heaven into a Mortal, what part doth it comfort? Fort. The Fort or Life, where the oul chiefly retires; which is that part? Heart. How long will uch Divine conolations tay? Ay. For ay will they abide? Bide. Oh Heavenly newes! But, Echo how com't thou to be of Heavens Privy-Counel? Didt e're fly o nigh the Gods, as to read
