the Records of Detiny? Nigh. Thou art mortal as well as I, art thou not? Not. Art thou not born below, among the Trees, and Dens, and Caves, re-ounding when we hollow? Low. But prethee Echo, tell me, what made thee pine for coy Na • cius love? Love. And what became of thy weet body? O dy. Where went thy oul, when thou grieving aw't thy Narcius tears o many hed? Vanihed. What inchanted Charms were in his beauteous Face, to effect o trange a transformation? Ah, hone. And could his hining-beauty thee o oon annihilate? Late. What didt thou do, when thou awet him Metamorphoed into a Flower? Lowre. And what, when thou heardt his lat groan? Groan. And what did the Woods do, when he pin'd with the ight of his own beauty in the Spring? Ring. And what hat thou done, ever ince Heaven did tranmute thy hape? Ape. Since then thou art nothing but a Mortals Ape, how knowet thou Heavens Decrees o well? Well. How cant thou pry into their Deignes, who all earthborn Mortals in widom o urmount? Mount. And will the Gods above none from their Counels exclude? Lewd. Art thou not lewd, that for fond Nar
• iu's love dot moan inceantly? Lye. Sure uch unchat affection is not holy. Oly. But I have vowed to live for ever chat. Hate? And doth not uch a vow oblige to chatity? Tye, tye. Well, ince it tyes me o, I'll hence be gone. Be gone. And through Heavens aitance perform what I have vowed to do. Do.

Thus did poor Gl • cera • rive to divert the thoughts of her miery, omtimes by dicouring with Echo, omtimes be • oaning to her elf her own hard fortune omtimes praying to Heaven for relief, omtimes wihing for Death, and if he chanced to hea • a whi • r • ng
wind, flutter among the Leaves, her orrow would perwade her fancy to conceit it to be ome Meenger of Heaven or Death, to bring her the tidings of a reprival, or removal from her tate of woe; and if a whipering blat chanced to re-bound to her from the Leaves, preently grief would repreent to her fancy Deaths Arrowes inging her Elogies, as they flew to her obvious heart.

Thus did he pend that night, in wayling, weeping, ighing, obbing, grieving, groaning, till Titan's fiery Steeds had chaed away the leer luminaries, that had uurped his Throne; but yet no Day-break of hope dawned upon her with beams of comfort, but in that woful depairing condition, did he run through invious Woods, rocky Dearts, and hollow Caves, where night kept houe, with mournful olitarines, and over hills and mountains inhabited only by the Clouds, until at length he came into a pleaant Vale, incircled with a murmuring River, which eemed with ilent mutterings to repine at her orrows; and over-pread with a gloomy hade, by reaon of hanging Rocks, that defended it from the Suns invaion, eemed, as it were, d • eed in funeral-attire to mourn for Glycera's orrows.

Glycera oberving this Vale to be a fit place, where he might bid her Adieu to the world, and all ublunary contentments, reolved there to it her down, and dye: For of four dayes and nights, that he had wandred through thoe Dearts, had he not received the leat utenance; and therefore her fainting pirits, too weak Chains to faten her Soul to her Body, were oft ready to let looe their Prioner.

By this River he at down, and prayed to Heaven, to let looe the bands of Life, and not to retard low-pac'd Death any longer, but to conort her among
the hades, that wander in the Elizium Plains: And further begg'd, That when Death hould crumble her body to Atomes, and reolve it into individual Units, that then her oul might be united to the great and only Eternal Individual, and dwell among thoe beatified Souls, that float like Atomes in the Sun-hine of his replendent glory.

This having aid, he laid her down upon the Brink of the mournfully-grumbling River, and cloed her Eyes, thinking never more to behold the loathed Light, and hourly expected the weet Gaol-delivery of her oul; but the Detinies that had inter-woven, and twited the Threeds of her life, and miery, o together, as neither could be clipped aunder, without clipping both, reolved that the bottom of her life, and miery, hould not yet be unwound by the wounds of Death; but nevertheles, a little to ap • eae the ragings of an uncontroulable Paion, they arrowed a humid Vapour out of its moit bed of dirt, and ent it to unlock her Pores, and uher in a gentle leep.

But no ooner had leep allayed the urges of Paion, but Morpheus began to form trange •• antams in her imagination: Somtimes he would erect a high precipice in her Fancy, o high, as the blended Clobe of earth and water would look like an Atom, and then tumble her down from thence, into ome profound abys, peopled with Adders, Toads, and Snakes, and other venemous vermine; and then he would tart and give a hriek, that the whole Foret would re • ound with the Eccho; but then the purlings of the ilver tream would huh her aleep again; and then the drowie Deity would Plant a Foret in her Brain, where he would digg dens for Lions, Bears, and howling Wolves, and build nets for Owls, Batts, and Night-Ravens, and other Birds of darknee, and then the
howling, roaring, bellowing, hrieking, croaking of thee wild inhabitants, would attach her faculties with hideous terrors, and imprion them in amazement.

Thus in a confued manner he pent the greatet part of the night, till about the time when Orion begins to bath himelf in the Ocean, and the Lamps near conumed, he heard a rutling among the leaves and boughs, which putting her in mind of her dream, obt • uded on her fancy a conceit, that it mut needs be ome wild beat, that roving through the Foret, ought for prey, whe • eat exceedingly atonihed, he flyes, as if fear and amazement had added wings to her heels, but, ah! to overtake her own ad fate, for as he was paing by a hollow cave (hollow-hearted indeed to her, though otherwie repleat with michief) there uddenly iued out a avage Ruffin, that ere he was aware, catcht her about her wate, and not at all regardi • g her • uful cries and groans, uch as would have melt • d a Rock of Adamant, uch as would have in • ued a
• ne-di • tracting grief into a Fury, though hardened with quotidian cruelty, he flings her upon the ground, and draws out a harp Ponyard, and threatens with that to peirce her heart, if he peedily urrendred not h • r body (that weet Temple, where Vertue lay inhrined, and potles thoughts were the pure ob
•• ions offered on the Altar of a chat heart) to the poll • tions of his filthy lut.

Glycera perceiving her inability to contend by force, by reaon of her faintnes, with a voice that hewed a heart fearles of death, returned him this re • ly. Lutful Villain (aid he) dot thou think that the p • ircing of a heart, can be a piercing terror, to a heart already peirced with killing orrow? the Antipathies between life and death, are too much reconciled in me by the
terrors of aiduous deaths, ever to be terrified with thy death-threatning avagenes, harpen thy Ponyard then with the Whettone of thy Marble-hearted cruelty, and when thou hat done, heath it in my heart; but then know, that it hall prove a Pandora's box, filled with thouands of mieries, which hall flutter forth out of that wound, and by heavens vengeance glewed to thy oul, hall at length poes thee with a terror, that will make thee exercie a death upon thy elf, more horrid than this that hell now prompts thee to exercie upon me; and the very teams that will acend from my reaking blood, hall become a thunder, which whereever skulkt, hall find thee out, and
• end thee into more pieces than hell will have Furies to torment.

Foolih woman (aid he) tell not me of heaven, hell or Furies, I know no other heaven, but atiating my deires, no other hell than uch dilatory interruptions of my pleaure, when extremity of deire breeds impatiency, nor other Fury, than a petilent imperious woman, uch as thou; therefore I tell thee, once more, reign up thy elf to my lut, or, by heavens (if there be any) I'le take thee by torm, as impregnable as thou thinkt thy elf, and quench the flames of my lut in thy heart bloud. The fear of death (he replyed) hath impreion upon none, but uch Villains as thou, whoe mutty ouls horror triking guilt corrodes; but as for me, my oul is carryed on the wings of Vertue, out of the reach of thoe terrors, therefore if thou wilt or if thou durt, broach my heart, and make thy oul drunk with cruelty, thou wilt but make a paage for my oul to fly to thoe manions, where happines dwells eentially.

Thy vertue? (aid he) flatter not thy elf wi •• that, for I'le plunder thee of that totally, and oh, that my
Steeletto could reach thy oul too, I'de nail it to the ground, from whence it hould never fly to fetch revenge; but no matter, when I have poured out my lut into the kennel of thy body, I'le wah away with thy blood thoe pollutions wherewith thy oul in the commixture may have tained mine. This aid, he binds her fair hands with her hair, that lovely hair, that had fettered and bound o many hearts, mut now bind her own hands, and tears her garments, and in depight of all her hrieking, groaning, crying, weeping, he at length unloads his lut, and not content only to plunder her of her honor, after he had thus demolihed the Cittadel of her vertue, but he with his Ponyard dienthrones thoe powers, that hould govern her faculties, and eals pale death in the majetick throne of her Beauty; and thus he leaves her like a fair flower nipt with the mornings Frot, hanging down her head, as if ahamed of her declining glory; her face covered with hoary palenes, as if deaths cold blat had congealed the dew of her tears into a hoary Frot.

But by this time the Sun having notice of the Tragedies acted in his abence, by Nights permiion, had ent the morning as his Scout, to draw the Curtain of the night, and decry whether any uch horrid Villanies, as even reounded thorough the arches of heaven, were committed under the protection of the Night; whilt he came after with an Army of beams to depoe her from her Throne of Jet: but no ooner had he haken his dewy locks, wet with toying too long with Thetis in her watery bower, but he beheld this ravihed wounded Lady; and no ooner beheld than he ent his light to call away a loytring dream that was ent of an Embaie from heaven to Polienus, a great Nobleman of Crete, that dwelt in that Foret, to inform of this cured act, and to command him to revenge
her. When a deep ilence hath fixt an intenenes upon the ouls faculties, then is the fittet time for divine impreions. Though exemption from ad fates, is not alwaies entailed upon innocence, yet that uneen Nemeis that runs through the whole machine of the univere, eldom connives at the wrongs of ditret Vertue.

The bloody wretch had no ooner ent his Ponyard as a meenger of death to her, but heaven tabbed his oul with horrors, that in a frenzy he leaps from a Rock, and dahes his body into as many pieces, as his oul was torn with Fu • ies. So apt a death did heaven prepare for one, whoe rocky heart had broke the neck of a Ladies chatity. Polienus, who (as I aid) had been divinely informed of this Ladies miery, awakens out of his dream, and eemes to have a bloody mit before his eyes, that repreents all things to his urprized fancy, horrid and tragical; o that in amazement he aries, lips on his morning Gown, takes his word in his hand, and hats he knows not whither, to ait he knows not what. But the heavenly powers who make ue of earthly intruments to execute their reaonable decrees, whilt men only act their own unreaonable paions; and range humane diorders into a divine kind of order; o ordered his diorderly teps, as that in a hort moment, he came to a place where he heard a mournful groan, which uhered in thee words, Heavens! eparate my potles oul, from this defiled body, and as my life doth, o oh! let the extravagant follies of my youth, pas out together. Oh! Receive me, where vertue hall ever be defended from all Villous invaions.

Polienus hearing this runs in a deep amazement ome paces farther, till he finds this poor Lady in a condition to have confirmed an Atheit, but con • uted a
Stoick by converting him into a weeping Heraclitus. For he lay imbalmed in her own blood, her hands entangled in her hair, and in her houlder there tuck a Ponyard that made a paage for uch treams of bloud, as deluged thoe beauties that inhabited her skin. Polienus eeing this woful pectacle, tood as if a profound ene of her miery, had truck him into an inenibility.

At length recovering himelf he runs to her, natches out the Steel that lay bathed in a fountain of blood, and tops up the wound, and feels her pule, to ee if life had yet foraken its fortres the heart, where it lat retires, and perceiving the living bloud to move in her veins, and ent as an Envoy from the heart, to acquaint him, that though life was treightly beieged in its Cittadel, with quadrons of pangs, yet it had not quite urrendered to the government of death, he repairs the bloody breach, as well as he could, and runs home and fetched men from his Catle, that conveyed her thither with all peed upon a downy Couch; where her ent for Chirurgions with peed to her, who with their extraordinary care and skill, in a few days retored her to her primitive health and beauty. When Polienus aw that he was recovered, and no pretence of weaknes could hinder his enquiry what hould be the caue of her miery, he uing omething more freedom of dicoure than ordinary, requeted her to acquaint him, whether ome direful chance, arm'd with merciles and inevitable fate, or ome accured hand had endeavoured to put that untimely date, to her life and happines? Glycera conidering what great engagements he had laid upon her, and that he might be jutly thought ungrateful, if he hould deny o poor a requet, and therefore related to him the whole tory of her mifortunes; how he fled from the Nunnery in Thealia,
to avoid the tedious Love of Pandion; and how natcht up by a Pirate, who at Sea endeavoured to ravih her, and then how in his rage, being diappointed of his deires, he threw her over-board; but then how he was mot miraculouly preerved by a Dolphin (that faithful friend to mankind in adverities) upon whom he had rid up and down for the pace of everal hours without any hope of uccour; how he was relieved by a Fiherman, and by him brought to Cyprus, but when he had conveyed her hither, how in all particulars he miued her, not permitting her to go ahore, and then to make amends for all his abues, how at lat he old her to a deformed Swain, that carried her to his cottage, and how the next day, as he was going to be joyned with him by Hymens bands in Venus Temple, a Knight came and recued her from him, but then what a tumult there was raied with the ruticks roaring, and how that occaioned a combate, between the Knight and others, that thought to have forc't her from him, as he had from Lacon; how at length he was forc't to reign her up to them, by that means to ave himelf: but then how when they had obtained their prize, they could not agree among themelves, but fell upon one another, with as much fury as before they did upon the Knight, and how he perceiving an opportunity for ecape, fled into that Foret, where he had wandered uccourles, and hopeles of uccour for everal days and nights.

But when he came to relate the dimall tory of her dihonor (poor Lady) the tears fell from a cloud of orrows, that over-pread the heaven of her beauty, jut as if that tranparent cloud that encircles heavens hollow arches, had been condened into • Crytal hower, and her faltring tongue left it to her countenance, in orrowful and yet bahful igns to declare her miery, and
there you might have plainly een the pourtraicture of her bleeding honor, adumbrated to the life in her bluhing Cheeks.

Polienus oberving her paionate grief, grew more inquiitive about the caue, o that with vehement importuning he crued thus much from her, in a broken manner, that a villain would have forced her, and would have killed her. As oon as Polienus heard this, he felt his heart even divided between the two paions of pity and revenge, at length pity augmenting revenge, gave that the overaignty over his will; o that in a fury he kneels down, and implores heaven, that the vengeance due to uch an accured act might light on him, if he permitted that to the unrevenged; and with that Glycera having given him a Character of him, as well as he could, he takes his word, and mounts his Steed, and o rides out into the Foret in purute of this wretch, but ere he had gone a quarter of a mile, he found him dead upon the ground, having broke his neck with the fall from the Rock. When Polienus aw this, he was glad that heavens vengeance had found him out, but orry that any one had been the executioner beides himelf, but however he goes home to his Catle, and commands his men to fetch the body, and give it to his dogs.

Jutice thus being done upon him, Glycera began a little to allay the pangs of orrow, that daily had wont to tir up ome great commotions in her bret, and to entertain ome mall familiarity with mi • th, which had o long been exiled from her, o that in a hort time he was retored to her health, and pri •• ine beauty, which thoe excellencies before drowned in orrow, now wimming in her countenance, ufficiently tetified, o that Polienus who before beheld her only with compaion, now looks upon her with admiration, for he
eemed to him not compoed of the common principles, but of ome heavenly materials, even refined to an immateriality, fit to captivate an immaterial oul, o that at length he never viewed her, but he aw ome weetnes, ome grace, ome delicacy, that gradually converted his admiration into affection, and by an imperceptible acenion gave love the overaignty over his heart; and now Glycera, and none but Glycera grew the object of his thoughts, the ubject of his dicoure, and the joy of his heart. Long did Polienus cover his affection with the veil of ilence, but love, though its chiefet reidence is in the heart, yet it will oft peep forth at the Caements of the eyes, and like the Bee, though its dwelling is in the Hive of the heart, yet it mut come forth to feed it elf with the heavenly weets imparadized in thoe flowers that grow in the Garden of Beauty; o Polienus though he endeavoured to conceal his griefs, yet his eyes would dicloe what his heart incloed, for if ever he was in her preence, her beauties attracted both his eyes and heart, and the radiant beams that glanc'd from hers would eem to trike upon his heart trings, and compoe uch a oft entrancing melody, as he thought he felt his very Soul charmed into a love extaie.

Polienus thus oberving daily how love did degree it elf into his heart, and a crowd of inevitable inconveniences iuing thereupon, thronging into his undertanding, he trove to uppres all inurrections of that paion that thus endeavoured to depoe his will, and make his Reaon do homage to it what he could. For you mut know, this Polienus was one of prime quality, having both a great wit, and a greater fortune, o that what the former could devie, the latter could accomplih; his peron alo not being meanly beautiful, yet his beauty coniting in a mean between a maculine
comelines, and a feminine weetnes, and one who as he was never a hater, o neither ever any great admirer of the female ex, but looked on them as piles of well complexioned dut, that like Sodoms Apples with the leat touch of Times finger would moulder to nothing, or as Natures painted Gallipots, where you may meet as oft with poion as with a potion; where he aw Vertue enhrined in the Temple of Beauty, there he could even adore, and counted uch as Angels inveted in refined fleh, but where he aw Vertue lye bleeding in a Roie cheek, and Lillyed beauty to erve only for Chatities winding heet, thoe he counted as Devils clothed in an Angels form, and born to tempt men to recede from vertue, and ent to be plagues to the minds of men, and preerved for eternal petilence to the world.

This Polienus had been beloved by Amoroia daughter to Loritus King of Cyprus, a Lady whoe accomplihments might well have challenged a reciprocal affection, having a delicate wit treaured in the Ivory Cabinet of a beautiful body, and as he had powerful paions in a great mind, o her mind had great power over her paions, o that long he could conceal her love, ealing it under the impreion of her memory; but (you know) love is uch a trong paion that you may as well think to queez down the Sun-beams, and hinder their reflection, as to uppres the flames of love, but in depight of all oppoition, yea the more for oppoition, they will rebound from the heart to the eyes, and are legible there to any that are not unacquainted with the Characters of affections; and beides, in women that paion is ever mot viible, their Ivory fairenes is but as white paper where they pourtray the picture of their minds, which their tongues are loth to betray, their thin skins being as tranparent Crytal, through
which the beams of love wil hine, & therefore the mot Chat in that repect have not the gift of continence, but though they may think to Cloyter up Love as a Reclue in the chat Nunneries of their hearts, yet alas, upon the leat allurements of their beloveds beauty, they will uffer all uch vain reolves to be ravihed from them, and their eyes and tongues to be wedded to a heart-inflaming eye; o it was with Amoroia, in his abence, his praies was all the entertainment of her dicoure, in his preence, her eyes mut move with his, as if the beams that came from his had chained hers, and as oft as he pake, he mut accent her entences with ighs, by thoe fumes plainly dicovering the fire in her heart; which though Polienus oberved, yet he would not be oberved to have oberved it, but rather penned down his obervations in the leiger of his memory.

But Amoroia's affection that had thus long been imprioned in her heart, would no longer endure retraint, but mut either come forth, or break the prion, o that no longer able to endure the unupportable tyranny of her paion, he goes to Polienus, and with as much eloquence as a mind wracked between the extremiti • s of two violent paions, Love and Fear, and ditracted with the contrary thoughts of pondering how to peak, and whether to peak at all, could frame, deciphering firt in her weet countenance the prologue of her dicoure, he diplays the torehoue of her deires, and withall craves of him to poize them in the ballances of honor, and not to let this condecenion of hers exhale any mits of uncharitable thoughts, that might obcure her Vertue.

Polienus oberving in what cotly robes both her peech and countenance was apparelled, the former clad in the refined Go • d of eloquence even dazled his
mind with admiration, but in the latter uch a Majety clothed in purple at inthroned, as eemed rather to dazle than delight, o that he could not but wonder, though he could not love, or rather he wondred why he could not love; but though her perwaive peeches, and peaking looks could not dart affection into him, yet they even tran • fixt his heart with compaion, which procured from him only a hort reply, wihing that heaven would crown him with o much happines, as to raie his merits to that height, that deervedly he might be eated in the throne of her heart, but till then he craved pardon if he rejected her ute, and begged of her, rather to accue his fortunes than him, that did thus incapacitate him to atisfie o great a debt as the high honor he had done him did oblige him to. But however, ince he could not retaliate her affection, nor retribute her unparallel'd favours, yet he would accept them with a deire to compenate, when his benign Stars hould bles him with a poibility.

With this anwer he went home, endeavoring to cat as charitable a glos upon it, as expreions of o deep a able dye would bear; o eaie it is to circumvent a oul that beholds all things through the refracted medium of affection, which will repreent things treight though in themelves never o oblique. Thus he remained for a long time, great with child with expectation of ome not only verbal but real tetimonies of Polienus's affection, and longed for that time that hould Midwive ome uch happy production. But Polienus, whoe heart was not con • ederate with his tongue, meant her no uch felicity, as appeared by thoe exquiite methods he ued to avoid and anwer her importunities.

Amoroia oberving no fruit of her endeav • r • , and
her hopes to wane, but depair growing to the full, began to wax pale and wan, and pine away; and thoe beauties that had hitherto retained their lutre, though weather-beat • n with the tormy frowns of misfortune, as if they had been immarceible, now began to fade with his cold replies, like a fair flower nipt with the morning Frot; thus did her love feed upon her beauty, as if Cupid were turned Cannibal, and would devour his mother for want of other repat. Concealed affection is like a Wolf in a womans Breat, if no other refection be provided, be ure it feeds on that. The imilitudes indeed are homely, but apt and • ignificative to expres the nature of imprioned paion.

Loritus her Father oberving her withered beauty on a day, trictly charged her to tell him what was the worm that bit the root of o weet a flower, and withall promied that the one half of his Kingdom hould freely be given to purchae her content; with that he gave him a full relation of her unucceeding affection.

Loritus hearing this, ends with peed for Polienus, and moothing the rough furrows of his countenance (being a little moved, when he firt heard how his Daughter was rejected) he endeavors with oft and mild perwaions to allure his conent to his own felicity: but when he aw all to be in vain, he conjures him by all the terrifying words, and enraged mind could indite, and Majety utter, to give him his final anwer, which was only this, that Nature had engaged him to perpetual Chatity.

Thee words were as fire, put under the Cauldron of his boyling blood; o that he wears by J • ve, that if ever he heard, that he inned againt the Oblig • tion, in what ever remote corner of the wide Univere • e lurked, his
Revenge, like Lightning, hould find him out, and hurl him to detruction: And believe me (aid he) Kings words reach from Pole to Pole, and run parallel with all Climates.

Polienus hearing this, fearing he hould be entrapt with the delicate Baits of beauty that Court did abound in, he equetred himelf wholly from their ociety, and built him a tately Catle, where now Glycera found him.

But I have too much digreed with this long relation, yet it is only to hew what Squadrons of misfortunes attended his affection, o that he durt not harbour a thought, that would counel him to harbour his Paion, but trove to drive away his new guet, with bad entertainment; but then Love began o to play the Tyrant, that nothing would atisfie him, but the contant Tribute of ighs and groans; neither could uch windy meat, atiate his hungry deire, but he mut now and then feed upon the dainties of Glycera's beauty; o that at lat, Polienus was forced to unlock the Cabinet of his thoughts, and dicover what a Jewel he there treaured up; no other than Glycera's Picture, lively engraven on a rich Tablet, gilded with affection, and incloed in a Wounded-Heart.

Glycera beholding Polienus o accomplihed, and remembring how her body was abued, thought if e're he conented to him, it might be a means to obcure that hame, which otherwie would obcure her Honour; therefore began to embrace his motion.

Polienus
• eeing her thus to toop to his lure, reolved to queeze the quinteence of benefit out of this opportunity, and to give uch a thrut to the falling-tone of her Paion, that it hould never ret, till it came to the Centre of Felicity: So that, to be brief, the day was appointed when Hymen's Bonds hould conummate their joyes.

Thus long did heaven give intermiion to Glycera's orrows; but alas, many times ther's a reerve of miery, that puts to • light all our happines; when we think we have routed the main Battel, and begin to erect Trophies of joyes, and to lead Captive all our former ad Accidents, at the Chariot of our triumphing fortune; o it was with Glycera, joy began to triumph in her Eyes, and her heart bid Adieu to all dicontent, and the udden delight he took in thoe rich Excellencies, wherewith Nature had endued Polienus, elevated her mind to o high a pitch of contentment, that he almot thought ome heavenly Apparition had imparadized her thoughts in a golden repreentation of Elizium: but thee towring joyes did but lead her to a precipice of miery, that o her fall might be the greater; for before the marriage-day, the King had intelligence of it.
The multitude may be well compared to a Foret, that Ecchoes all things poke or done, to their Kings ears.

Loritus hearing this, reolved that his revenge hould be of an equal Latitude with his threatning, and though Amoroia upon her knees entreated for his Pardon, yet he hook her off, and told her, That the heavens themelves, though more powerful, yet are not more jut and reolute to execute their Decrees, than he was. And accordingly, he ends a Party of Hore in the night, who being let into the Catle by ome Loyal Perons, but treacherous ervants to Polienus, they urprized both him and Glycera in theis beds, who little dreamt of uch a ad interception of their happines, or that their new-coyn'd joyes hould thus prove Dros, and not pas current.

Thus doth a black hadow of miery attend a Sunhine of properity. Thus doth Hope, as a Propective-glas, preent to our dim-e • 'd ouls ome great looming
joy; but in the end, it proves nothing but a vanihing Cloud, or a Rock to hip-wrack our hopes and contents upon.

Thus many times when we think to be conducted by the glimmering glories of this World, through a night of orrows, to ome Haven, where our deluded thoughts perwade us Blis reides, they indeed prove but an ignis fatuus, that lights us through the invious Paths, and Mits of airy deluions, to a precipice of miery, where they leave us.

So it was with Polienus and Glycera, Hope, the bright Harbinger of the dawning day of Comfort, had rien upon them, and the Morning had ditilled her Dew upon their blooming joyes; but ah! The one was no ooner rien, than et; and the other no ooner fallen, than frozen, by the cold blats of Depair, that nipt their pringing happines in the Bud: for that night they were conveyed to Gortyna, a Town of great reort in Cyprus, being the Centre of it, and tands near the River Lethaeus.

The next morning, Polienus was adjudged to be thrown off a high Rock, but whether or no executed, the Knight could not reolve; but Glycera was conveyed to Kolax his houe, one who was much favoured of the King, not for his merit, but for his flattery, being a man of a ervile leaden pirit, and one that would perfectly bow, and comply with the Kings humour, and receive any Form, or Impreion he would tamp upon him; and thus by this counterfeit Coyn, gilded over with fair pretences, did he purchae his Kings favour, and poes his eaie nature; o that if any thing that required extraordinary fidelity, was to be done, he was the Peron Elected, and for that reaon, Glycera became his Prioner.

But Glycera, under all thee inquietudes, behaved her
elf with o much aequanimity, as plainly hewed, that her oul had more Antidote in it, than misfortune had Poyon; as if her contant uffering Fortunes incontancy, had hardned her oul, contrary to the nature of pirits, to an impenetrability: Which Kolax oberving, together with the vivacity of her Wit, the magnanimity of her Spirit, the olidity of her Judgment, and the Majety that attended them all, could not ufficiently behold her; and at length fell from beholding, to admiring, and from admiring, to affecting; and thus became his Prioners Prioner.

Glycera perceiving both viible and audible effects of his paion, thought a favourable entertainment of him, o far as vertue would permit, might be a means to procure ome liberty from her trict retraint; and therefore received him till with a Countenance as full of weetnes, and grace, as her mind repleat with goodnes could dipoe her to frame; o that at lat, he totally gained his heart to her devotion.

Zelota, wi • e to Kolax, a woman eaie to be moved, and being once moved, of an implacable pirit, epying her husbands love to Glycera, not enduring that any hould be admired, or affected beides her elf, and yet doing nothing that might merit admiration or affection, except to detract from others will challenge the Title of Deert, and the reward of Admiration, reolved to countermine all their underminings of her Honour, and either to make way for Glycera's light, or to make her away, where he hould never more be a Pet to her cankered mind. At length intelligence arrived at her ears of a Veel bound for Peloponneus, which he preently gave information of to Glycera, promiing to ait in her ecape, to the utmot of her ability; and covering the venom in her heart, with pleaing looks, and more pleaing expre • ons, he prevailed o farr
on Glycera's Charity, as to infue a leepy Potion into her husbands drink, that hould eize all his enes with uch a Lethargy, as ere he recovered out of his brainick trance, he might be near arrived at Peloponneus; and from thence (he aid) the paage to Thealia was not difficult.

Glycera poizing thee Propoals in her judgment, thought it not inconitent with prudence to accept of them; for all thoe mountains of dicouragements, that depair raied in her thoughts, now lay level to her wihes, and what would be the concluion of her Imprionment, he knew not; but however, this he reolved hould be the Concluion of her doubtfully revolving thoughts, that a few dayes hould put a Concluion to her abode there.

The next day Zelota comes to Glycera, with a Cup commixt, not with a leepy, but a poyonous drug (oh heavens, what will not a malitious mind, animated with Revenge, be provoked unto? What venemous gore will not ditil out of the ranklings of a gangrened mind, fetered with the incurable wounds of jealouie?) Glycera not at all imagining what a horrid enterprize he went about to atchive, yet all the way as he went, a trange kind of horror eized upon her pirits, the very Ayr eemed to fetter her leggs, and every hadowy appearance, or even hadow of uch an appearance, eemed to interrupt her Progres, that he even thought her elf hurryed away, by a trange kind of fate, contrary to the bent of her own Genius; however, he tops not, but goes to Kolax, and tells him, that he had brought him a Love-po • ion, that would incite amorous deires in the coldet nature: Kolax accepts it with gratitude, (as love you know invets all things with an amability, that proceeds from the Object beloved) and drinks of it with uch exces, as if he had a mind to convert himelf
into Loves individual ubtance. But no ooner had he emptyed the Cup of Poyon, than the poyonful Cup had filled him with pain and horror; and having roared out ome cures on Glycera, he dyed, leaving her overwhelmed with amazing Terrors, and rerrifying amazement.

The Servants of the houe, hearing this hidious cry, ran up to their Maters Chamber, where they found him dead with Poyon, and Glycera with atonihment; affrighted with this woful ight, ome ran to find Zelota, but he that morning had taken a walk abroad, intending to be abent at the execution of her bloody Plot, thereby to avoid upition: Others apply themelves to recall Glycera's mierable enes, but ah! to be the more enible of her miery, and others ran to call near-adjoyning Inhabitants, to behold this lamentable Spectacle; o that in a hort time, Fame had blazed abroad this direful Tragedy, that it re-ounded in the Kings Court, and at length came to the Kings ears alo; who no ooner heard it, but he grew even ditracted with orrow, for the los of his minion, and threatned preently to end Glycera after him, of a meage to Pluto, to require him in his name, to releae Kolax from his dark Prions, and end him among the living, or ele, if he could provoke all the Powers in Heaven and Earth to detroy his Kingdom, he would do it. Amoroia his Daughter, that had a Character given her by ome of Kolax his Servants, of Glycera, how he was a woman endued with olid Vertue, profound Widom, and trong Judgment, and hated not o much the name of Vice, as to be vitious; that if the Air had a voyce, it could proclaim no uch infection from her, as contantly teams from an impious oul; o that an Angel in his mot reclue retirements, is not more chat than he; and whoever had an eye, that could
have pierced into her heart, would have been a greater admirer of her Internal Vertue, than External Beauty; though in that was ufficiently pourtrayed all the lineaments of a mind fraught with goodnes.

Amoroia I ay, having this decription given her, could not let common fame commit uch a Rape on her Charity, or entice her to wed her belief to the tatling reports that all places abounded in, but fell down on her knees, and in a paionate manner implored Glycera's remiion of her father, or at leat a forbearance of Execution, till her Caue was heard. But the King, the more enraged with her Petitions, thus replyed: What, aid he, we hall have you Attorney to every Strumpet, to plead for their unlawful coures, and intercede for perverting jutice; no Daughter, let this reolve of mine henceforth make you ceae the renovations of this ort of entreaties; for, believe it, I'll not uffer an Innocents blood to rut that Sword of jutice, that hath hitherto been kept bright, to the dazling of admiring Beholders.

Amoroia hearing this, forbore any further upplications, till her father freed from his paionate Feaver, might be able to relih her counel; which being not long after, he goeth to him, and informs him of her tate, and lays before him all the probabilities of her innocency, a mind dicreet and charitable could uppoe, together with the inconveniences might enue a rah execution of a Forein Lady, allyed (as he heard) to the blood Royal of Thealia, and courted by Prince P •• dion, and withall gave him uch a decription of her, that at lat divorced the former reolutions from his mind, and wrought in him uch a compaion for Glycera's adverity, that he commanded he hould be honorably attended and entertained, but yet imprioned, for the pace of about a year and half, within which
time, if Pandion ent not ome Knight, that by encountring with and overcoming ome Knight of Cyprus, hould releae her, that then he hould endure the penalty of the Law; but in the mean time, he would dipatch a meenger unto him, to give him intelligence of her condition, and his determination. The meenger that he ent, was the Knight that I pake of before, and the peron elected to atchieve this enterprie, is my elf.

No ooner had he poke thee words, than a hrill noie peirced their ears, with uch an acutenes, as if it had fled before to make way for a groan that preently ucceeded it, which they hearing, imagining they came from ome ditreed Lady, ran with peed to help her, and jut as they turned round, they epied Florinda under a Tree, hard by the place where they had ate and dicoured, fallen upon the ground in a wound. Periander eeing this, chafes her tender limbs, and recovers her out of her deadly trance, who when he perceived her elf retored to her elf, he falls a weeping and ighing; ah, aid he, can my Periander find in his heart to leave me? I can and will leave thee with all my heart (aid Periander) I mean, all my heart with thee; but to find in my heart to leave thee, I cannot, ince I can find nothing there but thee. Oh but Periander hall not go (aid he) Periander will not go (aid he) for hee'l leave his oul with thee, his better part.

And will you then be gone (aid Florinda weeping) what hall become of me the while, think you? Live in as much repoe (aid Periander) as a vertuous mind rewarded by heaven with earthly joys can extract from its own internal felicity. Can true Lovers part then with o much eae (aid he) I had hoped—(and then the tears ditilled down her Cheeks in uch abundance,
as interrupted her peech, yet fain he would have poke, but her triving to peak, made her peech the more difficult, o that grief made o large a Parentheis, as if it would have put a period to her life, in the midt of her entence) but proceeding, I had hoped (aid he) Periander had thought I had loved him too dearly, ever to take any repoe in his abence. But though he can part from me, and exchange a potles affection, for a little blood-tained honor, though he can inatiably carowe my tears, yet I could not ee a tear drop from his eyes, but 'twould corrode my oul, nor can I part from him, and retain my elf, for affection hath o glewed him to my heart, as the leat eparation would rend it in pieces.

But he dicouring to her, how much it did import his honor, and of what evil conequence to Danpions affairs his negligence in that repect would be, he hung on his neck, and kied his cheeks, and all the while bathed her kies and his cheeks in tears. Oh (aid he) do not, do not go, if we mut part now, we mut part for ever. But with that, as if every letter in the word, Ever, had been a thunderbolt hot from the ulphurous clouds of love mixt with orrow in her heart, her enes were on a udden overwhelmed with extremity, and he falls down into a woun. Periander eeing this, was forc't to take an abrupt leave of Danpion, whoe dear affection each to other would ele have compelled them to be more copious in their parting ceremonies, and takes Florinda in his arms, and carries her to a houe neer adjoyning, where we leave them.

Danpion being thus unhappily deprived of his friends, and with them of his hopes of ever attaining either his Love, or his Kingdom, began mot paionately to lament his condition. For Periander that had o far befriended
him on Pandions ide, and Florinda by whoe means he had accomplihed many projects in Hiarba's Court, and who had defended him o often from Hiarbas and Amphigenia's dipleaure, were now both gone, o that he eemed at once to have lot both his word and buckler, and left alone to manage his deigns, and bear the brunt of all.

In this condition he returned to his Chamber, and there gave vent to his orrows, and in the midt of all his adnes, he ets down this reolution with himelf, that ince all his hopes were fled with Periander and Florinda, he would quench that Vetal fire of chat love that flamed in his heart, which could only be kindled at the beams of Amphigenia's beauty, and with the moke of that extinguihed flame, mother his grief, and deface that image of orrow deciphered in his de-dejected countenance, and treight apply himelf to Hiarbas will, and comply with his humors, by that means not onely to enter into, but to interr himelf alive during his dying life in his affection.

But humane determinations are but as glitering Bubbles, where ome bright reflections may pleae the fancy for a while, but oon vanih into Air with the leat blat of a divine decree; every beam of a Planet comes laden with transformations, which though it cannot have immediate commerce with the immaterial oul, yet it will bribe the Organs, and by that means unhinge the doors of reolution that exclude incontancy from the mind.

So Danpion, however for a time he flattered his orrows with the thoughts of blotting out the Characters of love with black oblivion, yet at length he found love to be of uch a trange invincible unreitable force, that the more he endeavoured to conquer its rebellions, the more it rebelled and conquered his endeavors,
o that in depight of his reaon, he was led captive by his paion. Flahes of beauty may dazle beholders eyes, but where they light to purpoe, they melt the teeliet hearts, and make them receive impreions of love, which cannot oon be obliterated: which Danpions experience could confirm, for the more he endeavoured to extinguih the flames of affection with the cold blats of depair, the more ardent they grew, and the les tolerable; o that at length with contant pining, not onely the colour, but the figure of his face began to be altered; which many oberved, as alo how he affected olitarines, to walk and talk alone, ometimes breathing forth his complaints in the Groves and Gardens, ometimes inwardly ighing, and groaning, as if his heart held a dialogue with orrow. And when he was in company, his thoughts ran o much of Amphigenia, as all the jollity and recreation the Court did abound in, eemed to him but unneceary Parenthees, and tedious digreions, to that weet ubject that his oul ilently dicoured of. And when he was in Hiarbas preence, though his policy would compell him to throw off thoe mourning weeds wherein grief had attired his countenance, let he hould lay a foundation for upicion in Hiarbas thoughts, yet the countenance holds uch a ympathy with the mind, that it is very difficult, o to counterfeit a contrary affection, that a judicious eye in every lineament of the face may not read the diimulation; o that Hiarbas could not but by every action dicern the paion, wherewith he was affected, his dull dejected looks, his impertinent dicoure, his frequent obbing, abrupt ighing, and the very tone of his voice, that did plainly proclame his heart held a correpondence with orrow.

This uddain alteration in Danpions countenance
and behaviour, bred admiration in many Noblemen of the Court, but epecially one Bacanius a great emulator and corrival of Danpions, oberving his deportments, that he might dicover the caue of his grief (which he conjectured could not be ordinary, ince the effect was o uperlative and extraordinary) he on a day in a private place meeting with Kalapitus, Danpions Page, examined him very trictly, concerning his Lord, what the caue was of his extremity of grief, whether he was in love, and had received ome repule, or whether he had committed any traiterous fact, and feared dicovery, the latter of which he chiefly hoped might be the ditemper, and if o, he in his thoughts had oon found a remedy, to wit, remediles digrace and ruine.

Kalapitus of late having unjutly (as he thought) received a box on the ear from his Mater, as he was walking with him in the Cypres-grove; the occaion of which, being onely this, Danpion (as was aid) delighting much in olitudes, and oliloquies, one morning walked forth with his Page into the Grove, where through intennes of mind, forgetting that he was attended, he fell into a lamentation of his hopeles condition, and depairing affection, and through vehemence of paion, at length giving liberty to his voice to declare his orrows, omething louder than ordinary his words were retorted back to his ears by Eccho, which Danpion hearing, minding not whence the voice came, on a udden turned round, and epying his Page, preently entertained a conceit, it was he that repeated his words, and o for his miconceived aw • ines, gave him that correction, which being more than his due, he with an ingrateful kind of gratitude, reolved to requite it, when opportunity preented.

And now fortune endeavouring like Penelope in a night of black adverity, to unweave that golden web of happines, wherewith he had hitherto inveted Danpion, incited this faithles Boys evil Genius, to inpire his mind with o much hellih rancor, as to betray his Lord, which he did to Bacanius's great atisfaction; telling him how his Lord was in Love with Amphigenia, and what means he ued to gain her affection, and how he once ent him in the night into her Chamber, attired like an Angel, with a pretended letter from Venus, and what a ecret paage he had through a crankling vault to her Chamber, and many things o to Bacanius's content, as that he gave him fifty Setercies, telling him, my weet Boy (aid he) thou art my Paris, and I accept this news from thee with higher reentments, than the Cytherean Queen on Ida's top received the golden Apple from the fair Trojan hepherd, and I doubt not but by thy means to procure that Helena of glory o courted by us, but yet by him ravihed from us. With thee words they parted.

Bacanius being a man of an implacable malice, repining at every beam of honor that hone from his Peers, never allaying the urges of rage and envy, till he had wallowed up his Competitors, a great uter to fortune, and had obtained her for his Paramour, till of late he wedded her elf to Danpion, bringing with her, her whole dowry of honor and riches, and every thing ele that makes her o deirable, having thus dicovered a paage to the haven of contentment, reolved ince the wind blew o properouly from uch a corner of the heavens, not to loe the benefit of ucces, proffered him in the acces of o fit a means to procure Danpions declenion; but though he was rejected by fortune, yet ince he was thus courted by opportunity, he would not light its importunities. And being Danpion
was o great a Favourite, it was not therefore afe for him to obey the violent impule of his inordinate Paion, which prompted him to nothing, but preent atisfying of his Malice, that thirted for Danpion's immediate ruine; but rather to wake lowly, and ecurely. For having no other to tetifie Danpion's affection to Amphigenia, but his Page, he feared, let if he hould inconiderately inform the King, without ome more pregnant confirmations of it, than his own, and the Boyes bare affirmations, the King hould dicern his envy, and o the ruine he intended Danpion, might attend himelf.

And therefore to bring about his purpoes, he intices Kalapitus with promie of a mot liberal reward, to bring him thoe clothes in which his Mater was arrayed, wh • n Amphigenia aw him in the Grove. The Boy having gratified his deires, <> on a day attires himelf in them, and watching his opportunity, when Amphigenia was bathing her elf, he rudely ruhes into the Garden, and comes upon her jut as he was come out of the ilver treams, which eemed to murmur for her departure, having onely a rich thin mantle cat over her naked body.

Bacanius, who had never before beheld o much excellency contracted and united, could not but gaze himelf into admiration and atonihment, that he thought her to be the very refined Elixar of all perfections, and every part of her a mall volume of all created excellencies in heaven or earth epitomiz'd, and writ in golden Characters; he thought her to be ome incarnate Angel clad with a body compoed of the ame quinteential matter with the heavens, but refined to uch a purity and even tranparency, that every part eemed a burning mirror, wherein the Angelical beams it incloed were united, to the inflaming of
all beholders, in fine he eemed in a definite circumference to et forth an infinite beauty, o that Bacanius tood a while even ravihed with a tupefying contentation, as if he had lot his oul in that world of beauty, or as if all the faculties of his mind thronging together to behold that wonder, had overwhelmed each other.

What hall I ay? to decribe his unexpreible admiration, were a task fitter for thoe ublime ouls who are acquainted with rapturous contemplations, and know what it is to be natcht into an extaie. But oh, the vehemence of Amphigenia's paion, at this udden urprizal! At firt he tood wondring rather whether he aw at all, than what he aw, o that he tood a while even entranced with atonihment, but at length awakned out of her dream of amazement, he betakes her elf for refuge to her leggs, and runs, and hrieks, with uch a peircing hrilnes, as the Air eemed to hand her voice to the heavens, to implore revenge for uch hideous preumption; but as it fled the Air eemed delighted with o weet a traveller, as it bandyed it to and fro, as if each part was ambitious to entertain it.

The Ladies that were walking up and down in the Gardens, ome beheading flowers, to purifie their brains with fragrant exhalations that team from thoe nets of weets, others umming up the riches of the ears in Muicks charming numbers, others paing away the time with pleaant patime, thee, I ay, hearing thus on a uddain their Lady hriek, preently run for her uccour, and at length they might ee the Princes nimbly tripping along upon the verdant Gras, which as proud to be depreed with o weet a foot, would erect it elf with a pretty kind of tatelines, after her departure, whilt he ran with o much wiftnes,
as even robbed their eyes of a plenary view of her excellencies, and Danpion as they uppoed puruing of her, who no ooner aw this beautiful train, but he fled with as much celerity from them, as before he did towards them, and hardly ecaped ere the King hearing a whole Conort of hrieks and crys, among the Ladies in the Garden, came with peed to know the caue, and found his daughter urrounded with her Ladies, like Diana amongt her Nymphs, o that he eemed like Sol among the Planets, where all beauty center'd, theirs being onely reflections of hers.

The King eeing that, called ome of them to him, to inform him of the reaon of their outcries, who told him, that Danpion (as was conjectured by his Garb) had endeavoured to force the Lady Amphigenia; Danpion (aid the King) Danpion a raviher! Danpion a raviher of my daughter! oh montrous impiety! horrid enterprie! hellih ingratitude! what Danpion, I ay, it can never be. He who hath received uch trancend • nt favours from me, as would even impoverih a Monarchs gratitude, that could command all the riches of the Orient, or make the Sea vomit up her treaures, uch as though he would urrender up his oul it would be too poor a retitution, and can it be, that he hould attempt mine or my daughters dihonor? heaven and earth would conpire their forces in avengement of uch atonihing ingratitude. But if I find it true, by all the Celetial powers, he had better have mounted on the wings of his ambition to heaven and de • lowred Venus.

This aid, the King in a fury returns to the Palace, and banihes Danpion the Court, and confined him to a houe, ome miles from the Palace, upon pain of death at the leat attempt of liberty. Bacanius eeing uch a happy reult of his plot, inwardly o welled
with content, that he could not contain his venemous rancor from burting forth to the poioning of Danpions honor, but privately gives forth candalous libells, and publikely teaches Fame the language of Danpions digrace, which hitherto he had been wholly unacquainted with, and makes her declame on nothing but the Theme of his lut and ruine; and not contended onely with this, but he relates at large to the King, Danpions affection to Amphigenia, his former attempts to atiate (as he termed it) his libidinous deires, to which this late event tood as a tet for confirmation. And now all Danpions oppoits in the Court, that had born him inveterate malice, purn at this muzled Lion, and vent their malicious fumes to obcure his lutre. Every one can lend a hand to thrut down a tottering Wall.

Thus this innocent Prince was on the udden made the ubject of Fortunes hate, and his enemies malice, and his new hatcht glory choaked by the black Acherontick vapours that teamed from his enemies hellih malignity.

But now to tell you how this gallant and Princely prioner behaved himelf under this ad fate. At firt indeed the uddenes, not the greatnes of the wo • atonihed him, as whom would it not tranport with amazement, with a thunderbolt of Fortune, in an intant to be hurid out of the Chariot of uch dazling glory, as would have exhauted a Kings Exchequer but to have made o • e repreentations of it, and thrown into a lake of mi • ery? and uch was Danpions cae, he who before was <> hing like Fortunes Admiral, in the Sea of her incont • nt glory, one little moment and linke of time chains him as a lave to the Galley of miery and digrace. He who before hone with uch a lutre as every beam of State eemd to faten to him numerous
pairs of ervil eyes that did attend his beck, is now plundered of all tate, of all repect, unpittyed, unregarded.

But though miery like Circes cup can thus metamorphoe our externals, yet it can have no influence on the rational part. None but caduque beings are ubject to the tyranny of Time and Change; and therefore abtracted beings, that come not under the predicament of corporeity, as their eence, o their happines is of an immutable permanency; and though ome abject ouls that teep their Intellectuals in ence, and can relih nothing but Epicurean pleaures, may have their delights as tranient as time, yet a compoed oul, truly fortified with Vertue, is its own detiny, and depends not for its felicity on any other than its own arbitrement, and that of an eternal Fate, which guiding all things according to their natures, conequently rules free Agents, their Actions and Fortunes, happy or unhappy, as the former are attended with Vertue or Vice, according to the principles it hath placed within them, as its Vicegerents and repreentatives to govern them. Now uch a one mieries may try, cannot dicompoe or diorder; uch a one no revolution of time can drive from reolution in the midt of extremities, and uch a one was Danpion. For he eemed a man to whom whatever can merit the epithete of Excellent might be attributed to him, having a ublime pirit in a matchles body; the former eemed a ray of Prometheu •
fire, omething ratifyed, and inveted with a more pure and active quality, not having the leat mixture of thoe ponde ••• s elements that clogg the mind, but all of rare acending fire, that clarified his blood from thoe feculent • umors that flow from the groier elements, and compoed uch a harmony in his oul, as no misfortune could make a jarr,
and the latter was o weet a compoition of all thoe maculine graces that at once feed both delight and wonder, as it eemed that Nature with Lilied beauty had chalked out his oul a lodging proportionable to its own greatnes, and given him a body uitable to the vigorous activity of his pirit.

In fine, he that will give a perfect repreentation of the former, mut not be ravihed with an ordinary fury; but his mind mut be wholly purified from all droie conceits; his fancy tarified and heightened with Ethereal fire, and his oul inpired, actuated, and inlightned with a beam of Empyreal glory, which mut form ublime fancys in it, as the Sun gives form to ublunary matter. And he that would give a true lively and lovely draught of the latter, he mut either fix his eyes on ome peron, whoe complexion, features and harmony, hold ome proportion with the delicacy, weetnes and grace, of which Danpions beauty was compoed; or ele leave the oul of his love and pas by tranmigration into him, that o by that Idea love forms in the mind, to copy out ome imperfect adumbration of his perfections; but the one being unlikely, and the other impoible, renders the Painter unable.

Now what inundation of miery could overwhelm o great a pirit, which like a rich mount of Oar, eemed to bid defiance to the turbulent waves of Fortune? That that did mot trongly invade his breat, was the remembrance of the los of Amphigenia's favour; and that indeed compelled him to let his orrow diolve in drops, and to indulge himelf to melting paions. One while hee'd huh his griefs with eaie ighes, as if they whipered in his litning ear the pleaing news of Amphigenia's pitty; and then each groan would eem a note of Love, and with thoe raptures hee'd lye entranc'd a while.

Thus ubtilly did orrow ininuate it elf into his heart, by coming hid under a bait of pleaure. But then a deep fetcht igh would tell him roundly in his ear, thoe pleaing dreams were but deluions; then grief would change the former Phrygian harmony, in his thoughts to the Dorick tone, compoed of mournful trains and doleful airs, where every note ounds like a groan, and every quaver like the trembling igh of one that weeps; And then a flowing Sea of orrow would upply his eyes with tears, which oftly trickling down his cheeks would eem to draw a Map of grief in his face; here Ilands inhabited with weets and graces, and their Garden filled with Roes and Lilies; here a lake of liquid Pearls, and there a briny tream oftly kiing his cheeks. Then he would even break out to curing Bacanius and his Pages treachery, but then Amphigenia would fill his thoughts, and make him break off abruptly, as he broke out paionately. At length epying a Lute that hung behind the hangings in a corner of the chamber, he took it down; and made it dicoure his griefs in uch melting accents, as every note eemed to flye gently into the till entrance of his charmed ear, and intrance him with a oft pleaing paion; ometimes it would eem even to teal his very oul and imprion it in the Lute; the anti • athies between the chirping Trebles, and the grumbling Bae, being o weetly reconciled by the mean, as eemed in Muicks language, to teach him Vertues mediocrity. But he making no other commentary on it, than that of grief, would think the quavering trings did tremble at his orrows, and the Lutes heart-diolving airs to igh forth the lamentations of his unfortunate but paionate love, in uch ympathizing trains, as made him almot think the pirit of ome unhappy Lover had taken up its Elizium in its belly, and there in ilent
• ones breathed forth his woes, which the trembling trings in imitation of Fame would eem to eccho to his ears; and then laying his mouth to the carved Navel of the Lutes weet womb, he would call aloud, If any Lovers oul by tranmigration dwells within this little cell of pleaure, let him come forth and tune his groans to mine, and we will charm our orrows, and top the Spheres, who litning to our tones may not whi • le our woful fates o fat upon us, and bribe the Detinies to cancel their decrees; but then nothing but a hollow ound would give reply to his words, as 'twere to hew, what little ubtantial comfort uch any conceipts afforded. It is not o eaie to tanch a Lovers bleeding heart.

But eeing the Lute refued to coffin up his woes, he
• lings it down, and takes his Pen and Inke, and fain would wrap up his griefs in the winding heet of a Letter, which embalmed in tears he would end to Amphigenia to bury them in her pittying thoughts. And that each entence might more lively expres his paion, hee'd teep every letter in a tear; but then the letters as not able to wim on the briny drops, would ink into the tear-bedabled-paper, and as i • were drowned in orrow would loe their forms, and rather repreent a montrous draught of horror.

Then he would fling away his paper, as not fit to contain the name of Amphigenia; and toe his pen, which would eem to weep for its neglect, and beprinkle the wall with its tears; tears that clad in black, eemed as dark mirors, or the quinteential extracts of orrow; where each Globe-like-drop, that trundled among the dut, eemed a little bottle that contained a livelyer reemblance of griefs Elixar, than Danpion coul ditil out of his brain.

But then he would take it again and write, and blot, and enter-line; here he thought the expreion was too flat, and there too full of big-ounding, bum-bate words, containing more yllables, than ene, and fuller of noie, than reaon; and not like the Amber-phraes, wherein witty Lovers dres their Paions, where any Love-chooled eye, in every clear conceit may decry Cupid plac'd, as in a Crytal hrine: Then he would condemn his wit, which now would eem too barren, then o full of unlickt fancies, as their number would choak their grace, and render his Style an indigeted mas of ene-confounding-nonene, and not like thoe quick lively raptures, begotten by the wanton Boy upon the Invention, which o reemble their Father, as eem to be his perfect Picture; and no ooner born, than borne on his Wings, out of the view of vulgar eyes. Then he would bid fie on his Genius, that now hould fill his head with nothing but Barbarims, when his brain had more need been a Florilegium of ublime Stories; a Store-houe of acute Metaphors, <> Similitudes, and compendiums of Eloquence, and an Inventory of all thoe Excellencies treaure • up in every Creature; but then, that would put <> in mind of Amphigenia, and then he would blame his Tongue for its unpardonable preump • ion, to mention with the leat detetation, any thing that had but the hadow of an Image of that, that might be call'd hers.

Thus did his orrow variouly vent it elf, having none to commierate him, but the enles Walls, (which with a dull noie, would repeat his moans, and ay Amen to his cryes) and the Marble of the Chimney, which would weep and weat, as 't were with ympathizing pain; but grief would transform the Form of every thing, that had the hape of comfort, and make the Walls echo his groans, with a ad dolefulnes, and the
Marble drops to reflect his viage, and therein the Portraiture of orrow. True grief delights in olitudes, if it may be aid to have any delight; and he mourns with a witnes, that mourns without a witnes.

But now, to leave him in his lamentations, and return to Amphigenia, who with the fright he took at her urprizal, fell into uch a dangerous ditemper, as threatned little les than her udden diolution; every moment the fatal Thief, would teal ome portion of her Roy-excellence, or rather the Graces enhrined in her beautious Face, by a myterious tranition paed into my oul, to make her fit to inhabit among the Celetial dwellers; which when her Father aw, he grew o enraged with Danpion, as he reolved not to be partial, but gave trict command to his Keeper, that night to put out his eyes, as others before had uffered for an offence of the like kind, though without thoe high aggravations that attended his: and moreover, to keep him Prioner, until they aw whether Amphigenia would recover, or not; if not, he hould be acrificed on her Tomb, and her Epitaph hould be written in his Ahes, and engraven with the point of a Sword on his Skull; but if the contrary, he hould have his freedom.

The Jailor, to execute the Kings commands, in the depth and dead of all the night, oftly teals up to Danpion's chamber, whom care and orrow, and a trange noie of confued thoughts, would not permit to leep, o that he was only laid down on his bed, a little wax Taper burning by him, and was reading the ad tory of Hero and Leander's love, and was o moved with its woful concluion, as that he could not but hed ome drops on the Book, and by drowning their names with Tears, make them act over again their own Tragedy.

The Keeper perceiving a dim light in his Chamber, (which gave him to ee his hopes to take him aleep were vanihed) ruhes in violently with a naked Sword in his hand, and with all the terror a deformed countenance (expreing more horror in a gatly look, than could be otherwie contained in a Volume) could frame, he delivers the meage, and commands him to ubmit with patience, as he expected to meet with better uage.

Danpion hearing this unexpected tidings, fixed his eye undauntedly upon him, whoe Majety might have truck an awful terror into the mot ruthles Villains heart, and enraged more with the churlihnes of his peech, than with the terriblenes of his meage, he, with a reolute fury, leaps upon the Jaylor, and on the udden writhes the word out of his hand, and redeems himelf, giving him blowes for his Ranom. Extremity is Vertues Opportunity, which never appears clad with greater lutre, than when tript naked by Fortune.

Danpion having releaed himelf, runs to a near adjoyning Wood, where he pends that night in ighing forth his woes; omtimes raving at the Kings merciles tyranny, omtimes curing Bacanius's treachery, omtimes lamenting Amphigenia's cruelty. His Mind floating in a tempetuous Sea of thoughts, would be wrecked, omtimes upon Rocks of inuperable difficulties, omtimes overwhelmed in a Gulf of depair: Then his Tongue, the ervant of his Mind, to give ome little eae, would vent ome treams, out of the over-flowings of his thoughts. Words are airy ucceors to our intetate comforts: Flitting Shadows, and vanihing Pictures of our mindes, or our mindes transformed into Air, and that formed into Words; inviible trancripts of our thoughts, writ upon Air, and copyed out by our
Tongues; poor breathing Orators of our woes, whoe Rhetorick will for a while huh them to ilence; who give eae, though they give no uccour.

So Danpion, with the wind of his words, would a little dipere the Clouds of grief in his mind. Somtimes he would inveigh againt Envy, calling it the putrid Blain of a corrupt mind, or the very Impothume of all vitious humours; which burting with its own venom, ends forth an infectious gore, called Slaunder: Slaunder, that bae canker of Renown, filthy vapour of an ulcerous mind, whoe team obcures Vertues bright Ray; vile demoliher of the Temple of Honour, and the accured pawn of a hellih mind.

But then his Hate to Envy, would bring to his mind the contrary oppoite, a Love to Vertue; and both thee would be as alarms, to awaken the thoughts of Amphigenia, the Object of the firt, and the Subject of the latter; And then he would condemn his too too adventurous eyes, for their preumptuous beholding of that miracle of beauty; but more his remembrance, for retaining that Soul-captivating Species, her Idea; but mot of all, his Heart, for urrendring up its Cittadel to the tyranny of love.

And then he would call out, Ah! Why did I love? Alas! alas! Why did I love? Thus to be made a lave to Beauty; but how could I chue but love? love? nay adore o Divine a Form? Rather why do I remember? ince it is remembrance that is the life of my grief, and that that renews my woes; but how can I chue but remember uch a heavenly hape, in whom all unparalleld Excellencies meet like parallels in their proper Centre; whoe every beam glanced from her eyes, writ a compleat tory in my mind, of Beauties Perfection, and Loves Prerogative? But ah! Why did I then give liberty to my eyes to ee that model of Divine
perfections? ince the eyes are the Crytal doors of the mind, at which all Objects enter that enthrall the affections; but alas! who could but gaze, and gaze himelf to admiration, and admire himelf into an Extaie, to behold one, in whoe Eye lay the diapazon of beauties viible harmony, which with their motions, like the Spheres, would trike Entrancing Raptures into all chat hearts; and where thouands of Stars lay couched under a able Veil, reembling nights Canopy, whoe rapting influence, would compel all eyes to ee, all thoughts to remember, and all hearts to love and adore?

Thus his thoughts flying from one oppoite to another, would till centre on Amphigenia; like the Eagles, that flying from Eat to VVet, met in Delphos; and thus he conumed the night, untill about the dawning of the morn; that impartially partial hour, which whilet it eems to tand as a Neuter, between night and day, and to take to neither, doth indeed incline to both; when remembring, that though his ecape had freed him from preent miery, yet not from future ruine, he therefore reolved to flee to Cyprus, after his friend Periander, and ait him in the releament of Glycera, and then return with him to Thealia, and by his means ingratiate himelf with Pandion, and he feared not but to procure a coniderable Party that hould revolt from Hiarbas, upon the leat knowledge of his intentions.

As he was thus walking and pondering, there uddenly came upon him about five Hormen, who by force (he having no weapon to defend himelf) carried him about the pace of a mile, to a green Valley, where there lay great numbers of Souldiers, as in a Buh; in the midt of whom, was a rich <> , drawn by four milk-white Hores abreat, wherein there at a mot incomparable
Lady, clad in rich attire, in whoe face was diplayed all the Enignes and Trophaes of conquering beauty, and in her looks there at not only an attractive weetnes, but a Majetick tatelines; o that he eemed at once to allure and command affection, to behold, conquer, and tryumph: So that Caears Motto, Veni, vidi, vici, tranlated into the language of Love, eemed written on every feature, in the Roie-Characters of beauty.

In this tryumphant poture he rode, four Virgins that were her Attendants, itting at her feet, a proper Gentleman, all in Armour, well mounted, riding by her as a captive to her beauty; whoe oul peeping thorow the Prion-windows of his eyes, plainly dicovered it elf to be fettered with the Beams that came from hers. To this Gentleman they carried Danpion, who no ooner aw him, but he di-mounted, and aluted him with all the tetimonies of repect and honour, an innate civility, together with a true grounded affection, and a jut repect, founded upon great worth, all meeting in one Peron, could poibly dipoe him to utter.

Danpion amazed with this unexpected manner of encounter, and the more amazed, becaue o unexpected, was at firt (contrary to his wonted manner of laying deep engagements upon others, with his unimitable courteie) carried with atonihment to that extremity, that borders on the confines of Incivility; till at length, called out of his amazement, with exces of amazement, (as waters chilnes recalls the pirits) he retorts back his alutation, with the like manner of Ceremonies, and craving pardon for his rudenes, requets him therein to accue his bad fortunes, who rendring him unworthy to chalenge, had alo banihed all expectations to meet with any uch honour; and withall,
condemning his memory, that could retain his orrows, but not the name and Idea of a Peron of o much worth. The Gentleman hearing this told him, that his name was Athalus, who, that his actions might be of an equal latitude with his promies, he, with ome few men, came to erve him in the attaining of his Kingdom.

Then Danpion called to mind, that this was the Peron that came with Periander to the Hermits Cave, and alo what engagements he made at his parting from thence, and thereupon embraced him with all poible joy, and gave him Millions of thanks for his obligements; telling him, how eaonable his aitance came, and therewithall fully informing him of his condition, and what Plots he had ued, and what ucces of his Plots, and what advantage by that ucces, and in what tate and poture his affairs were in for the preent; how much weakned by the udden departure of P • riander, whoe counel and aitance had exceedingly farthered his Deignes: And then he told him of Periander's happy meeting with Florinda, and by what wile he had ecaped from Acatus; neither did he tick to tell him of his own affection to Amphigenia, though neither by his manner of peech, countenance, or geture, did he accue in himelf any uch Paion; not like thoe puny Lovers, who can coyn no expreions, but in the Mint-houe of Paion; and when they peak, their peech is nothing but a bundle of incongruities, and incohaerent Phraes, and all the while their April-faces mut now moiten the ground with a howr of Tears, anon the clouds of grief mut be dipered, and nothing but erenity; and thus by external incontancy, decribing their inward contancy. But then Danpion began to enquire of Athalus, about the event of his love to Matilda (for Periander, as they
came along from the Hermitage, had told him the whole tory) and whether that excellent Lady, that beautified the Coach with her Beauty, were not he: To whom Athalus replyed, that that indeed was the Lady, that was the Pole-tar of all his endeavours, through whoe favour he breathed, through whoe breath he lived, through the life of whoe love he loved his life, and by which he poized all his felicity.

Danpion having performed his alutations to her, Athalus began his relation. It hapned (aid he) that during the time my wounds were healing in the Cave, where firt it was my happines to meet with your Lordhip, Plirio (through whoe means Periander and I were et upon, by the Villains that dragged us into thoe Woods, with intents to kill us) became Lord of Parrhaia, by the death of his Father; he being the only preerver of his name, was left the only Poeor of his Lordhip; who having now ability to execute what only before he had wickednes to de • ire, hoping that both of us, but epecially my elf, had tated the fruit of his bae revenge, eizes upon my Catle in my abence, under pretence of a forfeiture for Treaons, Murders, and Conpiracies aid to be acted and ploted by me and my Complices. And that he might colour over thee unjut pretences, with pretences of Jutice, he caued thoe that ecaped from Periander by • light, after they had acted their bloody Tragedy upon me, vehemently to petition for jutice againt me; who being men not only of murderous, but mercenary pirits, and never would refue to dive into a Sea of wickednes, to find that Pearl called Gain, and ever thought it the greatet piece of folly in the world, for men to recede from their own Interet, through a childih dread of impiety, and to be affrighted from the beaten rode of Vice, if it leads to a Mine of wealth,
with the foolih Bug-bear terrors that haunt that path; and therefore they'd no les deride at thoe, that not teering their actions by the compas of Profit, would ail where ever thoe guts of popular breath entituled Honor hould drive them; than a skillful experienced Mariner would at a freh-water Seaman, that neglecting his Compas, hould flatter himelf with hopes of a peedy arrival at his Port, becaue he runs afore the wind, though it blow from a quite contrary quarter. Thee men being thus a fit matter for him to uperinduce any form upon, he transforms their former hapes, and makes them become of lovers to Vice, pretended lovers of Vertue; and therefore deirous of jutice, no •
not only becaue it was jutly ranked in the catalogue of Vertues, but becaue it was the detroyer of Vice, and the cheriher and protector of Vertue
And this he did to obcure his own malice, and their revenge, from the popular view; that o his actions having an image of jutice impreed upon them, might pas current.

Having thus by policy and ubtilty, plundered me of my etate, the next thing he had to do was to poes himelf of Arriteia, without whom all the other iues of his brain would prove abortive; and to that end he invites both the iters Arriteia and Matilda, (to intercept all jealouies in them or their Father, that might intercept his plot) to a mot magnificent feat, where (as was reported) luxury and exces eemed to ride in triumph in every dih, as though the torehoues of the elements had been ranacked to furnih his Table; as if he had been rather to have courted his Mitries appetite, than her affection; o that his Table eemed the Scene of Prodigality, whereon was acted the Tragedy of Temperance and true Liberalty; the mot poinant meats being poions to the former,
as exceive profuenes is detructive to the latter.

But the Feat being concluded, Plivio had another play to act, to which this erved but for a Prologue; and that was to eize upon Arriteia; that ince (as the Philoopher aith) every one is the framer of his own fate, he reolved that none hould accue his negligence for his infelicity, but he would purchae that by compulion, to which milder means he aw would prove ineffectual. For (my Lord) you mut know Arriteia was a Lady in whom appeared all the delicate attractives of beauty, and external demontrations of internal Vertue; o that as the former would ufficiently excue a Stoick hould he become an amorit: excue? nay accue him of a bae ignorance of worth, hould he not admire her perfections; o the influence of the latter, might have created goodnes in the wort of men, and rendered him inexcuable in whoe breat was the leat park of an impure fire. Now no wonder if a vertuous oul enhrined in o weet a body, by a reflex act viewing its own internal beauty, be like Narcius gazing on his picture limned by the Sun-beams in a Fountain, enamoured with its own excellencies; and o was Arriteia, yet not o as to obcure her worth, with being void of humility, but rather made Humility a means to dicover the worthines of her worth, and o her Vertues as they became more perpicuous, o more delectable; o that if her humility was apt to entice hope, her dazling worth would again tupiie and confound it.
