But as none can cat up their eyes at the Sun, with more confidence, and les dazling, than the blind; o none are les ravihed with true worth, than thoe whoe ignorance of it, makes them leat admire it.

So Plivio, though none had les grounds for hope,
yet none had greater confidence than he; not becaue he o far excelled others, as that his trancending deerts hould excite her to pitch upon him, but becaue his worth being hort of many, made him les able to dicern of anothers, and begat conceits of himelf above what his deerts could challenge, and uch thoughts in any will oon augment hope to a preumption; but this did but create the more dieteemes of him in Arriteia's thoughts, who by the light of her own worth was able to ee his worthlenes, and where dieteem once gets entrance, its hard to crowd out diaffection, they being ineparably linked together, as love and contempt are irreconcileably eparated; o that Arriteia thus lighting his peron would much more contemn his importunings, that he let all his words dye in their own ounds, his mot pathetick expreions taking no more impreion on her, than puffs of Air upon an Adamant.

Her mind was a Paradie, where warmed Angels of high thoughts, uch thoughts as each deerved a Crown, and could he think uch thoughts would admit of ociety with o mean and abject meditations as his imaginary Vertues? But whither doth my paion tranport me! Plivio finding her thus (as he tearmed her) an obtinate piece, bent his wit more to devie ome tratagem, how to procure her by the favour of policy, than before he did to compoe his mooth courting peeches to torm her by the force of eloquence. And having by that ubtilty enticed her to his Catle (as I told you) after the Feat was concluded, and the ri • hes of the time pent in dalliance and delights, the two Si ••
ers, with great acknowledgements of his c • vility, took leave of him.

Plivio being now if ever to accompl • h his de • r • s, waits upon them to the Catle Ga • e, performs many
ceremonies to them both to delay their udden departure, but epecially to Arriteia, to whom he applies himelf in all the dilatory potures of a parling Lover; o that Matilda by this time was entered into her Coach, and all their attendants tood without, waiting when Plivio would dimis their Lady, whoe ear was urfeited with his tedious complements. But Plivio having now brought about what he deired, thought it not prudence to dally with opportunity, but on the uddain gives the watch-word to his ervants, who being able to interpret the meaning, make fat the Gate, and by force drew in Arriteia into the Catle, not regarding her pittiful hrieks and crys, and tears, able to wound the flintyet heart, and peirce the mot impenetrable ears. Oh! that heaven hould ever permit any to fix the upercription of love, upon actions o plainly viible to the dimmet eye, to be nothing but the offprings of a luxurious paion.

Matilda, with the company that were without, hearing Arriteia's crys, and eeing the ad effects of his plot, and that his former delays were but the courtings of occaion, they in a confued manner run home to Pirotes's houe, to inform him of his Daughters urprizal; but as they went, amazing fear had o ditracted ome, and fearles amazement tranported others, that when Pirotes at their arrival (having his heart no les filled with terror, than his ears were with the noie of that rout) inquired of them the caue of their confuion, as the one (at firt) could not tell what to relate, o neither could the other tell how to deliver their doleful meage, but made their countenances upply the defects of their peech; till at length they declared the villany of Plivio, and the miery of his Daughter.

Pirotes, whoe ears with uch greedy hate hunted for words, had now over-taken the prey that preyed upon him, and pulling his hat over his face (as I was told) tears fell in uch abundance, as if his heart diolved into drops, had ditilled thorough his eyes; uch a ource of orrow did over- • low him, as even drowned his enes, and with too much ene of grief, made grief become eneles. Sorrow when it wells above the dam of moderation confounds it elf.

In this confued conflict of mind, he fixes this reolution in his thoughts (if an unteadfat mind, floating on the incontant waves of grief, can ever be aid to reolve) that a few womanih complaints hould not atisfie his revenge, but he would give the coyn that Mars ues to purchae Kingdoms with for her Dowry.

The next day, according to his reolution, he ummons all his Tenants together; and as many as thorow either envy or hatred to Plivio, or love to Arriteia (for he had many uters, and he many rivals, whoe merits far over-ballanced his, though his fortunes exceeded theirs) would appear in arms againt him, and beieges him in his Catle before his pies could give any information; o that all his preparations were to fight Cupids battels, for intead of that micellany of noies and combutions that are the uual effects of udden alarms, they might hear nothing but Muick and dancing, and all things that argued a fearles ecurity; only, as happened, the Gates were hu • , but rather to keep out the air than an enemy, the Guard being dicharged that hould have watched upon the walls, and the Centinels that hould have given notice of this invaion.

Thus many times, ome unthought of michief teals away our joys, whilt our enes lye teept in olace and
benummed with a dream of pleaure, and eldom that iue of an improvident mind Security, lights upon any that move upon the till waters of content, but like that inaupicious meteor called Helena, it preages a torm.

And o it was with Plivio, he was reaping the harvet of delight with one hand, whilt he owed the eeds of his own ruin with the other. And had not the Gates been happily fatned (thanks more to his good fortune than his vigilance) he had been urprized in the midt of all his jollity; but by that means they were forced to ue caling Ladders, battering Rams, and other Engines of War, to force a paage into the Catle. And o trongly was it fortified by Art and Nature, that notwithtanding they were interrupted with o mall reitance, as onely from ome few of Plivio's menial attendants, that were more beholding to Nature for valour than their Mater, and had made what oppoition, men grown deperate with courage and neceity would dare to attempt, yet ucces had not put a period to their enterprize, untill the etting of the Sun had concluded the day. And jut then (as • ortune would have it) it was my happines to arrive at the Catle, to the admiration of Pirotes and all his company, who before were fully poeed with the belief of my death. But after ome congratulations that paed betwixt us, he gave me a full information of the reaons of his proceedings, and what had been Plivio's deigns in my abence, and how that fate that commonly attends uch actions, had now diipated all his endeavors.

The whilt he held me in this dicoure, the ret of the men were ranacking the Catle for Plivio and Arriteia, the one the onely prey for their revenge, and the latter the onely treaure they ought after: but
notwithtanding all the care and diligence that could be expected in men earching for a Jewel, that mut ranom them from the killing tortures of a living death, not the leat footteps of either could be found. But how, or when, or which way, or whither they ecaped, was as great a ubject of our admiration, as if the Sun had droped down from heaven. But I hall never forget how the good old man, when the news of his Daughters flight • lew to his ears, how he at once both wept and wondered, grief and atonihment having both taken the Fortres of his heart, and both at once diplayed their Banners in his countenance, and there I aw at once an agreement betwixt them to tyrannize over him, and a diagreement about dominion over each other; his amazement did at once tranport him and confound grief, his grief would at once overflow him and drown his amazement.

But at length after a tedious earch for Arriteia, for whom they looked with more curioity than Ceres did for Proerpina, and the time of night being come, that is wont to teal our enes, and hide them in a Pandora's box of dreams, Pirotes returned home (for home he would return) though (as common civility obliged) I much preed him to the contrary. But as he went (poor Gentleman) methoughts I aw a doleful heare of orrow in his looks, his heavy eyes with their dim lights pointing towards • he ground, as if there he meant to inhabit next, and eemed like torches in a grave; whilt every part would act its part, and eemed to give a dumb relation of that tory of woe written in his thoughts.

But to be hort, orrow had o cloed up all the entries of his mind, that there was not the leat • rany for a beam of comfort to hine in; yea it o plaid the Tyrant, that it quite exil'd all ret and leep, and every
thing that eemed an enemy to mourning, o that he convered with nothing but olitarynes, aw nothing but darknes, heard nothing but inward ighs, pake nothing but ilent moans, felt nothing but pangs that tupified his feeling, and tated nothing but inipid grief, till at length death that unties the Gordian knots of nature, that untunes the harmony of compounded beings; the poor mans wih, the rich mans fear, the ad mans joy, the tout mans Page, the young mans
• oy, and the old mans expectation; that thief that teals man away, and leaves his picture for a while, tole Pirotes out of this world, who amongt many other grave counels to Matilda (the rare off-prings of thoe evere but excellent thoughts, that team forth from a departing oul, carried above it elf with that exces of joy extracted from thoe pleaureable meditations that a well-paed life in this world do afford) I ay much and o excellent advice he gave her, as if he would have contracted the former goodnes of the whole pan of his life into a punctum, of all his years into that lat moment, and then like the lat blaze of an Aromatick Torch, breath forth the fragrant odors of his life in his lat intant; and then my good Angel inpired him with uch high thoughts of me, as (indeed) it would be the greatet preumption to think my merits could challenge a farr inferior reputation: So that at his lat hour he charged her, that if ever (as he pleaed to tearm it) o much happines was reerved for her, as that I hould pitch upon her as the object of my affections, not to be o great an enemy to her elf (he might more properly have aid an enemy to me) as to light me, though my mall worth might be a ufficient excue, having nothing that might merit the contrary, except in that I love her; but however, this was • o • h his advie and command; o that encouraged by this, <…>
freh remembrance of his death was a little withered (as nothing ever continues verdant, though farr be it from me to expunge the remembrance of him, 'twould be an eternal blot to my name, and might jutly make me remembred onely for infamy) but I ay, after the verdant frehnes of it, though watered with the dew of many tears, began to decay, I went to Matilda, and unbreated my thoughts to her, and dicloed the beauteous image of her elf there incloed; and how pure a flame was hot from her eyes into my heart, and in a broken manner (for uch is the language of Lovers, the commotions of their hearts diturbing their peech) I ay brokenly I begged of her to love me, if not for my own ake, yet as the Cabinet of uch a Jewel as her Idea, and if not for that, yet for her Fathers ake, who had bequeathed o excellent a Legacy unto me as her elf, the Jewel of the world, the pattern of perfection, in whoe preence all beauties loe their lutre, as the Suns refulgent beams drown the plendor of the Stars; and in comparion of whom Venus was but a blowze, and might jutly be accued of the highet arrogance, hould he account her excellencies worth etimation when compared with hers.

In fine, I left nothing unaid that Love could dictate (and Love did dictate as much as can be within the compas of invention) o that at length with thee aaults I battered down all thoe reaons that fortified her heart againt me; and forced her to bluh forth a dumb conent, when methoughts I aw her former thoughts marching out of her mind with the colours flying in the lovely Air of her countenance, with uch a delicate bravery, as he eemed at once to yield and tryumph; o that I became o • a captive a victor, but yet uch a victor, as my conquet did but augment my captivity.
And before he would urrender up her heart to my poeion, he compelled me by many Vows to wear, not to deface her potles Vertue, but that chatity hould retain its governance; and withall to pay a large um of merits, towards the building a Temple of honor, where her Vertue hould lye enhrined; and ince that no deerts purchae greater renown, than thoe that are founded on Valour and Deeds of Arms, therefore he engaged me to travel with her thorough Greece to hunt for fame with heroick exploits. And remembring that there was no better way to eternize my name, than to erve o excellent a Prince as your elf, in o jut and honorable a caue, I raied what forces I could in Parrhaia, and am now come to obey Matilda, and erve your Lordhip.

Athalus having thus finihed his tory, Danpion and he began to conult about their deigns. Great affairs being urrounded with difficulties, for their better accomplihment, require as well Argus's eyes as Briarcus hands. And therefore as a Prince would proclame himelf guilty of no great prudence, whoe confidence on anothers judgement hould create in him a diffidence of his own, and by that means make another the Atlas of his Crown; o neither would it argue height of policy, hould an over-valuing opinion of himelf, beget in him a contempt of his counel: For by that means, viewing his reaons thorough the pectacles of elf-conceipt, be ure they will appear (however empty in themelves) more full of widom, more forcible, and more demontrative than others. That Prince had need have a brain pregnant with Minerva that needs no co • nel, as he hews himelf a Prince (carce a man I hould ay) with a head, empty of brains, that refues all counel.

But to digres from this digreion. Pandion and Athalus (as I aid) fell into conultation about the managing this caue in which they were embarqued, and how to teer it afely to the Port of Soveraignty. Now in all determinable caes, controverted by a Councel, thee three points are chiefly to be inited on.
Firt, The Jutnes of the caue: for who can expect to return crowned with a Lawrel, that at once fightt againt the powers of heaven and earth?

Secondly, The facility of accomplihing; and therein is to be conidered the intrumental caues: for never was any o in league with Heaven, as to challenge upernatural aitance. None could free him from the imputation of madnes, that would endeavor to effect an enterprize without endeavors; that were to create not to get victories.

Thirdly, The honor and profit: ince man acting as a rational creature by voluntary election, not by intinct of Nature, or compulive impule of Sene, always propounds ome thing to himelf, which appearing under the notion of good, is called the final caue, which though lat in execution • , is firt in intention; therefore much more in the management of the highet affairs, man is entruted with on earth, they ought to ue the greatet reaon; and Reaon never excites the will to proceed to election of any thing for its object, that contains not real worth to render it eligible, or is at leat gilded over with an amability.
Now thee three things were chiefly conidered in their deliberation.

And as to the firt, namely, The jutnes of the Caue; that was affirmed to be as apparent as the Sun by whom all things are apparent; it being the proecution of a perecuted right, and uch a right, that had been founded upon an indubitate ucceion for many
generations, proclamed by the voyce of heaven the people, and confirmed by the Law of Nature and Nations.

And to that Objection that Hiarbas his right, both by Conquet, and by Agis his reignation, had wallowed up Danpion's, Reply was made: To the firt Part of the Objection, That Nature was an impartial Legilator, and Univerals were equally hared among Specials and Individuals: Now if it was an Univeral Rule, That Might could purchae Right, then it was as jut for Danpion to regain the Kingdom by force, as Hiarbas by force to poes it. If the longet word is a fit tool to carve Crowns for one, it is for another. If the Trophies of Conquet can afford materials for a Throne for one, they can for another. But the Sword uing no other Arguments, than thoe of Victory and Succes, cannot be a fit way to contitute, nor a fit Umpire to determine Right: And though it may plead Cutom and Example, yet uch Pleas are only valid with thoe, whoe ignorance of the Original and true contitution of Right, Equity, and Jutice, dipoeth them to adhere to a Precedent; and though they follow the example of one, whoe actions were probably entituled jut, becaue they ecaped that vengeance that purues injutice: We are not to quare our actions by anothers, unles he quares his by the rules of jutice: And though (it is true) in the tate of War, that all men are in, before the intitution of Common-wealths, (every man by nature being as a little World, o a little Republick) a Right procured by the Sword is not unjut, becaue unjutice is the wrongful detaining of anothers Propriety; now one man having as much right to all things as another, there can be no Propriety, until a coercive Power is etablihed, that mut divide this vat Common into Incloures; yet after Commonwealths
are intituted, to invade anothers right, is not to procure a Propriety, but a Poeion; for Propriety is a Right to enjoy and improve any thing transferred by mutual voluntary compact, under a coercive Power, that can render the Contract valid, by compelling the mutual performance: Now a Covenant being an act of the Will, and the Will having only ome good for its Object, and no greater evil, than to abandon means of elf-preervation (which is the end and ue of all things we eek to enjoy) therefore none can be uppoed voluntarily to renounce his right of enjoyment of that, the los whereof tends to his detruction; becaue he therein cannot be thought to aim at any good to himelf.

Again, a Covenant being a voluntary act, mut be free from all coercion: For though the Elicit actions of the Will are not ubject to compulion, yet the Imperate actions are omtimes forced to rebel againt its commands and dictates: Now a Covenant being a voluntary transferring of Right, that is, not a conferring a Right upon another that he had not before, becaue Nature equally hares all things, among all perons, but a deveting ones elf of a liberty of interrupting anothers Original Right, in the thing alienated, or a voluntary tanding out of the way, that another may enjoy his Original Right derived to him by Nature: As Alexander, when he ecliped the Sun, by his interpoition between it and Diogines's little Hermitage, removed his tation at the Cynicks requet: But an enjoyment purchaed by force, doth not by a reciprical tranferring of ome good, move the Will of any one by compact, voluntarily to renounce his Right, or liberty of impeding anothers ue of his own Right Original, and to remove himelf away the main obtacle, but rather thruts uch a one away by force; as if Diogines
hould have crowded Alexander from between him and the Suns Rayes.

And therefore a Right o procured, is only a preent fruition, that is Poeion, until a tronger natches the Prey. Hence, no one can invet himelf with a right of Soveraignety only by force, a power of governing o procured, being not a Soveraignty, but a Tyranny: For all Soveraigntie, or Power of governing others, is Originally derived from a certain number of Perons, covenanting one with another, to urrender up their natural right of Self-gubernation, to one or more Perons, who repreenting the whole, o united by mutual compact, may ue the power and trength of them all for the afety, and benefit, and weal of the Publick.

Therefore a Power attained by violence, is not a Power to rule, but tyrannize; the multitude having never o much as implicitly transferred over their right, and conequently not obliged to obedience, any farther than as their Non-obedience may turn to their detruction: And in that repect, the right of Soveraignty being equally hared among all Perons, by nature, the diproportion only remains in this, Thar uch a one hath the longet Sword.
But concerning the econd part of the Objection, viz: That Agis had transferred over his right to Hiarbas by Reignation, this was the olution:

Firt, though it is true, Covenants entred into by force are Obligatory, from the Law of Nature that commands Self-preervation, and conequently an Election of thoe means that tend thereunto; therefore if an extorted reignation be a means to procure uch a good, as a freedom from that evil that is the Object of fear, it cannot but be binding, where there is no other Law (as in the conditihn of meer Nature)
forbiddeth the performance; but uch Covenants being acts of men, conidered as in the condition of War, are therefore obliging no longer, than until there arieth a new and jut caue of fear, and then he is much obliged by the ame Law, that for Self-conervation commanded him to reign up uch a Right, becaue the reervation of it was inconitent with his preervation, to re-invet himelf with that right he relinquihed, if it be the only means for his afety, as before he was to reign it up.

But it was alleged, That there was a jut caue of fear, though not in Agis, yet in Danpion his Heir, or Repreentative, who had the entence of Death paed upon him, and therefore might jutly eek to re-gain the Kingdom, not only as his lawful inheritance, but to preerve himelf from the invaions of Hiarbas, there being nothing more reaonable than Anticipation, that is, the over-powring thoe Perons that eek ones detruction.

But econdly, The people of Thealia had given the overaignty to thoe that were lineally decended of Agis's Ancetors, and therefore were bound by Covenant to obey them, as their lawful Soveraigns: Conequently Agis, though he might dipoe of the Government during his life, yet not of the Succeion; becaue he derived no uch authority from the Fountain of Soveraigntie, the Multitude, in the firt intitution; and therefore the transferring of the right of governing from his Poterity to a tranger, was the giving away anothers Propriety, or an aiting of one, in the invaion of another.

Hence, Hiarbas was but a temporary King, to whom the entire exercie of Power was committed for a time; which once expired, his Power mut alo expire with it: after which, his Government was but an unjut Uurpation,
or a wrongful detaining of anothers Propriety.

The econd thing they conulted about, was the facility of accomplihing: For Policy forbids any man to ingage in a War, though for a jut and lawful recovery of his own; unles he can produce pregnant and demontrative aurances, that he hall be econded with ucces. But they did not doubt of ucces, for thee Reaons:

Firt becaue, the ooner any thing comes to perfection, the ooner it declines to corruption and diolution; o the ooner any arrives at the height of power, the nearer he is to his declenion. And this was Hiarbas cae, being on a udden rebounded, by a trange fortune, into the throne, from the ground of a hopeles irreolution.

Secondly, As in Nature, o in Government, nothing is permanent that is violent. For though for a time a Tyrant (i.e. an unjut Uurper, or poeor of anothers Power, to whom the right of overaignty in Propriety belongs) though for ome time he may underprop his tate with the Sword and Policy; yet in the end, Divine Jutice naps the Sword in under, infatuates his Council, and makes his own the ubaltern caues of his down-fall.

But Hiarbas, as he came to his Government by a Politick violence, o he upheld it by the ame; and therefore they feared not, but that fale pretended right, incribed by the Sword-point, on the leaf of a Laurel, would be diipated, like the Prophecies of that Sybill, that ued Leaves for her Paper, by the blats of Heavens Vengeance.

Thirdly, That Government that is erected on the Bais of a Faction, cannot tand; becaue the Foundation being too narrow for the Fabrick, and it having no
Internal Principle of tability, mut be upheld by External Props, and conequently ubject to diolution, upon the leat failing of that force, by which it was contituted.

But as the former was mot apparently true in Hiarbas his Government, o alo the latter; viz: That that force that was the Architect of his overaignty, daily declined thorow intetine diorder. Thee, and many other Reaons that were then given, encouraged them in their high enterprize.

But as for the third thing, viz: the Honour and Profit that would redound, if their atchivements were crowned with ucces, that was o conpicuous, as it required no great conideration. So that in Fine, this was the reult of the conultation, That Athalus hould march with his men to the Court, and pretend to be revolted from Pandion, through an opinion of the merit of Hiarbas's Caue; that ince Danpion was exiled from thence, and none to nourih Faction in the Court or Kingdom, Athalus by that means might ingratiate himelf with the King, and breed emulation among the Nobles, and dientions among the Commonalty; that o by that means, they might fit all things in a readines againt the firt acces of a miling fortune. And as for Danpion, it was thought not afe for him to entrut himelf in any part of the Kingdom, unles diguied; it was therefore reolved, that he hould attire himelf in the habit of a Lady, and go to the Court as a companion of Matilda's, and o make that mask a tep at once to reach the prize of his Ambition and Affection.

Thee things thus agreed on, Danpion arrayes himelf in a white ilken Robe, that taught from his houlders to the ground, the train whereof trayed a pretty ditance from his heels, and before was bu ••• ned with
rich Jewels, from his neck, to his knees, and there left open to dicover the pure whitenes of his skin: His leggs and feet were imprioned within the gilded Labyrinth of rich Buskins, which were fatned under his knee, with a mot precious Jewel, where the ends of all the Knots did centre and unite: His hair being very long, after the Thealian manner, hung looely, and carelely upon his houlders, having no other attire upon his head, than a lawn Veil cat over his head, face, and houlder, on the top of which, he wore a Coronet of Gold, et with Diamonds, the antient Habit of Virgin-Princees in ome parts of Greece. Thus arrayed, he teps up into the Chariot, and its on the right hand of Matilda, and accompanies her to the Court, under the name of Celania; where in a hort time they arrived, and were received by Hiarbas (after notice given by a Herauld from Athalus, what they were, and what the intents of their coming) with all poible demontrations of Honour; not neglecting any ceremonies or complements that appertain to State, but manifeting all things that might expres the greatnes of a Princes mind, who corns to be overcome in curteie.

And as for the two Ladies, Celania and Matilda, with the four Virgins that were the Attendants, they were conducted by a chief Gentleman-Uher, thorow the outward Court, to a tately Gallery, that led into a mot beautiful Garden; where they were received by a Lady of Honour, and thence led to the Princes Amphigenia; who in her Chamber was et in a Chair of State, under a mot rich Canopy of cloth of gold, with many young beautiful Ladies, clad in Crimon Damask, attending on her.

Amongt whom, her mot trancendent beauty made her hine, with as much uperiority, as the Sun doth over
the leer Luminaries; o excellent and incomparable were the Graces that at enhrined in her lively Countenance, as he eemed as a perfect mirror of all beauty and Majety; uch a miraculous compoition of all thoe Excellencies, that can at once both enravih with delight, and tranport with admiration: She eemed (as indeed he was) a fitter ubject for the pen of Angels, whoe vat capacities render them more able to comprehend, as their being converant with immortal Glories, to decribe the ublimity of her Perfections, than any Mortal whatoever; becaue, though he had an undertanding as vat as the Creation, that he could put a Girdle upon Nature, and might, like the Bee, here and there extract the choycet Flowers, that grow in her Garden, to fill his invention with imilitudes, yet being cooped within the Univere, he can no more decribe the perfection of her beauties, than a Picture of the Sun can imitate its Splendor.

In this tately poture he ate, until the Ladies were conducted into her preence, and then he aroe and aluted them, with a countenance and geture expreing o much weetnes, but yet tempered with uch a lovely, but tately reervednes, as he at once gave them their due Honour, and yet retained her own State; o that Majety in her deportments eemed to decend on the wings of Humility, like Phaebus's Chariot, ruled by Phaeton, and inflamed their hearts with admiration; but epecially Celanias's who was truck into a trange kind of tranport, that had near dicovered her, had not concience recovered her; for her heart fell into uch a vehement panting, and her body was arreted with uch a quiv'ring, as even hindred both her peech and getures, at leat the grace of them, o that he at firt wihed he could purchae a hanom conveyance out of the Room, with the los of thoe delights
Amphigenia's preence afforded: And no wonder, for he was never before acquainted with the happines of o near an acces; much les therefore with the effects of love, when extafied with o near an approach to the object beloved, and leat of all with an Antidote againt the trange influence of thoe effects.

But at length the conideration of thoe mieries that would be in the event of her dicovery, conquered thoe pangs, and gave his reaon the overaignty over his paion; o that though at firt Paion didained to hearken to Reaon as a Councellor, it now refued not to be ubject to it as a Prince.

Celania being now in a capacity • or convere, fell into conference with Amphigenia, the cadences of whoe words eemed to her a melody beyond the very relihes and cloes of Angels Muick, as her features eemed to trancend Angelical Beauty. After ome time conumed in pleaant dicoures, Amphigenia led them into the Gardens, and there hewed them all the delights might have ated an Epicure. Such a banquet had Art and Nature there et forth to feat the ight, as might atiate the mot greedy pomp-expecting eyes, atiate? rather atonih. Neither were the eyes alone partakers of the mollitious pleaures of that Paradie, but the ears were enriched with all the treaures a well-touched Lute (that weet Exchequer of delights) could afford, whoe reounding womb eemed the Limbeck of harmony, where its quinteence was ditilled, which gently dropping thorough the ear into the Cabinet of Sene, the Brain, with its oft pleaures charms the oul.

But this was but a prelude to a conort of Intruments excellently plaid on by delicate Ladies, itting under a Sun-proof Arbor, whoe features eemed as
full of harmony to their eyes, as their Muick was beautiful to the ears. But whilt they were keeping time in Muick, time danced by o nimbly, as th • y rather in keeping lot it, each minute crowded on o fat, and eemed to tread on its predeceors heels, as if it feared the others loytering might intercept its pleaures: o that it was not long ere the farr-extended hadows of the mountains, eemed ent as meengers from Titan, to tell them the news of his declenion, when upper was in great tate erved into the Banqueting houe; a tately building upended in the Air on Marble pillars, tanding on a flowry plain, embraced with the Silver treams of a purlling River that gently crept along: the Chamber above was hung with cloth of Tiue, in the midt of it was a round Tribunal made of Porphyry, on the top of which was a chair of State, wherein was placed the Statue of Diana, richly apparelled, a golden cepter in her hand, and the three Graces attending on her, playing on wind Intruments, which were carved o lively, that as their figure deceived the ight, o did the Muick the hearing, which the water conveyed by ilver pipes thorough the pillars made them compoe.

But all thee glories eemed to Celania onely to adorn the tryumph of Amphigena's beauty, which lead captive more hearts than they did eyes, or the Muick ears; o that he viewed them onely with a careles eye, accounting nothing worth the eeing in Amphigenia's preence but her, nor carce ever cating a glance on any thing; unles it were on that whoe extraordinary excellence might jutly challenge a look from a Criticks eye, and then he would compare it with her, to render her Beauty incomparable. But if Amphigenia chanced to crop a lower, or treaure up the perfumes of a Roe, or dipere the rays of her f • ir
eyes on any object, then he would look and look again, envy the flower, grow jealous of the Roe, and grieve that he her elf was not the object. Ah! (would he ay) thou pretty Martyre, how happy art thou to loe thy life by o weet an executioner! And when he aw it wither in her hands: Poor eneles flower (aid he) cannot a glance from that eye revive thee? nor a touch of that hand (whoe oft delicacy would warm a heart bennumed with Age, and in depight of years recall Youth fled with Time) cannot uch a hand (I ay) top the career of thy beauties? Poor foolih flower, what meanet thou to let death ravih thy weets? deface that portraiture of beauty, pencil'd by Nature in thy leaves? demolih thy lovely Cittadel of lovelines? thinket thou to reume more weetnes, more beauty, more lovelines, from her mot weet, mot beautiful, and mot lovely hand? no (fond thing) her chatnes hates a protitute. What then? what is the matter? dot thou bequeath thy weets to her? and do they by a ecret tranition pas away from thee, and by tranmigration dwell in her? no ure, her Ocean of beauty needs not thy drop, her infinite treaures conferr'd on her by too prodigal heaven, ure needs not the addition of thy poor mite: no, no, thou pinet away with grief, and o do I.

Again, when he aw her extract the fragrancy of a Roe: Oh! too happy flower (would he ay) and in this onely unhappy, that thou art ignorant of thy hapnes: Little thinket thou where thy fading weets do lye entomb'd; thou wouldt not grutch to part with all thy wealth, knewet thou but where its treaured, nor to be rob'd of thy little cargo of perfumes, didt thou but know thy Pirate. Rob'd? if a Merchant that cha •• e • s trah for Gold, or Glas for Pearls is rob'd, then o art thou.

Her pure hand that divides thee from thy root, doth but tranport thee from thy native dwelling, to the Vermilion Orient of her lips, where he changes the Aromaticks of her breath for thy poor odours. Oh! Oh! might my oul be refined by the heat of Loves paions into uch a team, as now expires out of thy bluhing leaves, and be exhaled like thine, and dwell among the Carnation clouds of her beauty, I'de not envy the inhabitants of Elizium.

Thee and the like peeches would he wiper to her elf upon every occaion, extracting out of that Garden of delights, onely what might feed the appetite of love. And when Supper was erved in, though there was all t • e rarities that could be expected at a refection invented by an Epicure, to feat his Sene without ene of atiety, yet Celania took no contentment in all, only let her eyes riot in the mot luxuriant banquet of Amphigenia's beauty, which he did with the more confidence, preuming her diguize might make her looks unregarded, or at mot unupected. Such trange effects did Love work in Celania's heart. If Amphigenia pake, the weet harmony of her voice, and eloquence in her peech, would trike Celania mute. If Amphigenia afforded her a glance, the lutre of her eyes (like the Sun whoe own brightnes is his hade, and ends a drop to veil a gazers eye) would trike Celania blind. If Amphigenia graced a Lute with h • r playing, the curious wiftnes of her fingers nimbly touching the quavering trings, in deep amazes would trike Celania motionles.

And thus did Amphigenia's preence abent Celania from her elf. But upper being ended, after a great deal of mirth that uually abounds in Princes Courts in times of • renity, but epecially upon uch occaions the night being far pent, the Sun having ditributed
much of his light to thoe of the other hemiphere, Amphigenia brought the Ladies to their everal lodgings, where my Mue will bid them good night, and leave them to take their repoe, that conort of darknes, that overaign of balme for care-wounded-minds.

Thus had Danpion, now Celania, finihed the econd part of his Tragicomedy, and is now tepping into the third, which as it was acted under various di • guizes, o with various fortunes, as we thus declare.

The two happy Lovers Athalus and Matilda having continued ome pace in the Court, not willing to tay any longer in the Suburbs of deires, nor to be confined within the portal of felicity, reolved to imparadie their hearts in Hymen •
Elizium; and by mar • iage (that pick-lock of chat weets) to drench their love-united
• ouls in a deluge of contentments; which accordingly was celebrated by Hiarbas's pecial command, with all the riches, pomp, and magnificence, that the highet gratitude could throw upon the greatet and mot unmatched deert; and with all the pleaures that might bribe a contemplative mind to toop to the lure of ene.

Among the variety of repreentations, whereby the wits of the Court trove to form delight in the fancy, the Princes Amphigenia with the chief Ladies of the Court, preented a Mask before the King and ome of the chiefet Nobl •• where the Muick was o rapturous, as would even confound an earth bred ear, that at firt hearing few could bear o trong a tranportation; The well agreeing notes eeming to combine together to atonih ouls with udden ravihment, & in their ex
••• es to perw • de them they heard the Spheres rowing harmony, for it eemed to the tronget ear, as if the
Muicians had contracted that heavenly melody, in the narrow circumference of their intruments, or had made an Epitome of its weetet trains; to which the Maskers footing kept uch even time, as none but would have thought the air (moved by the inchanting inews of the Intruments) danced her finet meaures after the motions of their feet. So that they eemed (as it were) the Intelligences that moved the Orbes of Muick.
But thee delights erved but to awaken Celania's evil Genius, who by the light of Hymens Torch dicovered a way to mother all her new-born joys, which was this.

It happened that at this time the • e was a Knight of Pandions at the Court, by name Dokimatus, one that pretended to be a revolter from his Mater, but was indeed a Spye, that Pandion had appointed under that diguize to pry into Hiarbas's affairs; who as he had reolution to attempt any thing that might further his Maters deigns, o he had craft and ubtilty to direct his reolution one that had learnt the Art of Ininuation, and with the Gyges Ring of deceit could walk undicovered in the midt of others privacies; one that would eem to dicloe himelf nakedly to his very thoughts, but yet make that nakednes his thoughts bet clothing. Words are the ouls reounding pourtraiture; he that draws a fale picture of his mind, pencils diimulation, not his own reemblance. He that agreeth not with himelf, whoe thoughts and words j • rr, his tongue refuing to accord with his mind in the harmony of truth, how can he be tho • ght to agree with another? But by this means had he crept into Hiarbas favour, o that nothing was concealed from him that he lited to dicover, and he li •• ed to dicover as much as did tend to his Maters advantage.

This Dokimatus being preent at the Mask, giving liberty to his eyes to range among that Paradie of Beauties, chanced among other Ladies to epye Celania covered with her Veil, according to her wonted garb; who having not her education among thoe of that Sex which he eemed to peronate, and therefore unacquainted with many female accomplihments, in the catalogue of which the compleat deportment of the body in Dancing is eteemed not the leat, which he being wholly a tranger to, and therefore jutly fearing let at the Mask he • hould unmask her elf, choe rather to obcure her ignorance with the mit of a pretended reervednes, and to make another bluh with a coy repule, than her elf ahamed with an indicreet familiarity. The trangenes of her garb and deportment, as they made many other objects ungazed on, by affording as much matter for admiration as they for delight, o in particular they drew a more curious obervation from Dokimatus than others, becaue that obervation begat a conceipt in him that was not in others, viz. that this Celania was no other then Glycera the Nunn, his Maters he-idoll, ecaped out of Cyprus, and for love of ome Courtier or other fled thither under that diguie.

This conceipt having admiion into his thoughts, did by degrees conquer all oppoition, bribe his belief with accumulation of Arguments from his continued obervation, and at length give it elf the overaignty in his mind; o that he reolved, that ince his obervation had conquered his belief, his belief hould Mater his purpoe, (which was to end her to Pandion) but his purpoe hould attend as a • ervant to opportunity. And that his Preent might be more acceptable he determined to end Amphigenia, that o Pandion having the heir of the Kingdom in his cutody, and
Hiarbas's onely child, he might be able with les difficulty to conquer his deigns.

Thee reolves he cloetted in his thoughts, till Time the winged Pot-hore of opportunity, that Whet-tone of reolution that keenes the edge of the dullet mind, hould bring the news of ucces. The next morning by that time Aurora's bluhing cheeks had wept her pearly drops, and itting in her gilded Chariot drawn with purple Steeds, had chat away the Stars, and triumphed over the gloomy Night, the two Princees Amphigenia and Celania having foraken the Snowy Paradie of their beds, walked forth into the Groves and Gardens, to hare in the Morns refined pleaures; where as they paed along, the gentle ditilling dew would eem to weep for their departure, whilt the Wetern iue of the perfumed air would oftly fan their treing cur • es with its flowry wings, the wift winged ingers triving which hould alute them with the weetet airs.

It happened that at this time Ternotus a Squire that attended on Dokimatus, invited forth by the Morns mollitious weets, was walking upon a little hill to refreh himelf with Zephyres cooling gales, where he chanced to epy thee two Ladies, itting under the green Canopy of a hady Bower, and earnet in dicoure. Celania had her beauty ecliped with her Lilly Veil, as he had wont; but Amphigenia fully diplayed the treaure of her beauty, where he eemed to hew all the riches of Nature; as he at under the Bower her eyes eemed pearly Bowers where thouands of Loves and Graces eemed to flutter up and down, and with their wift Arrows feathered with Majetick lovelines, and tipt with Diamonds, would wound beholders hearts: So that the Bower eemed a hady Palace, where heart-commanding beauty, attended with a
great retinue of perfections, eemed to keep its Court; or as an Aylum under whoe verdant Roof, the Stars in day time kept their reidence.

Ternotus having paid a little duty to admiration (as whom would it not tranport with wonder, to behold o many wonders?) run to his Mater, and told him what lovely objects that morning had aluted his eyes withall. Dokimatus hearing that, went by his Squires direction to the place where he beheld thoe two excellent Ladies, whom he had no ooner een, but he knew to be Celania and Amphigenia; the rays of whoe beauty made the day-break of occaion, for the execution of his plot; o that he preently dicloes his intents to Ternotus (having firt worn him to ecreie.) Much time they pent not in travering of their thoughts, till at length having agreed upon a way, which their reaon perwaded them would prove effectual, They on a udden ruh into the Grove, where the Ladies at (Ternotus having firt fetcht their weapons, and a uit of Apparel that belonged to one of Dokimatus's attendants) and by force carryed them into a little Valley, ome ditance from the Gardens, where they dirobed Celania of her Garments, and clothed her in that habit, and et Amphigenia in a Coach that they had prepared ready for that purpoe; but by that time they had accompliht their endeavors, the hrieks of Amphigenia ( • oth for her urprizal, and the fear he took at a bloudy fight that grew between Celania and Dokimatus, who ignorant of Celania's Sex and Valour, had put a word in her hand, thinking if any hould dicover them, it might be thought that he had conveyed Amphigenia away by force.) But I ay Amphigenia's out-crys, the Airy meengers of her miery, had oon carryed tydings of it to the ears of many in the Court, and with a doleful hrillnes
challenged peedy uccour; who hearkning more to the noie, than to dicretion or deliberation, ran out, ome dret, ome undret, ome with Weapons, ome without, but uing the till mourning voice, as a winged guide, by which they directed their teps, until they came to the Valley, where they beheld Dokimatus deperately engaged in a Combat with Celania, whom now in that garb they knew to be Danpion; and as for Amphigenia, he was hurried away in the Coach, with o much wiftnes, as to prevent being overtaken with the nimblet Foot-man; yet not o as to prevent their ears from overtaking the voyce, which like winged Pegaus, rode on the ayr, and cryed, Help Amphigenia, Help Amphigenia.

This ight and voice o filled the eyes and ears of the new arrived company, did o ditract and confound them with amazement, and all thoe Paions that atonih pirits with amazing confuion at uch udden accidents, as that whilt their hatred to Danpion, but love and duty to Amphigenia, prompted them both to kill the one, and ave the other, and at once to do all things, the welling Torrent of Amazement, dammed up the Current of their deires, and compelled them to do nothing: Some would purue Amphigenia, whilet themelves were overtaken with a raging grief; others would fight with Danpion, whilet themelves were conquered with a mad rage.

Thus the fight continued for a time, to <> detruction of many, but the admiration of all Danpion encountring with the multitude for Amphigenia, as Hercules once did with the many-headed H • dra, for the Heperides golden fruit; till at length, jut as he was going to urrender up himelf, there came running among them a Hore, b • oken looe out of the Coach that carried away Amphigenia; who not regarding the multitude,
ran furiouly among them, as if it had been one of Phaeton's mad Palfreys, and killed ome, trampled on others, and dipert them all; o that Danpion watched his opportunity, catched hold of the Reigns, and wanting neither agility of body, prightfulnes of mind, nor skill in horman-hip, nimbly vaulted upon him, and in the • ight of them all, made his ecape.

By this time newes was fled to the King, that Danpion had carried away by force his Daughter, and with her, the princes Celania, and how that Dokimatus was much wounded in their defence, and many others lain, and how that his jut revenge for all thee villainous acts, was anticipated by Danpion's flight: But as if thee wounding words, Force, and Flight, had forc'd his Reaon to flight, he o unreaonably tormed, as he eemed nothing but an • odd compoition of Paion: What (aid he) Amphigenia gone? And with that he tampt on the ground with his foot, and made the earth quake with his fury, whilt fury made an Earth-quake in him: But then he went on,—Amphigenia! The life of all my Comforts, the tay of all my Hopes, and the very treaury of my Joyes; and is he gone? Gone? Nay ravihed; ravihed? Nay dead, for ought I know. Oh! Deadly word! Dead! and I live, and live to ee all this unrevenged? Oh! Tyrant-heaven! Was it not enough to rob me of my Daughter? My only Daughter, but you mut plunder me of all means for revenge too? For Revenge, for Jutice; if it be not jut to rid the world of uch a Monter, I know not what is jut; and if o, Why did you blindly put the Sword of Jutice into my hands? But oh! you Powers! If you will tyrannize, I am your Vice-gerent, and am warranted by your example; and with that he commanded his Courtiers peedily to purue them, and threatned to hang them, if they came back without one, or both.

But now, to return to Danpion, who had overtaken Amphigenia, by that time the Coach was arrived at Pandion's Catle; o that ome of the Souldiers that were upon the Walls, eeing a gallant and beautiful Lady, hunted by a man on Hor-back, with a drawn Sword (for Danpion, by reaon of the madnes of the Hore, had not time to imprion it in the Scabbard, and loath he was to diarm himelf, knowing not what future accidents might require its ervice) they ran preently out of the Gates, and commanded them to yield •
Danpion not being accutomed to urrender on uch eai • terms, began to treat with them in the churlih language of War, and dipute his Title to Liberty; till at lat he was confuted by the harp Sophitry of multiplyed Swords: who, after they had argued a while in the chool of War, at lat prevailed, and led them to Pandions General; who at the firt view of thee two excellent and beautiful Peronages, was poet with uch extreme wonder, that every beam of their Beauty, was a bright Key, that lockt up his enes in the Prion of amazement.

As for Danpion, though his Habit became not one of his Birth and Greatnes, yet he o became his Habit, as he eemed to put a Majety on Poverty; that whilet his garb preented him as anothers ervant, all thoe excellent endowments, that give height of mind in the lowet fortune, attended on him: His Eyes were graced with uch a verecundious ternnes, as eemed at once to allure and threaten; ome terrifying flahes would glance from them, but yet with uch a mixture of a well-becoming uavity, as inflamed the heart with a greater admiration of his Beauty: His Countenance (in which appeared no common Ayr) though omthing clouded, not with a dejecting, but rather uch a tumid grief, as uually attends thoe great ouls, whom no
fortunes can dicompoe, but thoe that deprive them of the exercie of Vertue; yet thorow thoe Clouds there hined uch Rayes of an undaunted Majety, as might well deerve the highet admiration in thoe mindes that eteem nothing vulgar.

But as for Amphigenia, he eemed a Peron o incomparably excellent, tis fitter to leave the Soul extaied with the contemplation of her Beauty, than to attmept its Delineation, ince no Tongue, nor Pen can pourtray them, but mut be vat debtors to her Perfections. And that that added no mal lutre to her Excellencies, was her Magnanimity under this misfortune, chuing rather that her heart hould break within, than her orrow break out; and reolving, that Death hould ravih her Soul from her Body, ooner than the addet accident her Vertue from her Soul; and making it the chiefet point of Vertue, to be commander of her inward Paions, whilet her outward etate was a ervant to Fortune: And this preent miery, though circumtanced with all the evils that envy could wih for, or her elf detet, not only her Peron, but her Chatity being at the dipoal of one, whom a double Antipathy, both as a man, and an enemy made infinitely hateful; yet by foyling it with her Vertue, he made erve, but as an Ornament to the beauty of her Vertues: So that the Clouds of adnes in her Countenance, made the brighter reflections of the beams of a tately Majety.

Whilet Pandion was taken up with the Propect of uch Heavenly Apects, the Coach-man (that had been the Charon that had hurried this ad Princes to uch a Hell of miery) comes to him, and humbly craves a minutes conference: He conenting, the Coach-man informs him, who that beautiful Subject of his admiration was, and by what, and whoe means, and for what end he had conveyed her thither; and as for the other,
he preumed he was ome Attendant of the Kings, by whoe command he purued them.

This news was as a Charm to Pandion's Paion, that gently did allay the urges of atonihment, and converted them into a mooth Sea of contentment: For now he doubted not but to procure the Kingdom, ince he had gotten the Inherit • ix within his Power, by making her to reign up her Right, to ranom her Chatity, or her Farher his Power, to ranom her. And oberving in the looks of Danpion, the Enigns of a brave reolute mind, and fearing let by his valour he hould releae the Princes, he gave trict charge to the chief Commander of the Catle, that if within a hort pace none came to redeem him, he hould be put to Death, to atisfie for the blood of thoe of his men whom he had lain.

But as he was farther peaking, he was interrupted by a udden Allarm, given to the Souldiers within by the Watch; who (it eems) had not only een a Cloud of dut arie, as if ome Demogorgon had belcht through a porous part of the earth, but they had alo epyed, epecially, when the Wind made a cham in this duty Region, the hining of Armour, which like portentous Comets threatned Detructions; or as glitring Stars were the Harbingers of a bloody day to enue.

This Martial noie coming to Pandions ears, as the Prologue of a bloody Scene, by reaon of his Authority, did challenge, with Authority from him, a particular Attendance; who loath to make negligence the Author of an irrecoverable Ruine, or his Ruine the mark of an unredeemable neglect, preently runs upon the Catle-walls, where he might epye vat Numbers of hining Swords, which though naked, where heathed in a terrible brightnes, and Armour, inlayed with Sun-beams, and Bucklers, that played at
Tenis with the Sun; and many other Objects, that might beget delight in a mind not already praegnant with the terror of approching danger.

Pandion already conceiving, that they were Hiarbas's men, come in recue of the Princes (as indeed they were) thought it none of the wort Policy, to de • a • d their too peedy aault, by ending a Herauld with Propoals, and a challenge; which, after conultation with ome of the chief Commanders, he did; the purport of whoe Meage was this: That both for putting a Period to that detructive War, whoe terrible effects had hitherto been no other than the acking of many famous Towns and Cities, the ranacking and plundring of many Lords and Gentlemen, and the general depopulating of the whole Kingdom; That the whole quarrel hould be decided by the Perons mot and onely concern'd, (which was the King and himelf) in a ingle Combate; which proffer, in regard of the advantage he had in poeing, not onely the greater part of the Realm, but the Realms immediate Heir, he could not but judge jut and honourable, upon which grounds he hoped it would be o eteemed and accepted.

The Herauld having his Meage given him, clothed in the Apparel of his Office, attended by a Trumpet, and (as Pandion had commanded) carrying a Gantlet dipt in blood, rides to the Army, where he craves audience of the King; which being granted, he
•• ung down his Gantlet, and delivered his Challenge.

The King hearing it, replyed, That it was not the cutom of Kings to decend to a private Duell with a Subject, much les with a Rebel; but if it was, that his Caue was not o unjut, that he feared ucces, nor his Souldiers uch Cowards, as they feared to fight, nor his Condition o low, as to ue deperate means,
nor himelf o unwie, as to leave his Caue, and Condition, Peron, and Army, to the Governance and Arbitration of For • une and Chaunce, which is apt ever to favour the rah and foolih: And were his Condition never o low, he would have him know, that Kings in their lowet etate, are highly coniderable, and one grain of Majety will weigh down many light pretences; though may be not in the Ballance of popular judgment, yet in theirs who poize the Univere.

And for his Kingdom and Daughter, though by he did not know what blind fortune he had attained ome part of the firt, and by a bae inferior Combination with Traytors, uch as himelf, he had innared the latter; yet let not (aid he) that ucces heighten his preumption, nor encourage his pereverance, ince the one will but add Unpardonablenes, and the other an impoibility of recovery to his horrid Rebellion: Therefore (aid he) I hall not eek to ranom the one with the other, but if he means to redeem himelf, let him reign both to my Protection, and himelf to my Mercy. With this anwer the Herauld returned, and acquainted Pandion, who expected, and indeed deired no other; the end of his Meage being onely to dally with Time, that paced by fater, than conited with the well-fare of his affairs. But having now all things in a readines, he marches forth with his men, and as he goes, commands the Captain of the Catle, that peedy execution be done upon Hiarbas's ervant, and charges him to be as vigilant of Amphigenia, as he would of his oul, were it in anothers keeping. The Captain having thus his Orders given hi • , goes to the Room where Danpion was, intending to releae him out of the Prion, but to imprion him in the Grave; but as oon as he eeth him, as if Danpion's beauty had turned him into Marble, he tands till, as if he grew to
the ground, and fixes his eye tedfatly upon him, as if he would inoculate his oul into him; at length, like one returned out of a Trance, he kneels down and kies his hand. Danpion eeing this, at firt amazed at his amazement, and now no les atoniht at this Complement, thus pake to him: Sir (aid he) my fortunes require no uch condecenions. Sir (aid the other) not onely the lowet condecenions, but the highet overaignty is your due by Decent and Deert. Sir (replyed Danpion) as I have not o much vanity to think my elf worthy of the honour you impoe upon me, nor o little gratitude, as not to tetifie my reentments, though in huge diproportion to your civilities; o neither am I o happy, as not to be able to accue my thoughts with the urrendry of your Name and Peron to Oblivion; which I mut needs regiter in the Catalogue of my misfortunes. Sir (aid the other) your Noble thoughts are too much buied in the contemplation of goodnes, ever to admit of uch diverions, as the remembrance of o mean a Peron as my elf, who have nothing in me that may merit regard, but that I once erved your Highnes in the quality of a Foter-father, being that ame Celadon the Foreter, who once had the care of your Royal Peron in your infancy, whilt your tender age, unable for elf-protection, expoed you to the malice and tyranny of your Enemy Hiarbas. Danpion hearing this, fell upon his neck, and embraced him, and even wept with joy, the tears trickling down, like rain in Sun-hine. After ome mutual tetimony of great endearments that paed betwixt them, the Foreter kneeled down, and asked him pardon for his trayterous adhering to his Enemy; but the reaon of it (he aid) was partly through fear, being terrified with the los of all that nature and affection could entitle Precious, upon the leat intimation
of dicovery; and partly for gain, being bribed with liberal gifts, and great honors, above what he knew how to manage, being made Commander of the Catle where Pandion chiefly had his reidence; all which he the more freely accepted, becaue he then dipaired of ever bleing his eyes with the ight of his Highnes; uppoing he had been torn in peices with ome of that brutih Nation, whom he ued for his port to perecute.

This aid, they fell into dicoure about Danpions condition, whether there was any hopes or means for ecape; the Foreter having firt informed him, how that Hiarbas was come with an Army to redeem his Daughter; then whether it was poible to procure admiion to Amphigenia; and whether Pandion intended any injury or dihonor to her; and whether by force or tratagem he might be relea • ed: but as they were thus dicouring, ome ouldiers with a hate too low for their minds, though too fat for their leggs, came tumbling into the room, and called away the Foreter their Captain.

Long had they not been eparated, ere Danpion heard a noie that ounded like a rude conort of many ill-agreeing voices, which eemed to keep time to the Martial Muick of clahing of words, and jutling of Armor; amongt which he heard from a neighboring Chamber uch hrieks, as eemed to teach the Air in an unperfect manner the prefect language of miery, which by reaon of its diordered convoy (the Air being variouly divided with a trange confuion of noies) came not to his ears o ditinctly as to give him information of the Autho • , yet by a trange ymyathy, it eemed to wound his oul. His mind in travail with multitudes of conceptions, would fain have been eaed of its tortures, with the knowledge of Amphigenia's condition,
which he endeavored by a near acces to the Chamber, where all thoe doleful births were generated; but ah! not to a freedom f • om, but an augmentation of his orrow, for he plainly, too plainly knew it be the voice of Amphigenia. With that, as if every hriek had been a Dart, not from orrow but from death, not from an ordinary death, but from a oul-torturing death, from a death made deadly with torments, having his enes tupified, and his reaon confounded, not with a orrow, rather a deperate madnes, he ran about exclaiming againt Heaven, Hell, Earth, Men, Devils; Heaven for permitting her to be abued, Earth for being the Theatre of uch an accured Tragedy; Men for the Actors, & the Devils for the Inpi • ers. Then he would cry out; Oh! Celadon! why didt thou reerve me for this? thee are torments would make an Atlas grown, hould a thouand Lyons Den within my breat, they would not tear me like one groan of Amphigenia's. Oh! cured walls that hinder all my attempts. And cruel Heaven! that denyes me the common cure of miery, a way to dye, which every lave can command; one dying groan would umm up all my mieries. Tis true, as a Prince I ought to reerve my elf for better fortunes, and not to abandon my elf though all the world forake me; yet as a Lover of Amphigenia, I ought not to hope for joy whilt he remains a Captive to her enemies, and the contrary paion. Thee and the like words did Danpion utter; and thus did he acrifize himelf to an unexpreible paion, who in all things ele hewed himelf commander of an undaunted mind. But now to leave him, and return to Pandion, who perceiving that Hiarbas was reolute in his purpoes, and wie in his reolutions, and trong to execute what his widom had reolved upon, thought it more widom to Treat with him peaceably, than to referr his caue to the Arbitration of War, whoe partial
deciion he feared, epecially conidering the unjutnes of his caue had made him an Out-law to Heaven, from whom he could challenge no protection, and therefore he again ends an Envoy with certain Propoals to the King. The um of which was this, That if the King regarded either his own or his Daughters afety or honor, he hould retreat with his men, otherwie he mut not hope for any other entertainment for himelf or her, than what a mortal enemy would betow on the mot hateful peron. And to let them ee that his performance hould be of an equal extent with his threatnings, before the meenger could deliver his errant, receive an anwer, and return, Pandion had caued a Scaffold to be erected, whereon preently appeared a mot excellent Lady, lead between two executioners, whom both by her Garments, and the Majety that apparrelled her deportments, Hiarbas knew to be his Daughter, for there eemed in her (as well as he could perceive at uch a ditance) the ame delicate lovelines, lovely excellency, Majetick weetnes, as were the ingredients of o divine a compoition as Amphigenia's Beauty; and if the ame perfections, then ure the ame peron, ince none could boat of an equality with her, in whom appeared all the excellencies, not wherewith Nature had, but wherewith he could beautifie a body. A lamentable ight it was to ee, the Diamond of the World et in an endles Ring of mieries; to ee her act her own Tragedy, whoe countenance eemed the Theatre of Love and Beauty; to ee her to whom all hearts do homage, to bow to an injurious fortune. And that that did extort pity from the cruellet heart, was the manner of her getures, wherewith he eemed to Antedate her miery, and make miery it elf more mierable, at leat more lamentable; for her eyes were fixt on Heaven, as if he meant to dart her Soul
thither, and prevent her enemies cruelty; her tongue not profue of words, her orrow eeming to feed it elf with inward contemplation; yet thoe few wherein he embodied her thoughts, were guarded with uch a captivating force, as would have compelled a Tyrants heart, to pitty her orrow; but they were no ooner Midwived by her tongue, than wadled up in Air, and o bequeathed to Heaven, that few ears could boat themelves to be the Nureries of uch Divine off-prings of a Heavenly Soul. Her hands were claped and folded each in other, and eemed to take their lat embracements; her arms not extended at their length, but omething bowing, eemed to embrace orrow, not as an unjut effect of humane malice, but as a jut reult of a Divine decree.

In fine, in all her getures, there was uch a Majetick humility, conquering ubmiion, unconquered Piety, olid devotion, as made a lively and beautiful repreentation, of what a great mind could do, depreed under the lowet fortune. But though the beholders, yea the actors were o acted by pity, as to pour forth their ene of her condition in tears, and (as it were) by a repentance to wah way the crime before Commiion, yet at length as if the neceity of Commiion had banihed away all thoughts of the crime, not the act, when they aw Hiarbas's men, marching in the order and poture they came into the Field differing in nothing but in peedy motion, which too peedily gave them to undertand, that their purpoe was to redeem Amphigenia by force not by Treaty, they by Pandions command, preently eparate her Head and Soul from her Body. But no ooner did the Air convey this ad and bloody pectacle to the eyes of Hiarbas, but he eemed • s if rage and orrow had borrowed his body to make a lively re • reentation of the deadly pang of a thunder <> oul.
Flahes flew from his eyes, as if he meant to et the world on fire in revenge of his Daughter; or as if he thought to ue no other light, in corn of the Sun, whom in his thoughts he accued of conpiracy with them. And he commands his men to fall on, and pare none but Pandion, that as he had been uperlative in his Treaons, o he might be exemplary in his tortures. The King had no ooner poke thee, or the like words, but the ignal was given, not for the battel, but (to the atonihment of Pandion and his whole Army, and of the Sun it elf, which then hid his face in a cloud) for the execution of a plot between the General and his Commanders, which was to take their own King prioner in the head of his Army, and to deliver him up to Pandion; which by reaon the combination was o trong, was oon and eaily effected without edition or mutiny.

Pandion amazed at this udden turn of the wheel of Fortune, knew not at firt how to interpret it, but till tood upon his defence expecting ome tratagem. And no les were his whole Army, though now by a trange fate Victorious, conquered with extremity of wonder; atonihment viibly tryumphing in every mans countenance, till at length their wonder was converted into joy, by the reignation of Hiarbas into Pandions poeion; who conidering it was not a time to indulge himelf to any paion, when uch trength of reaon was required for the wie improvement of uch an overture of fortune, thought it the bet way now if ever, to fit Hiarbas's Crown for his own head, when melted in a Fu • nace of misfortune, it eemed apt to receive any form; and therefore caues trong
• uards to be placed every where, and particularly about himelf, and now tronger then ever, his neceity being greater, and his force more, by the addition
of Hiarbias's men. This done, he commands the Royal Robes • o be produced, and in them Hiarbas to be attired, and o attired to go up on the Scaffold, which was by this time covered with purple Velvet, fringed and embroydered with Gold, and there to eat himelf in a Throne on purpoe prepared, with a Crown on his head, the Scepter in his hand, and the Sword born before him.

The King thus forced to act over a Pageant-like hew of Majety, to adorn the tryumph of treachery, and to add olemnity to cruelty, its in the Throne, with a heavy but imperious look, that the Beams of Majety eemed to unite and centre in his contracted brow, and with a trange kind of force to write a Law, not of pity, but of a reverential adoring a King though ditret.
And whilt he thus its, ometimes looking with an autere and cornful eye on Pandion, ometimes darting threats with a dauntles look at his ouldiers, Pandion caues Heralds to proclame;

Firt, That he had ignobly uurped the Royal dignity, and detained it by force and fraud, from himelf the lawful heir; which words pronounced, an Officer of State, appointed for that purpoe, took away the Crown, and et it on Pandions head.

Secondly, That he had unjutly uurped the power of adminitration of Jutice, to the general endamagement of the whole Realm, and to the particular injury of the jut and lawful Soveraign; which pronounced, they took away the Sword, and caued it to be delivered to Pandion.
Thirdly, That as he had uurped the upreme power of judicature, o of Government; this proclamed, they took from him the Scepter, and gave it Pandion.
Fourth, That he had uurped the Royal Throne, from the lawful inheritor; this was no ooner with a lowder voice than ordinary proclaimed, than the King was compelled to arie out of the Throne.

Latly, It was proclaimed, that as he was by univeral conent of the whole Kingdom, depoed from all overaignty, o he mut be depoyled of all Enigns of Majety, that Pandion might be therewith inveted, to whom by an indubitate ucceion they belonged; upon which words Hiarbas was deveted of the purple Robe, and forced to ait in the invetiture of Pandion; which done, Pandion its down in the Throne, and was proclaimed King of Tbealia, whilt Hiarbas was lead away a prioner into the Catle, chained in fetters of Gold; who as he went would have poke to the pectators, who conited mot of ouldiers, but he was interrupted by great acclamations of the people, that cryed, God ave King Pandion.

Thus was this great Prince, one not undeerving that title and power, had he not ued unjut means to entitle him to that power, one whoe oul was richly furniht with all thoe endowments of Fortitude, Jutice, Prudence, and Temperance, which are the imples that contitute a true Princely mind, and one who never before was unfortunate, unles in being too great a courter of Fortune; thus (I ay) was this o brave, o great a Prince on the udden thrown from the top of the highet pinacle of honor and overaignty, being lead captive at Noon, for the world to behold a clear mirror of Fortunes prodigious levity, and an exact model of the incontancy of humane felicity.

Pandion having at a while in great tate, aries out of his Throne, comes down from the Scaffold, and goes into his Catle attended with great numbers of
Lords and Commanders, and guarded with ouldiers, Hiarbas's General all the while bearing the word before him; where having paued a while on this udden, and no les trange, than udden mutation, the thoughts of all men being at a tand, and not able to flye higher with admiration, to ee an imperious word melted into an imperial Diadem, to ee a Crown formed into fetters, treachery to generate Royalty, and Royalty to degenerate into miery.

In fine, to ee him who late thundered from a Throne, whoe voice was power, and whoe looks were Majety, to be dethron'd with the thunder of fortune, plundered of all power, and deplum'd of Majety: They at lat fell into conultation, how to etablih that power by prudence, they had acquired by policy; great fortunes requiring as great force of mind, to conquer thoe difficulties that attended them once gotten, as they did force of body to conquer thoe enemies that oppoed their getting. After ome time pent in bandying to and fro, the various exigencies of State, the mutynies, editious uproars and tumults, that are the uual effects of alterations in a Monarchical Government, and the bet means to upply the one, and ubdue the other, the reult of all was this, that being Pandion would be thought to come to the Throne, not as a conqueror, but inheritor; and conidering that the manyfold exactions and impoitions, laid upon the people by Hiarbas to maintain his Army, had provoked them againt both himelf and them, the ad effect whereof was palpably viible in his depoition and detruction; and that the greatet part of the Kingdom was already in ubjection and under the command of his Garrions, and it was eaie to raie a force to ubdue that part that hould rebell, that therefore his Armies hould be disbanded, with promies
of plenary atisfaction for their ervice, which (they aid) would be a great engagement to his people to Loyalty, when they aw him eteem their love, as his principal protection.

And as for the General, that had done uch eminent and loyal ervice, he hould be eminently and Royally rewarded, and dimied with his me • to march at his leiure. And as for a Life-guard, it was thought rather decent, than convenient not any neceity, but ceremony of State requiring it. Therefore a certain number of choice Warlike Gentlemen were culled out, to guard his Peron, whereof Celadon was made Commander.

Thee things concluded on, were accordingly executed; the Army being dimi • t, with great thanks for their gallant ervice; the peron imployed in that office, telling them how highly the King reented their fidelity, and e •• eemed their valour, and that his rewards hould be parallel to his reentment and eteem.

This done, they further conult about the dipoal of Hiarbas's Peron; but as they at in Council, arguing pro and con, ome making plain peeches the Keys to their thoughts; others, Pathetical Orations, as windows to their deires, but others attiring both their thoughts and deires in ambiguous Expreions, which like changable Taffata might variouly reflect their minds; they heard in a Room underneath, uch a conort of doleful moans, as expret the wofull muick of a grieved mind. Somtimes they might hear groans formed into words, and words transformed into groans, that orrow eemed to build an Airy Pyramis, under which it entombed all joy; the deep-fetcht groans reembling the Bais, as the hrill cries the Spire. Pa •
dion hearing that, gave command, that the Authors of thoe lamentations hould be brought before him, to
give an account wherefore they temporize with orrow, when joy was the Genius of thoe miling hours. No ooner was the command given forth, than obeyed, the Peron being caued to appear, and no ooner appeared, than was known to be Danpion, by many of the Lords that had acquaintance with him, whilt he had acquaintance with a bright properity in Hiarbas's Court; but to Pandion only to be that ervant of Hiarbas, whom he had entenced to dye; which when he aw not executed, he eemed like one that travelled far from himelf, till the conideration that variety of occaions might well divert the mind of Celadon, interrupted the farther progres of his thoughts, and gave him occaion to charge trictly, that executi • n be peedily performed, threatning with a look o evere as eemed to antedate his threatning, no les than death for the leat delay.

This aid, the Prioner was led away; but as he went, none but might have een in him, a perfect image of captiv'd courage; his rage, not becaue he was to dye, but that any other than a victorious Launce hould force him to dye, though imprioned in his thoughts by reolution, yet fluht forth at his eyes; his countenance all the while repreenting the undaunted contancy •
wherewith he armed his mind, now he was to run the gauntlet with an invincible Enemy, yet at the ame time attiring his looks in uch a graceful Majety, as if this was but his marriage-day with Death having conideration rather to what might become his own Princely greatnes, than the ordidnes of his pale Spoue.
But jut as he was going out of the door, on the udden a voice bolted forth thee words, A Crown becoms not a Peaants head.

Pandion hearing that, cryed out, What Treaon's that? But carce had the cadence of his voyce put a
period to his peech, but a fearfull pectacle oon anwered his fearfull Interrogation, and deprived him of his fear, by preenting the evil he feared; for preently there iued out from under the Hangings, men clad in Armour, with naked Swords, who eized on Pandion in the midt of all his Pomp, whilt he was dictating Lawes with his Looks, and commanding obervance with his Brow, and hale him out of his Throne, diarray him of his Robes, rob him of that golden Jayl that imprion'd his head, and plunder him of all his plendor: So oon can a tempet of miery wah away a new gilded Fortune: Thus every Jewel of a Princes Diadem is a Star of mot malignant influence to Uurpers.

Scarce this was done, before Danpion was call'd back with peed; and no ooner turned, than received by Hiarbas's General, with all humility upon his knees; whom Danpion trictly oberving, he knew to be his friend Athalus: With that he caued him to arie, and with great joy embraced him, telling him, that now he had found him to be a compoition of incere friendhip, and that his oul was a meer extract of goodnes, and many other expreions, whereby he tetified his great reentments: After which, Athalus
• hered him in among the Lords, to whom he made an eloquent Oration, in which he declared, how that this Peron, whom they aw ready to be acrifized to the revenge of a Traytor, was the true Pandion, rightful Heir to Agis; which he confirmed by many Arguments, but chiefly by Celadon's acknowledgment then preent, a chief Actor in this late turn; and that the other, that had hitherto deluded them, was but an Impotor, being a Peaants on, his father at preent living in B • o
••• , and that his name was Eumaeus; which was alo confirmed by the free and unextor • ed confeion of Lumaeus, or the counterfeit Pandion.

Thee things thus trangely brought about, Royal Apparel was preently brought for Pandion, who now commands Hiarbas's peedy releament, and that he hould be brought to him; which done, he makes himelf known to him, returning him infinite thanks for all received favours, telling him what a high-umm'd debt he had contracted from his Royal goodnes.

After which, he began to clear himelf of that inexcuable incivility, Bacanius's malice and treachery had reproched him withall, confeing what flames Amphigenia had inkindled in his heart, which neither life nor death—but as he was farther peaking, the thoughts of Amphigenia divorced his mind from every thing but Revenge, that he preently commands that Eumaeus, and all that had any hand in her death, hould undergo the everet punihment the Law in its trictet interpretation could inflict.

Eumaeus hearing this, fell down on his knees, and asked pardon, but was not at all regarded, till he confet that the Lady that was executed, was not Amphigenia, but another in her Apparel, whom (he aid) he put to death, for endeavouring to betray him, and in that manner to terrifie Hiarbas.

Every man atoniht at the hearing of this, no les than if the Gods had come down from Heaven, to act wonders on Earth: but epecially Pandion and Hiarbas, whoe affection had increaed their admiration, even to a tranport: but recollecting themelves, they commanded he hould be brought to them, that they might bles their eyes with ight of the mot beautiful Lady, that ever made her Sex adored; which to their unexpreable joy, wa • oon performed.
