Amphigenia appearing in a mean habit, but o, as her beauty eemed to put a Majety on meannes: whom no ooner Hiarbas beheld, but he ran and embraced
her with omthing more fondnes of affection than became a wie Father, and more condecenion, than was fit for a King in uch a preence to declare.

And as for Pandion, the exces of joy at the firt ight almot took away the act of eeing, and pillaged his memory of thoe high-flown expreions that the raptures of love had created in his fancy; but in an humble manner begged pardon for whatoever of his, that in the trictet ene might be interpreted rudenes, which (he aid) proceeded from an irreitible impule of affection: And further he craved of her, that ince it was not her pleaure, o much as to inparadize his Form in her thoughts, (for her eyes were omthing cat aide upon the wall, hewing a lofty kind of humility) but to make an inanimate creature the object of his envy, that yet he would permit his lips, as Pilgrims from his heart, to acrifize the pure Oblations of his Love upon her hand, that pure hrine of purenes, and there to incribe its Image, that when the beauties of her hand, might challenge a glance from her eyes, that glance might challenge remembrance from her thoughts, of the humblet of her ervants, and the mot paionately devoted to her Princely Vertues.

Having aid this, he adventured to take her hand, and teal the riches of a Kis, from that oft and delicate Treaury; which he permitted, with a countenance that hewed rather how he hated her captivity, than loved her Captive.
Thee alutations being pat, Amphigenia was conducted to ome Ladies, that hearing of all thee Accidents, were come to congratulate their Princees afety, and to wait upon her home to the Palace.

After which Pandion accompanyed by Hiarbas, attended by all the Lords and Gentlemen, guarded by Athalus's Army (having left Celadon Commander
in chief of the Catle) preently followed; where • having teeped ome time in an Ocean of delights, and bribed it with the choycet of Pleaures, to mend its pace, Pandion was crowned in the chief City of Thealia, with all the joy and contentment, pomp and gallantry, as might either beget Loyalty to Soveraignty, or Reverence to Majety; both which, that the people might expres, they ent up uch volleys of acclamations to the Clouds, as if they meant to torm Heaven, and plunder it of its choyet glories, wherewith to crown their King.

After which, Hiarbas would have departed to his own Kingdom of Caonia, together with his Daughter Amphigenia, there to have pent the mall remainder of his dayes: But Pandion would by no means permit it, telling him, that the whole Kingdom hould be as much at his command, as ever, only reerving the Superiority to himelf, acquainting him alo, what Impoitions of affection his Daughters worth had laid upon him; for which reaons Hiarbas conented to take up his abode in Pandion's Court, chiefly perwaded thereunto, by the hopes of having uch an incomparable Prince for his Son in Law, by whoe happy conjunction with his Daughter in marriage, the Soveraignty of Thealia might run in his Reins, which was ever the highet aym of his ambition.

Having thus led my Hero through all difficulties, into the Throne, and layd him in the lap of Fortune, it may be expected, that to compleat his happines, I hould have placed him in the Arms of his beloved Amphigenia.

But they that know the tedious intricacy, and perplexing (but yet fidling) difficulty there is in getting the love of a Coy Mitres, will I hope excue me, if I give my Pen a quietus et, after o long a Pilgrimage.
I eteem Ambition a more tolerable, and Maculine ditraction than Love: And therefore I had rather place my Hero in the more noble embraces of Fortune, than in the oft Effeminate Arms of a Lady; about which, I have not impertinent thoughts enow to pend.

Poibly I may be alo thought too hard-hearted, in leaving my other Lovers uccourles in their mieries, and not leading them out of their Labyrinths, by the Threed of my dicoure: But the vulgar Rule of Roma • ces may alve all, That the Knight mut kill the Gyant, and get the Lady.
And thoe that are not pleaed with this Concluion, let them throw away as many idle hours as I have done, and they may compleat that Story, which hath now quite jaded and dull'd my Pen.
